fields.couplet: 'A' leads letters; the Ancient Lord Leads and lords the entire world
fields.meaning: As the letter A is the first of all letters, so the eternal God is first in the world

fields.couplet: That lore is vain which does not fall  At His good feet who knoweth all
fields.meaning: What Profit have those derived from learning, who worship not the good feet of Him who is possessed of pure knowledge ?

fields.couplet: Long they live on earth who gain The feet of God in florid brain
fields.meaning: They who are united to the glorious feet of Him who passes swiftly over the flower of the mind, shall flourish long above all worlds

fields.couplet: Who hold His feet who likes nor loathes Are free from woes of human births
fields.meaning: To those who meditate the feet of Him who is void of desire or aversion, evil shall never come

fields.couplet: God's praise who tell, are free from right  And wrong, the twins of dreaming night
fields.meaning: The two-fold deeds that spring from darkness shall not adhere to those who delight in the true praise of God

fields.couplet: They prosper long who walk His way Who has the senses signed away
fields.meaning: Those shall long proposer who abide in the faultless way of Him who has destroyed the five desires of the senses

fields.couplet: His feet, whose likeness none can find, Alone can ease the anxious mind
fields.meaning: Anxiety of mind cannot be removed, except from those who are united to the feet of Him who is incomparable

fields.couplet: Who swims the sea of vice is he Who clasps the feet of Virtue's sea
fields.meaning: None can swim the sea of vice, but those who are united to the feet of that gracious Being who is a sea of virtue

fields.couplet: Like senses stale that head is vain Which bows not to Eight-Virtued Divine
fields.meaning: The head that worships not the feet of Him who is possessed of eight attributes, is as useless as a sense without the power of sensation

fields.couplet: The sea of births they alone swim Who clench His feet and cleave to Him
fields.meaning: None can swim the great sea of births but those who are united to the feet of God

fields.couplet: The genial rain ambrosia call: The world but lasts while rain shall fall
fields.meaning: By the continuance of rain the world is preserved in existence; it is therefore worthy to be called ambrosia

fields.couplet: The rain begets the food we eat
fields.meaning: Rain produces good food, and is itself food

fields.couplet: Let clouds their visits stay, and dearth Distresses all the sea-girt earth
fields.meaning: If the cloud, withholding rain, deceive (our hopes) hunger will long distress the sea-girt spacious world

fields.couplet: Unless the fruitful shower descend, The ploughman's sacred toil must end
fields.meaning: If the abundance of wealth imparting rain diminish, the labour of the plough must cease

fields.couplet: Destruction it may sometimes pour But only rain can life restore
fields.meaning: Rain by its absence ruins men; and by its existence restores them to fortune

fields.couplet: No grassy blade its head will rear, If from the cloud no drop appear
fields.meaning: If no drop falls from the clouds, not even the green blade of grass will be seen

fields.couplet: The ocean's wealth will waste away, Except the cloud its stores repay
fields.meaning: Even the wealth of the wide sea will be diminished, if the cloud that has drawn (its waters) up gives them not back again (in rain)

fields.couplet: The earth, beneath a barren sky, Would offerings for the gods deny
fields.meaning: If the heaven dry up, neither yearly festivals, nor daily worship will be offered in this world, to the celestials

fields.couplet: Were heaven above to fail below Nor alms nor penance earth would show
fields.meaning: If rain fall not, penance and alms-deeds will not dwell within this spacious world

fields.couplet: Water is life that comes from rain Sans rain our duties go in vain
fields.meaning: If it be said that the duties of life cannot be discharged by any person without water, so without rain there cannot be the flowing of water

fields.couplet: No merit can be held so high As theirs who sense and self deny
fields.meaning: The end and aim of all treatise is to extol beyond all other excellence, the greatness of those who, while abiding in the rule of conduct peculiar to their state, have abandoned all desire

fields.couplet: To con ascetic glory here Is to count the dead upon the sphere
fields.meaning: To describe the measure of the greatness of those who have forsaken the two-fold desires, is like counting the dead

fields.couplet: No lustre can with theirs compare Who know the right and virtue wear
fields.meaning: The greatness of those who have discovered the properties of both states of being, and renounced the world, shines forth on earth (beyond all others)

fields.couplet: With hook of firmness to restrain The senses five, is heaven to gain
fields.meaning: He who guides his five senses by the hook of wisdom will be a seed in the world of heaven

fields.couplet: Indra himself has cause to say How great the power ascetics' sway
fields.meaning: Indra, the king of the inhabitants of the spacious heaven, is himself, a sufficient proof of the strength of him who has subdued his five senses

fields.couplet: The small the paths of ease pursue The great achieve things rare to do
fields.meaning: The great will do those things which is difficult to be done; but the mean cannot do them

fields.couplet: They gain the world, who grasp and tell Of taste, sight, hearing, touch and smell
fields.meaning: The world is within the knowledge of him who knows the properties of taste, sight, touch, hearing and smell

fields.couplet: Full-worded men by what they say, Their greatness to the world display
fields.meaning: The hidden words of the men whose words are full of effect, will shew their greatness to the world

fields.couplet: Their wrath, who've climb'd the mount of good, Though transient, cannot be withstood
fields.meaning: The anger of those who have ascended the mountain of goodness, though it continue but for a moment, cannot be resisted

fields.couplet: With gentle mercy towards all, The sage fulfils the vitue's call
fields.meaning: The virtuous are truly called Anthanar; because in their conduct towards all creatures they are clothed in kindness

fields.couplet: From virtue weal and wealth outflow; What greater good can mankind know?
fields.meaning: Virtue will confer heaven and wealth; what greater source of happiness can man possess ?

fields.couplet: Virtue enhances joy and gain; Forsaking it is fall and pain
fields.meaning: There can be no greater source of good than (the practice of) virtue; there can be no greater source of evil than the forgetfulness of it

fields.couplet: Perform good deeds as much you can Always and everywhere, o man!
fields.meaning: As much as possible, in every way, incessantly practise virtue

fields.couplet: In spotless mind virtue is found And not in show and swelling sound
fields.meaning: Let him who does virtuous deeds be of spotless mind; to that extent is virtue; all else is vain show

fields.couplet: Four ills eschew and virtue reach, Lust, anger, envy, evil-speech
fields.meaning: That conduct is virtue which is free from these four things, viz, malice, desire, anger and bitter speech

fields.couplet: Do good enow; defer it not A deathless aid in death if sought
fields.meaning: Defer not virtue to another day; receive her now; and at the dying hour she will be your undying friend

fields.couplet: Litter-bearer and rider say  Without a word, the fortune's way
fields.meaning: The fruit of virtue need not be described in books; it may be inferred from seeing the bearer of a palanquin and the rider therein

fields.couplet: Like stones that block rebirth and pain Are doing good and good again
fields.meaning: If one allows no day to pass without some good being done, his conduct will be a stone to block up the passage to other births

fields.couplet: Weal flows only from virtue done The rest is rue and renown gone
fields.meaning: Only that pleasure which flows from domestic virtue is pleasure; all else is not pleasure, and it is without praise

fields.couplet: Worthy act is virtue done Vice is what we ought to shun
fields.meaning: That is virtue which each ought to do, and that is vice which each should shun

fields.couplet: The ideal householder is he Who aids the natural orders there
fields.meaning: He will be called a (true) householder, who is a firm support to the virtuous of the three orders in

fields.couplet: His help the monk and retired share, And celibate students are his care
fields.meaning: He will be said to flourish in domestic virtue who aids the forsaken, the poor, and the dead

fields.couplet: By dutiful householder's aid God, manes, kin, self and guests are served
fields.meaning: The chief (duty of the householder) is to preserve the five-fold rule (of conduct) towards the manes, the Gods, his guests, his relations and himself

fields.couplet: Sin he shuns and food he shares His home is bright and brighter fares
fields.meaning: His descendants shall never fail who, living in the domestic state, fears vice (in the acquisition of property) and shares his food (with others)

fields.couplet: In grace and gain the home excels, Where love with virtue sweetly dwells
fields.meaning: If the married life possess love and virtue, these will be both its duty and reward

fields.couplet: Who turns from righteous family To be a monk, what profits he?
fields.meaning: What will he who lives virtuously in the domestic state gain by going into the other, (ascetic) state ?

fields.couplet: Of all who strive for bliss, the great Is he who leads the married state
fields.meaning: Among all those who labour (for future happiness) he is greatest who lives well in the household state

fields.couplet: Straight in virtue, right in living Make men brighter than monks praying
fields.meaning: The householder who, not swerving from virtue, helps the ascetic in his way, endures more than those who endure penance

fields.couplet: Home-life and virtue, are the same; Which spotless monkhood too can claim
fields.meaning: The marriage state is truly called virtue The other state is also good, if others do not reproach it

fields.couplet: He is a man of divine worth Who lives in ideal home on earth
fields.meaning: He who on earth has lived in the conjugal state as he should live, will be placed among the Gods who dwell in heaven

fields.couplet: A good housewife befits the house, Spending with thrift the mate's resource
fields.meaning: She who has the excellence of home virtues, and can expend within the means of her husband, is a help in the domestic state

fields.couplet: Bright is home when wife is chaste If not all greatness is but waste
fields.meaning: If the wife be devoid of domestic excellence, whatever (other) greatness be possessed, the conjugal state, is nothing

fields.couplet: What is rare when wife is good What can be there when she is bad?
fields.meaning: If his wife be eminent (in virtue), what does (that man) not possess ? If she be without excellence, what does (he) possess ?

fields.couplet: What greater fortune is for men Than a constant chaste woman?
fields.meaning: What is more excellent than a wife, if she possess the stability of chastity ?

fields.couplet: Her spouse before God who adores, Is like rain that at request pours
fields.meaning: If she, who does not worship God, but who rising worships her husband, say, "let it rain," it will rain

fields.couplet: The good wife guards herself from blame, She tends her spouse and brings him fame
fields.meaning: She is a wife who unweariedly guards herself, takes care of her husband, and preserves an unsullied fame

fields.couplet: Of what avail are watch and ward? Their purity is women's guard
fields.meaning: What avails the guard of a prison ? The chief guard of a woman is her chastity

fields.couplet: Women who win their husbands' heart Shall flourish where the gods resort
fields.meaning: If women shew reverence to their husbands, they will obtain great excellence in the world where the gods flourish

fields.couplet: A cuckold has not the lion-like gait Before his detractors aright
fields.meaning: The man whose wife seeks not the praise (of chastity) cannot walk with lion-like stately step, before those who revile them

fields.couplet: An honest wife is home's delight And children good are jewels abright
fields.meaning: The excellence of a wife is the good of her husband; and good children are the jewels of that goodness

fields.couplet: The world no higher bliss bestows Than children virtuous and wise
fields.meaning: Among all the benefits that may be acquired, we know no greater benefit than the acquisition of intelligent children

fields.couplet: No evil comes and no blemish; Noble sons bring all we wish
fields.meaning: The evils of the seven births shall not touch those who abtain children of a good disposition, free from vice

fields.couplet: Children are one's wealth indeed Their wealth is measured by their deed
fields.meaning: Men will call their sons their wealth, because it flows to them through the deeds which they (sons) perform on their behalf

fields.couplet: The food is more than nectar sweet In which one's children hands insert
fields.meaning: The rice in which the little hand of their children has dabbled will be far sweeter (to the parent) than ambrosia

fields.couplet: Children's touch delights the body Sweet to ears are their words lovely
fields.meaning: The touch of children gives pleasure to the body, and the hearing of their words, pleasure to the ear

fields.couplet: The flute and lute are sweet they say Deaf to baby's babble's lay!
fields.meaning: "The pipe is sweet, the lute is sweet," say those who have not heard the prattle of their own children

fields.couplet: A father's duty to his son is  To seat him in front of the wise
fields.meaning: The benefit which a father should confer on his son is to give him precedence in the assembly of the learned

fields.couplet: With joy the hearts of parents swell  To see their children themselves excel
fields.meaning: That their children should possess knowledge is more pleasing to all men of this great earth than to themselves

fields.couplet: The mother, hearing her son's merit  Delights more than when she begot
fields.meaning: The mother who hears her son called "a wise man" will rejoice more than she did at his birth

fields.couplet: The son to sire this word is debt  \"What penance such a son begot!\"
fields.meaning: (So to act) that it may be said "by what great penance did his father beget him," is the benefit which a son should render to his father

fields.couplet: What bolt can bar true love in fact  The tricking tears reveal the heart
fields.meaning: Is there any fastening that can shut in love ? Tears of the affectionate will publish the love that is within

fields.couplet: To selves belong the loveless ones;  To oth'rs the loving e'en to bones
fields.meaning: Those who are destitute of love appropriate all they have to themselves; but those who possess love consider even their bones to belong to others

fields.couplet: Soul is encased in frame of bone  To taste the life of love alone
fields.meaning: They say that the union of soul and body in man is the fruit of the union of love and virtue (in a former birth)

fields.couplet: Love yields aspiration and thence  Friendship springs up in excellence
fields.meaning: Love begets desire: and that (desire) begets the immeasureable excellence of friendship

fields.couplet: The crowning joy of home life flows  From peaceful psychic love always
fields.meaning: These are the fruits of tranquil life of love

fields.couplet: \"Love is virtue's friend\" say know-nots  It helps us against evil plots
fields.meaning: The ignorant say that love is an ally to virtue only, but it is also a help to get out of vice

fields.couplet: Justice burns the loveless form  Like solar blaze the boneless worm
fields.meaning: Virtue will burn up the soul which is without love, even as the sun burns up the creature which is without bone, ie worms

fields.couplet: Life bereft of love is gloom  Can sapless tree in desert bloom?
fields.meaning: The domestic state of that man whose mind is without love is like the flourishing of a withered tree upon the parched desert

fields.couplet: Love is the heart which limbs must move,  Or vain the outer parts will prove
fields.meaning: Of what avail are all the external members (of the body) to those who are destitute of love, the internal member

fields.couplet: The seat of life is love alone;  Or beings are but skin and bone!
fields.meaning: That body alone which is inspired with love contains a living soul: if void of it, (the body) is bone overlaid with skin

fields.couplet: Men set up home, toil and earn  To tend the guests and do good turn
fields.meaning: The whole design of living in the domestic state and laying up (property) is (to be able) to exercise the benevolence of hospitality

fields.couplet: To keep out guests cannot be good  Albeit you eat nector-like food
fields.meaning: It is not fit that one should wish his guests to be outside (his house) even though he were eating the food of immortality

fields.couplet: Who tends his guests day in and out  His life in want never wears out
fields.meaning: The domestic life of the man that daily entertains the guests who come to him shall not be laid waste by poverty

fields.couplet: The goddess of wealth will gladly rest  Where smiles welcome the worthy guest
fields.meaning: Lakshmi with joyous mind shall dwell in the house of that man who, with cheerful countenance, entertains the good as guests

fields.couplet: Should his field be sown who first  Feeds the guests and eats the rest?
fields.meaning: Is it necessary to sow the field of the man who, having feasted his guests, eats what may remain ?

fields.couplet: Who tends a guest and looks for next  Is a welcome guest in heaven's feast
fields.meaning: He who, having entertained the guests that have come, looks out for others who may yet come, will be a welcome guest to the inhabitants of heaven

fields.couplet: Worth of the guest of quality  Is worth of hospitality
fields.meaning: The advantages of benevolence cannot be measured; the measure (of the virtue) of the guests (entertained) is the only measure

fields.couplet: Who loathe guest-service one day cry:  \"We toil and store; but life is dry\"
fields.meaning: Those who have taken no part in the benevolence of hospitality shall (at length lament) saying, "we have laboured and laid up wealth and are now without support."

fields.couplet: The man of wealth is poor indeed  Whose folly fails the guest to feed
fields.meaning: That stupidity which excercises no hospitality is poverty in the midst of wealth It is the property of the stupid

fields.couplet: Anicham smelt withers: like that  A wry-faced look withers the guest
fields.meaning: As the Anicham flower fades in smelling, so fades the guest when the face is turned away

fields.couplet: The words of Seers are lovely sweet  Merciful and free from deceit
fields.meaning: Sweet words are those which imbued with love and free from deceit flow from the mouth of the virtuous

fields.couplet: Sweet words from smiling lips dispense  More joys than heart's beneficence
fields.meaning: Sweet speech, with a cheerful countenance is better than a gift made with a joyous mind

fields.couplet: Calm face, sweet look, kind words from heart  Such is the gracious virtue's part
fields.meaning: Sweet speech, flowing from the heart (uttered) with a cheerful countenance and a sweet look, is true virtue

fields.couplet: Whose loving words delight each one  The woe of want from them is gone
fields.meaning: Sorrow-increasing poverty shall not come upon those who use towards all, pleasure-increasing sweetness of speech

fields.couplet: To be humble and sweet words speak  No other jewel do wise men seek
fields.meaning: Humility and sweetness of speech are the ornaments of man; all others are not (ornaments)

fields.couplet: His sins vanish, his virtues grow  Whose fruitful words with sweetness flow
fields.meaning: If a man, while seeking to speak usefully, speaks also sweetly, his sins will diminish and his virtue increase

fields.couplet: The fruitful courteous kindly words  Lead to goodness and graceful deeds
fields.meaning: That speech which, while imparting benefits ceases not to please, will yield righteousness (for this world) and merit (for the next world)

fields.couplet: Kind words free from meanness delight  This life on earth and life the next
fields.meaning: Sweet speech, free from harm to others, will give pleasure both in this world and in the next

fields.couplet: Who sees the sweets of sweetness here  To use harsh words how can he dare?
fields.meaning: Why does he use harsh words, who sees the pleasure which sweet speech yields ?

fields.couplet: Leaving ripe fruits the raw he eats  Who speaks harsh words when sweet word suits
fields.meaning: To say disagreeable things when agreeable are at hand is like eating unripe fruit when there is ripe

fields.couplet: Unhelped in turn good help given  Exceeds in worth earth and heaven
fields.meaning: (The gift of) heaven and earth is not an equivalent for a benefit which is conferred where none had been received

fields.couplet: A help rendered in hour of need  Though small is greater than the world
fields.meaning: A favour conferred in the time of need, though it be small (in itself), is (in value) much larger than the world

fields.couplet: Help rendered without weighing fruits  Outweighs the sea in grand effects
fields.meaning: If we weigh the excellence of a benefit which is conferred without weighing the return, it is larger than the sea

fields.couplet: Help given though millet-small  Knowers count its good palm-tree tall
fields.meaning: Though the benefit conferred be as small as a millet seed, those who know its advantage will consider it as large as a palmyra fruit

fields.couplet: A help is not the help's measure  It is gainer's worth and pleasure
fields.meaning: The benefit itself is not the measure of the benefit; the worth of those who have received it is its measure

fields.couplet: Forget not friendship of the pure  Forsake not timely helpers sure
fields.meaning: Forsake not the friendship of those who have been your staff in adversity Forget not be benevolence of the blameless

fields.couplet: Through sevenfold births, in memory fares  The willing friend who wiped one's tears
fields.meaning: (The wise) will remember throughout their seven-fold births the love of those who have wiped away their affliction

fields.couplet: To forget good turns is not good  Good it is over wrong not to brood
fields.meaning: It is not good to forget a benefit; it is good to forget an injury even in the very moment (in which it is inflicted)

fields.couplet: Let deadly harms be forgotten  While remembering one good-turn
fields.meaning: Though one inflict an injury great as murder, it will perish before the thought of one benefit (formerly) conferred

fields.couplet: The virtue-killer may be saved  Not benefit-killer who is damned
fields.meaning: He who has killed every virtue may yet escape; there is no escape for him who has killed a benefit

fields.couplet: Equity is supreme virtue  It is to give each man his due
fields.meaning: That equity which consists in acting with equal regard to each of (the three) divisions of men [enemies, strangers and friends] is a pre-eminent virtue

fields.couplet: Wealth of the man of equity  Grows and lasts to posterity
fields.meaning: The wealth of the man of rectitude will not perish, but will bring happiness also to his posterity

fields.couplet: Though profitable, turn away  From unjust gains without delay
fields.meaning: Forsake in the very moment (of acquisition) that gain which, though it should bring advantage, is without equity

fields.couplet: The worthy and the unworthy  Are seen in their posterity
fields.meaning: The worthy and unworthy may be known by the existence or otherwise of good offsprings

fields.couplet: Loss and gain by cause arise;  Equal mind adorns the wise
fields.meaning: Loss and gain come not without cause; it is the ornament of the wise to preserve evenness of mind (under both)

fields.couplet: Of perdition let him be sure  Who leaves justice to sinful lure
fields.meaning: Let him whose mind departing from equity commits sin well consider thus within himself, "I shall perish."

fields.couplet: The just reduced to poverty  Is not held down by equity
fields.meaning: The great will not regard as poverty the low estate of that man who dwells in the virtue of equity

fields.couplet: Like balance holding equal scales  A well poised mind is jewel of the wise
fields.meaning: To incline to neither side, but to rest impartial as the even-fixed scale is the ornament of the wise

fields.couplet: Justice is upright, unbending  And free from crooked word-twisting
fields.meaning: Freedom from obliquity of speech is rectitude, if there be (corresponding) freedom from bias of mind

fields.couplet: A trader's trade prospers fairly  When his dealings are neighbourly
fields.meaning: The true merchandize of merchants is to guard and do by the things of others as they do by their own

fields.couplet: Self-rule leads to realms of gods  Indulgence leads to gloomy hades
fields.meaning: Self-control will place (a man) among the Gods; the want of it will drive (him) into the thickest darkness (of hell)

fields.couplet: No gains with self-control measure  Guard with care this great treasure
fields.meaning: Let self-control be guarded as a treasure; there is no greater source of good for man than that

fields.couplet: Knowing wisdom who lives controlled  Name and fame seek him untold
fields.meaning: Knowing that self-control is knowledge, if a man should control himself, in the prescribed course, such self-control will bring him distinction among the wise

fields.couplet: Firmly fixed in self serene  The sage looks grander than mountain
fields.meaning: More lofty than a mountain will be the greatness of that man who without swerving from his domestic state, controls himself

fields.couplet: Humility is good for all  To the rich it adds a wealth special
fields.meaning: Humility is good in all; but especially in the rich it is (the excellence of) higher riches

fields.couplet: Who senses five like tortoise hold  Their joy prolongs to births sevenfold
fields.meaning: Should one throughout a single birth, like a tortoise keep in his five senses, the fruit of it will prove a safe-guard to him throughout the seven-fold births.

fields.couplet: Rein the tongue if nothing else  Or slips of tongue bring all the woes
fields.meaning: Whatever besides you leave unguarded, guard your tongue; otherwise errors of speech and the consequent misery will ensue

fields.couplet: Even a single evil word  Will turn all good results to bad
fields.meaning: If a man's speech be productive of a single evil, all the good by him will be turned into evil

fields.couplet: The fire-burnt wounds do find a cure  Tongue-burnt wound rests a running sore
fields.meaning: The wound which has been burnt in by fire may heal, but a wound burnt in by the tongue will never heal

fields.couplet: Virtue seeks and peeps to see  Self-controlled savant anger free
fields.meaning: Virtue, seeking for an opportunity, will come into the path of that man who, possessed of learning and self-control, guards himself against anger

fields.couplet: Decorum does one dignity  More than life guard its purity
fields.meaning: Propriety of conduct leads to eminence, it should therefore be preserved more carefully than life

fields.couplet: Virtues of conduct all excel;  The soul aid should be guarded well
fields.meaning: Let propriety of conduct be laboriously preserved and guarded; though one know and practise and excel in many virtues, that will be an eminent aid

fields.couplet: Good conduct shows good family  Low manners mark anomaly
fields.meaning: Propriety of conduct is true greatness of birth, and impropriety will sink into a mean birth

fields.couplet: Readers recall forgotten lore,  But conduct lost returns no more
fields.meaning: A Brahman though he should forget the Vedas may recover it by reading; but, if he fail in propriety of conduct even his high birth will be destroyed

fields.couplet: The envious prosper but ill  The ill-behaved sinks lower still
fields.meaning: Just as the envious man will be without wealth, so will the man of destitute of propriety of conduct be without greatness

fields.couplet: The firm from virtue falter not  They know the ills of evil thought
fields.meaning: Those firm in mind will not slacken in their observance of the proprieties of life, knowing, as they do, the misery that flows from the transgression from them

fields.couplet: Conduct good ennobles man,  Bad conduct entails disgrace mean
fields.meaning: From propriety of conduct men obtain greatness; from impropriety comes insufferable disgrace

fields.couplet: Good conduct sows seeds of blessings  Bad conduct endless evil brings
fields.meaning: Propriety of conduct is the seed of virtue; impropriety will ever cause sorrow

fields.couplet: Foul words will never fall from lips  Of righteous men even by slips
fields.meaning: Those who study propriety of conduct will not speak evil, even forgetfully

fields.couplet: Though read much they are ignorant  Whose life is not world-accordant
fields.meaning: Those who know not how to act agreeably to the world, though they have learnt many things, are still ignorant

fields.couplet: Who know the wealth and virtue's way  After other's wife do not stray
fields.meaning: The folly of desiring her who is the property of another will not be found in those who know (the attributes of) virtue and (the rights of) property

fields.couplet: He is the worst law breaking boor  Who haunts around his neighbour's door
fields.meaning: Among all those who stand on the outside of virtue, there are no greater fools than those who stand outside their neighbour's door

fields.couplet: The vile are dead who evil aim  And put faithful friends' wives to shame
fields.meaning: Certainly they are no better than dead men who desire evil towards the wife of those who

fields.couplet: Their boasted greatness means nothing  When to another's wife they cling
fields.meaning: However great one may be, what does it avail if, without at all considering his guilt, he goes unto the wife of another ?

fields.couplet: Who trifles with another's wife  His guilty stain will last for life
fields.meaning: He who thinks lightly of going into the wife of another acquires guilt that will abide with him imperishably and for ever

fields.couplet: Hatred, sin, fear, and shame-these four  Stain adulterers ever more
fields.meaning: Hatred, sin, fear, disgrace; these four will never leave him who goes in to his neighbour's wife

fields.couplet: He is the righteous householder  His neighbour's wife who covets never
fields.meaning: He who desires not the womanhood of her who should walk according to the will of another will be praised as a virtuous house-holder

fields.couplet: They lead a high-souled manly life  The pure who eye not another's wife
fields.meaning: That noble manliness which looks not at the wife of another is the virtue and dignity of the great

fields.couplet: Good in storm bound earth is with those  Who clasp not arms of another's spouse
fields.meaning: Is it asked, "who are those who shall obtain good in this world surrounded by the terror-producing sea ?" Those who touch not the shoulder of her who belongs to another

fields.couplet: Sinners breaking virtue's behest  Lust not for another's wife at least
fields.meaning: Though a man perform no virtuous deeds and commit (every) vice, it will be well if he desire not the womanhood of her who is within the limit (of the house) of another

fields.couplet: As earth bears up with diggers too  To bear revilers is prime virtue
fields.meaning: To bear with those who revile us, just as the earth bears up those who dig it, is the first of virtues

fields.couplet: Forgive insults is a good habit  Better it is to forget it
fields.meaning: Bear with reproach even when you can retaliate; but to forget it will be still better than that

fields.couplet: Neglect the guest is dearth of dearth  To bear with fools is strength of strength
fields.meaning: To neglect hospitality is poverty of poverty To bear with the ignorant is might of might

fields.couplet: Practice of patient quality  Retains intact itegrity
fields.meaning: If you desire that greatness should never leave, you preserve in your conduct the exercise of patience

fields.couplet: Vengeance is not in esteem held  Patience is praised as hidden gold
fields.meaning: (The wise) will not at all esteem the resentful They will esteem the patient just as the gold which they lay up with care

fields.couplet: Revenge accords but one day's joy  Patience carries its praise for aye
fields.meaning: The pleasure of the resentful continues for a day The praise of the patient will continue until (the final destruction of) the world

fields.couplet: Though others cause you wanton pain  Grieve not; from unjust harm refrain
fields.meaning: Though others inflict injuries on you, yet compassionating the evil (that will come upon them) it will be well not to do them anything contrary to virtue

fields.couplet: By noble forbearance vanquish  The proud that have caused you anguish
fields.meaning: Let a man by patience overcome those who through pride commit excesses

fields.couplet: More than ascetics they are pure  Who bitter tongues meekly endure
fields.meaning: Those who bear with the uncourteous speech of the insolent are as pure as the ascetics

fields.couplet: Who fast are great to do penance  Greater are they who bear offence
fields.meaning: Those who endure abstinence from food are great, next to those who endure the uncourteous speech of others

fields.couplet: Deem your heart as virtuous  When your nature is not jealous
fields.meaning: Let a man esteem that disposition which is free from envy in the same manner as propriety of conduct

fields.couplet: No excellence excels the one  That by nature envies none
fields.meaning: Amongst all attainable excellences there is none equal to that of being free from envy towords others

fields.couplet: Who envies others' good fortune  Can't prosper in virtue of his own
fields.meaning: Of him who instead of rejoicing in the wealth of others, envies it, it will be said "he neither desires virtue not wealth."

fields.couplet: The wise through envy don't others wrong  Knowing that woes from evils throng
fields.meaning: (The wise) knowing the misery that comes from transgression will not through envy commit unrighteous deeds

fields.couplet: Man shall be wrecked by envy's whim  Even if enemies spare him
fields.meaning: To those who cherish envy that is enough Though free from enemies that (envy) will bring destruction

fields.couplet: Who envies gifts shall suffer ruin  Without food and clothes with his kin
fields.meaning: He who is envious at a gift (made to another) will with his relations utterly perish destitute of food and rainment

fields.couplet: Fortune deserts the envious  Leaving misfortune omnious
fields.meaning: Lakshmi envying (the prosperity) of the envious man will depart and introduce him to her sister

fields.couplet: Caitiff envy despoils wealth  And drags one into evil path
fields.meaning: Envy will destroy (a man's) wealth (in his world) and drive him into the pit of fire (in the world to come.)

fields.couplet: Why is envy rich, goodmen poor  People with surprise think over
fields.meaning: The wealth of a man of envious mind and the poverty of the righteous will be pondered

fields.couplet: The envious prosper never  The envyless prosper ever
fields.meaning: Never have the envious become great; never have those who are free from envy been without greatness

fields.couplet: Who covets others' honest wealth  That greed ruins his house forthwith
fields.meaning: If a man departing from equity covet the property (of others), at that very time will his family be destroyed and guilt be incurred

fields.couplet: Who shrink with shame from sin, refrain  From coveting which brings ruin
fields.meaning: Those who blush at the want of equity will not commit disgraceful acts through desire of the profit that may be gained

fields.couplet: For spiritual bliss who long  For fleeting joy commit no wrong
fields.meaning: Those who desire the higher pleasures (of heaven) will not act unjustly through desire of the trifling joy. (in this life.)

fields.couplet: The truth-knowers of sense-control  Though in want covet not at all
fields.meaning: The wise who have conquered their senses and are free from crime, will not covet (the things of others), with the thought "we are destitute."

fields.couplet: What is one's subtle wisdom worth  If it deals ill with all on earth
fields.meaning: What is the advantage of extensive and accurate knowledge if a man through covetousness act senselessly towards all ?

fields.couplet: Who seeks for grace on righteous path  Suffers by evil covetous wealth
fields.meaning: If he, who through desire of the virtue of kindness abides in the domestic state ie, the path in which it may be obtained, covet (the property of others) and think of evil methods (to obtain it), he will perish

fields.couplet: Shun the fruit of covetousness  All its yield is inglorious
fields.meaning: Desire not the gain of covetousness In the enjoyment of its fruits there is no glory

fields.couplet: The mark of lasting wealth is shown  By not coveting others' own
fields.meaning: If it is weighed, "what is the indestructibility of wealth," it is freedom from covetousness

fields.couplet: Fortune seeks the just and wise  Who are free from coveting vice
fields.meaning: Lakshmi, knowing the manner (in which she may approach) will immediately come to those wise men who, knowing that it is virtue, covet not the property of others

fields.couplet: Desireless, greatness conquers all;  Coveting misers ruined fall
fields.meaning: To covet (the wealth of another) regardless of consequences will bring destruction That greatness (of mind) which covets not will give victory

fields.couplet: Though a man from virtue strays,  To keep from slander brings him praise
fields.meaning: Though one do not even speak of virtue and live in sin, it will be well if it be said of him "he does not backbite."

fields.couplet: Who bite behind, and before smile  Are worse than open traitors vile
fields.meaning: To smile deceitfully (in another's presence) after having reviled him to his destruction (behind his back) is a greater evil than the commission of (every other) sin and the destruction of (every) virtue

fields.couplet: Virtue thinks it better to die,  Than live to backbite and to lie
fields.meaning: Death rather than life will confer upon the deceitful backbiter the profit which (the treatises on) virtue point out

fields.couplet: Though harsh you speak in one's presence  Abuse is worse in his absence
fields.meaning: Though you speak without kindness before another's face speak not in his absence words which regard not the evil subsequently resulting from it

fields.couplet: Who turns to slander makes it plain  His praise of virtue is in vain
fields.meaning: The emptiness of that man's mind who (merely) praises virtue will be seen from the meanness of reviling another behind his back

fields.couplet: His failings will be found and shown,  Who makes another's failings known
fields.meaning: The character of the faults of that man who publishes abroad the faults of others will be sought out and published

fields.couplet: By pleasing words who make not friends  Sever their hearts by hostile trends
fields.meaning: Those who know not to live in friendship with amusing conversation will by back-biting estrange even their relatives

fields.couplet: What will they not to strangers do  Who bring their friends' defects to view?
fields.meaning: What will those not do to strangers whose nature leads them to publish abroad the faults of their intimate friends ?

fields.couplet: The world in mercy bears his load  Who rants behind words untoward
fields.meaning: The world through charity supports the weight of those who reproach others observing their absence

fields.couplet: No harm would fall to any man  If each his own defect could scan
fields.meaning: If they observed their own faults as they observe the faults of others, would any evil happen to men ?

fields.couplet: With silly words who insults all  Is held in contempt as banal
fields.meaning: He who to the disgust of many speaks useless things will be despised by all

fields.couplet: Vain talk before many is worse  Than doing to friends deeds adverse
fields.meaning: To speak useless things in the presence of many is a greater evil than to do unkind things towards friends

fields.couplet: The babbler's hasty lips proclaim  That \"good-for-nothing\" is his name
fields.meaning: That conversation in which a man utters forth useless things will say of him "he is without virtue."

fields.couplet: Vain words before an assembly  Will make all gains and goodness flee
fields.meaning: The words devoid of profit or pleasure which a man speaks will, being inconsistent with virtue,

fields.couplet: Glory and grace will go away  When savants silly nonsense say
fields.meaning: If the good speak vain words their eminence and excellence will leave them

fields.couplet: Call him a human chaff who prides  Himself in weightless idle words
fields.meaning: Call not him a man who parades forth his empty words Call him the chaff of men

fields.couplet: Let not men of worth vainly quack  Even if they would roughly speak
fields.meaning: Let the wise if they will, speak things without excellence; it will be well for them not to speak useless things

fields.couplet: The wise who weigh the worth refrain  From words that have no grain and brain
fields.meaning: The wise who seek after rare pleasures will not speak words that have not much weight in them

fields.couplet: The wise of spotless self-vision  Slip not to silly words-mention
fields.meaning: Those wise men who are without faults and are freed from ignorance will not even forgetfully speak things that profit not

fields.couplet: To purpose speak the fruitful word  And never indulge in useless load
fields.meaning: Speak what is useful, and speak not useless words

fields.couplet: Sinners fear not the pride of sin  The worthy dread the ill within
fields.meaning: Those who have experience of evil deeds will not fear, but the excellent will fear the pride of sin

fields.couplet: Since evil begets evil dire  Fear ye evil more than fire
fields.meaning: Because evil produces evil, therefore should evil be feared more than fire

fields.couplet: The wisest of the wise are those  Who injure not even their foes
fields.meaning: So shalt thou wisdom's highest law, 'tis said, fulfil

fields.couplet: His ruin virtue plots who plans  The ruin of another man's
fields.meaning: Even though forgetfulness meditate not the ruin of another Virtue will meditate the ruin of him who thus meditates

fields.couplet: Who makes poverty plea for ill  Shall reduce himself poorer still
fields.meaning: Commit not evil, saying, "I am poor": if you do, you will become poorer still

fields.couplet: From wounding others let him refrain  Who would from harm himself remain
fields.meaning: Let him not do evil to others who desires not that sorrows should pursue him

fields.couplet: Men may escape other foes and live  But sin its deadly blow will give
fields.meaning: However great be the enmity men have incurred they may still live The enmity of sin will incessantly pursue and kill

fields.couplet: Ruin follows who evil do  As shadow follows as they go
fields.meaning: Destruction will dwell at the heels of those who commit evil even as their shadow that leaves them not

fields.couplet: Let none who loves himself at all  Think of evil however small
fields.meaning: If a man love himself, let him not commit any sin however small

fields.couplet: He is secure, know ye, from ills  Who slips not right path to do evils
fields.meaning: Know ye that he is freed from destruction who commits no evil, going to neither side of the right path

fields.couplet: Duty demands nothing in turn;  How can the world recompense rain?
fields.meaning: Benevolence seeks not a return. What does the world give back to the clouds ?

fields.couplet: All the wealth that toils give  Is meant to serve those who deserve
fields.meaning: All the wealth acquired with perseverance by the worthy is for the exercise of benevolence

fields.couplet: In heav'n and earth 'tis hard to find  A greater good than being kind
fields.meaning: It is difficult to obtain another good equal to benevolence either in this world or in that of the gods

fields.couplet: He lives who knows befitting act  Others are deemed as dead in fact
fields.meaning: He truly lives who knows (and discharges) the proper duties (of benevolence) He who knows them not will be reckoned among the dead

fields.couplet: The wealth that wise and kind do make  Is like water that fills a lake
fields.meaning: The wealth of that man of eminent knowledge who desires to exercise the benevolence approved of by the world, is like the full waters of a city-tank

fields.couplet: Who plenty gets and plenty gives  Is like town-tree teeming with fruits
fields.meaning: The wealth of a man (possessed of the virtue) of benevolence is like the ripening of a fruitful tree in the midst of a town

fields.couplet: The wealth of a wide-hearted soul  Is a herbal tree that healeth all
fields.meaning: If wealth be in the possession of a man who has the great excellence (of benevolence), it is like a tree which as a medicine is an infallible cure for disease

fields.couplet: Though seers may fall on evil days  Their sense of duty never strays
fields.meaning: The wise who know what is duty will not scant their benevolence even when they are without wealth

fields.couplet: The good man's poverty and grief  Is want of means to give relief
fields.meaning: The poverty of a benevolent man, is nothing but his inability to exercise the same

fields.couplet: By good if ruin comes across  Sell yourself to save that loss
fields.meaning: If it be said that loss will result from benevolence, such loss is worth being procured even by the sale of one's self

fields.couplet: To give the poor is charity  The rest is loan and vanity
fields.meaning: To give to the destitute is true charity All other gifts have the nature of (what is done for) a measured return

fields.couplet: To beg is bad e'en from the good  To give is good, were heaven forbid
fields.meaning: To beg is evil, even though it were said that it is a good path (to heaven) To give is good, even though it were said that those who do so cannot obtain heaven

fields.couplet: No pleading, \"I am nothing worth,\"  But giving marks a noble birth
fields.meaning: (Even in a low state) not to adopt the mean expedient of saying "I have nothing," but to give, is the characteristic of the mad of noble birth

fields.couplet: The cry for alms is painful sight  Until the giver sees him bright
fields.meaning: To see men begging from us in disagreeable, until we see their pleasant countenance

fields.couplet: Higher's power which hunger cures  Than that of penance which endures
fields.meaning: The power of those who perform penance is the power of enduring hunger It is inferior to the power of those who remove the hunger (of others)

fields.couplet: Drive from the poor their gnawing pains  If room you seek to store your gains
fields.meaning: The removal of the killing hunger of the poor is the place for one to lay up his wealth

fields.couplet: Who shares his food with those who need  Hunger shall not harm his creed
fields.meaning: The fiery disease of hunger shall never touch him who habitually distributes his food to others

fields.couplet: The joy of give and take they lose  Hard-hearted rich whose hoarding fails
fields.meaning: Do the hard-eyed who lay up and lose their possessions not know the happiness which springs from the pleasure of giving ?

fields.couplet: Worse than begging is that boarding  Alone what one's greed is hoarding
fields.meaning: Solitary and unshared eating for the sake of filling up one's own riches is certainly much more

fields.couplet: Nothing is more painful than death  Yet more is pain of giftless dearth
fields.meaning: Nothing is more unpleasant than death: yet even that is pleasant where charity cannot be exercised

fields.couplet: They gather fame who freely give  The greatest gain for all that live
fields.meaning: Give to the poor and live with praise There is no greater profit to man than that

fields.couplet: The glory of the alms-giver  Is praised aloud as popular
fields.meaning: Whatsoever is spoken in the world will abide as praise upon that man who gives alms to the poor

fields.couplet: Nothing else lasts on earth for e'er  Saving high fame of the giver!
fields.meaning: There is nothing that stands forth in the world imperishable, except fame, exalted in solitary greatness

fields.couplet: From hailing gods heavens will cease  To hail the men of lasting praise
fields.meaning: If one has acquired extensive fame within the limits of this earth, the world of the Gods will no longer praise those sages who have attained that world

fields.couplet: Fame in fall and life in death  Are rare but for the soulful worth
fields.meaning: Prosperity to the body of fame, resulting in poverty to the body of flesh and the stability to the former arising from the death of the latter, are achievable only by the wise

fields.couplet: Be born with fame if birth you want  If not of birth you must not vaunt
fields.meaning: If you are born (in this world), be born with qualities conductive to fame From those who are destitute of them it will be better not to be born

fields.couplet: Why grieve at those who blame the shame  Of those who cannot live in fame?
fields.meaning: Why do those who cannot live with praise, grieve those who despise them, instead of grieving themselves for their own inability

fields.couplet: To men on earth it is a shame  Not to beget the child of fame
fields.meaning: Not to beget fame will be esteemed a disgrace by the wise in this world

fields.couplet: The land will shrink in yield if men  O'erburden it without renown
fields.meaning: The ground which supports a body without fame will diminish in its rich produce

fields.couplet: They live who live without blemish  The blameful ones do not flurish
fields.meaning: Those live who live without disgrace Those who live without fame live not

fields.couplet: The wealth of wealth is wealth of grace  Earthly wealth e'en the basest has
fields.meaning: The wealth of kindness is wealth of wealth, in as much as the wealth of property is possessed by the basest of men

fields.couplet: Seek by sound ways good compassion;  All faiths mark that for-salvation
fields.meaning: (Stand) in the good path, consider, and be kind. Even considering according to the conflicting tenets of the different sects, kindness will be your best aid, (in the acquisition of heavenly bliss.)

fields.couplet: The hearts of mercy shall not go  Into dark worlds of gruesome woe
fields.meaning: They will never enter the world of darkness and wretchedness whose minds are the abode of kindness

fields.couplet: His soul is free from dread of sins  Whose mercy serveth all beings
fields.meaning: (The wise) say that the evils, which his soul would dread, will never come upon the man who exercises kindness and protects the life (of other creatures)

fields.couplet: The wide wind-fed world witness bears:  Men of mercy meet not sorrows
fields.meaning: This great rich earth over which the wind blows, is a witness that sorrow never comes upon the kindhearted

fields.couplet: Who grace forsake and graceless act  The former loss and woes forget
fields.meaning: (The wise) say that those who neglect kindness and practise cruelties, neglected virtue (in their former birth), and forgot (the sorrows which they must suffer.)

fields.couplet: This world is not for weathless ones  That world is not for graceless swines
fields.meaning: As this world is not for those who are without wealth, so that world is not for those who are without kindness

fields.couplet: The wealthless may prosper one day;  The graceless never bloom agay
fields.meaning: Those who are without wealth may, at some future time, become prosperous; those who are destitute of kindness are utterly destitute; for them there is no change

fields.couplet: Like Truth twisted by confused mind  Wisdom is vain in hearts unkind
fields.meaning: If you consider, the virtue of him who is without kindness is like the perception of the true being by him who is without wisdom

fields.couplet: Think how you feel before the strong  When to the feeble you do wrong
fields.meaning: When a man is about to rush upon those who are weaker than himself, let him remember how he has stood (trembling) before those who are stronger than himself

fields.couplet: What graciousness can one command  who feeds his flesh by flesh gourmand
fields.meaning: How can he be possessed of kindness, who to increase his own flesh, eats the flesh of other creatures

fields.couplet: The thriftless have no property  And flesh-eaters have no pity
fields.meaning: As those possess no property who do not take care of it, so those possess no kindness who feed on flesh

fields.couplet: Who wields a steel is steel-hearted  Who tastes body is hard-hearted
fields.meaning: Like the (murderous) mind of him who carries a weapon (in his hand), the mind of him who feasts with pleasure on the body of another (creature), has no regard for goodness

fields.couplet: If merciless it is to kill,  To kill and eat is disgraceful
fields.meaning: If it be asked what is kindness and what its opposite, the answer would be preservation and destruction of life; and therefore it is not right to feed on the flesh (obtained by taking away life)

fields.couplet: Off with flesh; a life you save  The eater hell's mouth shall not waive!
fields.meaning: Not to eat flesh contributes to the continuance of life; therefore if a man eat flesh, hell will not open its mouth (to let him escape out, after he has once fallen in)

fields.couplet: None would kill and sell the flesh  For eating it if they don't wish
fields.meaning: If the world does not destroy life for the purpose of eating, then no one would sell flesh for the sake of money

fields.couplet: From eating flesh men must abstain  If they but feel the being's pain
fields.meaning: If men should come to know that flesh is nothing but the unclean ulcer of a body, let them abstain from eating it

fields.couplet: Whose mind from illusion is freed  Refuse on lifeless flesh to feed
fields.meaning: The wise, who have freed themselves from mental delusion, will not eat the flesh which has been severed from an animal

fields.couplet: Not to-kill-and-eat, truly  Excels thousand pourings of ghee!
fields.meaning: Not to kill and eat (the flesh of) an animal, is better than the pouring forth of ghee etc, in a thousand sacrifices

fields.couplet: All lives shall lift their palms to him  Who eats not flesh nor kills with whim
fields.meaning: All creatures will join their hands together, and worship him who has never taken away life, nor eaten flesh

fields.couplet: Pains endure; pain not beings  This is the type of true penance
fields.meaning: The nature of religious discipline consists, in the endurance (by the ascetic) of the sufferings which it brings on himself, and in abstaining from giving pain to others

fields.couplet: Penance is fit for penitents  Not for him who in vain pretends
fields.meaning: Austerities can only be borne, and their benefits enjoyed, by those who have practised them (in a former birth); it will be useless for those who have not done so, to attempt to practise them (now)

fields.couplet: Is it to true penitent's aid,  That others austere path avoid?
fields.meaning: It is to provide food etc, for the ascetics who have abandoned (the desire of earthly possessions) that other persons have forgotten (to practise) austerity ?

fields.couplet: In penance lies the power to save  The friends and foil the foe and knave
fields.meaning: If (the ascetic) desire the destruction of his enemies, or the aggrandizement of his friends, it will be effected by (the power of) his austerities

fields.couplet: What they wish as they wish is won  Here hence by men penance is done
fields.meaning: Religious dislipline is practised in this world, because it secures the attainment of whatever one may wish to enjoy (in the world to come)

fields.couplet: Who do penance achieve their aim  Others desire-rid themselves harm
fields.meaning: Those discharge their duty who perform austerities; all others accomplish their own destruction, through the entanglement of the desire (of riches and sensual pleasure)

fields.couplet: Pure and bright gets the gold in fire;  and so the life by pain austere
fields.meaning: Just as gold is purified as heated in the fire, will those shine, who have endured the burning of pain (in frequent austerities)

fields.couplet: He worship wins from every soul  Who Master is by soul control
fields.meaning: All other creatures will worship him who has attained the control of his own soul

fields.couplet: They can even defy death  Who get by penance godly strenth
fields.meaning: Those who have attained the power which religious discipline confers, will be able also to pass the limit of Yama, (the God of death)

fields.couplet: Many are poor and few are rich  For they care not for penance much
fields.meaning: Because there are few who practise austerity and many who do not, there are many destitute and few rich in this world

fields.couplet: Elements five of feigned life  Of a sly hypocrite within laugh
fields.meaning: The five elements (of his body) will laugh within him at the feigned conduct of the deceitful minded man

fields.couplet: Of what avail are sky-high shows  When guild the conscience gnaws and knows
fields.meaning: What avails an appearance (of sanctity) high as heaven, if his mind suffers (the indulgence) of conscious sin

fields.couplet: Vaunting sainthood while week within  Seems a grazer with tiger skin
fields.meaning: The assumed appearance of power, by a man who has no power (to restrain his senses and perform austerity), is like a cow feeding on grass covered with a tiger's skin

fields.couplet: Sinning in saintly show is like  Fowlers in ambush birds to strike
fields.meaning: He who hides himself under the mask of an ascetic and commits sins, like a sportsman who conceals himself in the thicket to catch birds

fields.couplet: Who false within but freedom feign  Shall moan \"What have we done\" with pain
fields.meaning: The false conduct of those who say they have renounced all desire will one day bring them sorrows that will make them cry out, "Oh! what have we done, what have we done."

fields.couplet: Vilest is he who seems a saint  Cheating the world without restraint
fields.meaning: Amongst living men there are none so hard-hearted as those who without to saking (desire) in their heart, falsely take the appearance of those who have forsaken (it)

fields.couplet: Berry-red is his outward view,  Black like its nose his inward hue
fields.meaning: (The world) contains persons whose outside appears (as fair) as the (red) berry of the Abrus, but whose inside is as black as the nose of that berry

fields.couplet: Filthy in mind some bathe in streams  Hiding sins in showy extremes
fields.meaning: There are many men of masked conduct, who perform their ablutions, and (make a show) of

fields.couplet: Know men by acts and not by forms  Strait arrow kills, bent lute but charms
fields.meaning: As, in its use, the arrow is crooked, and the curved lute is straight, so by their deeds, (and not by their appearance) let (the uprightness or crookedness of) men be estimated

fields.couplet: No balding nor tangling the hair!  Abstain from condemned acts with care
fields.meaning: There is no need of a shaven crown, nor of tangled hair, if a man abstain from those deeds which the wise have condemned

fields.couplet: Let him who would reproachless be  From all frauds guard his conscience free
fields.meaning: Let him, who desires not to be despised, keep his mind from (the desire of) defrauding another of the smallest thing

fields.couplet: \"We will by fraud win other's wealth\"  Even this thought is sin and stealth
fields.meaning: Even the thought (of sin) is sin; think not then of crafiily stealing the property of another

fields.couplet: The gain by fraud may overflow  But swift to ruin it shall go
fields.meaning: The property, which is acquired by fraud, will entirely perish, even while it seems to increase

fields.couplet: The fruit that fraud and greed obtain  Shall end in endless grief and pain
fields.meaning: The eager desire of defrauding others will, when it brings forth its fruit, produce undying sorrow

fields.couplet: Love and Grace are not their worth  Who watch to waylay dozer's wealth
fields.meaning: The study of kindness and the exercise of benevolence is not with those who watch for another's forgetfulness, though desire of his property

fields.couplet: They cannot walk in measured bounds  who crave and have covetous ends
fields.meaning: They cannot walk steadfastly, according to rule, who eagerly desire to defraud others

fields.couplet: Men of measured wisdom shun  Black art of fraud and what it won
fields.meaning: That black-knowledge which is called fraud, is not in those who desire that greatness which is called rectitude

fields.couplet: Virtue abides in righteous hearts  Into minds of frauds deceit darts
fields.meaning: Deceit dwells in the mind of those who are conversant with fraud, even as virtue in the minds of those who are conversant with rectitude

fields.couplet: They perish in their perfidy  Who know nothing but pilfery
fields.meaning: Those, who are acquainted with nothing but fraud, will perish in the very commission of transgression

fields.couplet: Even the body rejects thieves;  The honest men, heaven receives
fields.meaning: Even their body will fail the fraudulent; but even the world of the gods will not fail those who are free from fraud

fields.couplet: If \"What is truth\"? the question be,  It is to speak out evil-free
fields.meaning: Truth is the speaking of such words as are free from the least degree of evil (to others)

fields.couplet: E'en falsehood may for truth suffice,  When good it brings removing vice
fields.meaning: Even falsehood has the nature of truth, if it confer a benefit that is free from fault

fields.couplet: Let not a man knowingly lie;  Conscience will scorch and make him sigh
fields.meaning: Let not a man knowingly tell a lie; for after he has told the lie, his mind will burn him (with the memory of his guilt)

fields.couplet: He lives in loving hearts of all  Who serves the Truth serene in soul
fields.meaning: He who, in his conduct, preserves a mind free from deceit, will dwell in the minds of all men

fields.couplet: To speak the truth from heart sincere  Is more than giving and living austere
fields.meaning: He, who speaks truth with all his heart, is superior to those who make gifts and practise austerities

fields.couplet: Not to lie brings all the praise  All virtues from Truth arise
fields.meaning: There is no praise like the praise of never uttering a falsehood: without causing any suffering, it will lead to every virtue

fields.couplet: Lie not lie not Naught else you need  All virtues are in Truth indeed
fields.meaning: If a man has the power to abstain from falsehood, it will be well with him, even though he practise no other virtue

fields.couplet: Water makes you pure outward  Truth renders you pure inward
fields.meaning: Purity of body is produced by water and purity of mind by truthfulness

fields.couplet: All lights are not lights for the wise;  Truth light is light bright like Sun-light
fields.meaning: All lamps of nature are not lamps; the lamp of truth is the lamp of the wise

fields.couplet: Of all the things we here have seen  Nothing surpasses Truth serene!
fields.meaning: Amidst all that we have seen (described) as real (excellence), there is nothing so good as truthfulness

fields.couplet: Anger against the weak is wrong  It is futile against the strong
fields.meaning: He restrains his anger who restrains it when it can injure; when it cannot injure, what does it matter whether he restrain it, or not ?

fields.couplet: Vain is wrath against men of force  Against the meek it is still worse
fields.meaning: Anger is bad, even when it cannot injure; when it can injure; there is no greater evil

fields.couplet: Off with wrath with any one  It is the source of sin and pain
fields.meaning: Forget anger towards every one, as fountains of evil spring from it

fields.couplet: Is there a foe like harmful ire  Which kills the smile and joyful cheer?
fields.meaning: What other foe to man works such annoy?

fields.couplet: Thyself to save, from wrath away!  If not thyself the wrath will slay
fields.meaning: If a man would guard himself, let him guard against anger; if he do not guard it, anger will kill him

fields.couplet: Friend-killer is the fatal rage  It burns the helpful kinship-barge
fields.meaning: The fire of anger will burn up even the pleasant raft of friendship

fields.couplet: The wrath-lover to doom is bound  Like failless-hand that strikes the ground
fields.meaning: Destruction will come upon him who ragards anger as a good thing, as surely as the hand of him who strikes the ground will not fail

fields.couplet: Save thy soul from burning ire  Though tortured like the touch of fire
fields.meaning: Though one commit things against you as painful (to bear) as if a bundle of fire had been thrust upon you, it will be well, to refrain, if possible, from anger

fields.couplet: Wishes he gains as he wishes  If man refrains from rage vicious!
fields.meaning: If a man never indulges anger in his heart, he will at once obtain whatever he has thought of

fields.couplet: Dead are they who are anger-fed  Saints are they from whom wrath has fled
fields.meaning: Those, who give way to excessive anger, are no better than dead men; but those, who are freed from it, are equal to those who are freed (from death)

fields.couplet: The pure by faith mean pain to none  Though princely wealth by that is won
fields.meaning: It is the determination of the spotless not to cause sorrow to others, although they could (by so causing) obtain the wealth which confers greatness

fields.couplet: The spotless hearts seek not revenge  Though Malice does the worst in rage
fields.meaning: It is the determination of the spotless not to do evil, even in return, to those who have cherished enmity and done them evil

fields.couplet: Revenging even causeless hate  Bad-blood breeds and baneful heat
fields.meaning: In an ascetic inflict suffering even on those who hate him, when he has not done them any evil, it will afterwards give him irretrievable sorrow

fields.couplet: Doing good-turns, put them to shame  Thus chide the evil who do harm
fields.meaning: The (proper) punishment to those who have done evil (to you), is to put them to shame by showing them kindness, in return and to forget both the evil and the good done on both sides

fields.couplet: What does a man from wisdom gain  If he pines not at other's pain?
fields.meaning: What benefit has he derived from his knowledge, who does not endeavour to keep off pain from another as much as from himself ?

fields.couplet: What you feel as pain to yourself  Do it not to the other-self
fields.meaning: Let not a man consent to do those things to another which, he knows, will cause sorrow

fields.couplet: Any, anywhere injure not  At any time even in thought
fields.meaning: It is the chief of all virtues not knowingly to do any person evil, even in the lowest degree, and at any time

fields.couplet: How can he injure other souls  Who in his life injury feels
fields.meaning: Why does a man inflict upon other creatures those sufferings, which he has found by experience are sufferings to himself ?

fields.couplet: Harm others in the forenoon  Harm seeks thee in afternoon
fields.meaning: If a man inflict sorrow upon others in the morning, it will come upon him unsought in the very evening

fields.couplet: No harm is done by peace-lovers  For pains rebound on pain-givers
fields.meaning: Sorrow will come upon those who cause pain to others; therfore those, who desire to be free from sorrow, give no pain to others

fields.couplet: What is Virtue? 'Tis not to kill  For killing causes every ill
fields.meaning: Never to destroy life is the sum of all virtuous conduct The destruction of life leads to every evil

fields.couplet: Share the food and serve all lives  This is the law of all the laws
fields.meaning: The chief of all (the virtues) which authors have summed up, is the partaking of food that has been shared with others, and the preservation of the mainfold life of other creatures

fields.couplet: Not to kill is unique good  The next, not to utter falsehood
fields.meaning: Not to destroy life is an incomparably (great) good next to it in goodness ranks freedom from falsehood

fields.couplet: What way is good? That we can say  The way away from heat to slay
fields.meaning: Good path is that which considers how it may avoid killing any creature

fields.couplet: Of saints who renounce birth-fearing  The head is he who dreads killing
fields.meaning: Of all those who, fearing the permanence of earthly births, have abandoned desire, he is the chief who, fearing (the guilt of) murder, considers how he may avoid the destruction of life

fields.couplet: Life-eating-Death shall spare the breath  Of him who no life puts to death
fields.meaning: Yama, the destroyer of life, will not attack the life of him, who acts under the determination of never destroying life

fields.couplet: Kill not life that others cherish  Even when your life must perish
fields.meaning: Let no one do that which would destroy the life of another, although he should by so doing, lose his own life

fields.couplet: The gain of slaughter is a vice  Though deemed good in sacrifice
fields.meaning: The advantage which might flow from destroying life in sacrifice, is dishonourable to the wise (who renounced the world), even although it should be said to be productive of great good

fields.couplet: Those who live by slaying are  Eaters of carrion bizarre!
fields.meaning: To minds of them who what is vileness know

fields.couplet: The loathsome poor sickly and sore  Are killers stained by blood before
fields.meaning: (The wise) will say that men of diseased bodies, who live in degradation and in poverty, are those who separated the life from the body of animals (in a former birth)

fields.couplet: The worst of follies it is told  The fleeting as lasting to hold
fields.meaning: That ignorance which considers those things to be stable which are not so, is dishonourable (to the wise)

fields.couplet: Like a drama-crowd wealth gathers  Like passing show its pride too goes
fields.meaning: The acquisition of wealth is like the gathering together of an assembly for a theatre; its expenditure is like the breaking up of that assembly

fields.couplet: Wealth wanes away; but when it comes  Take care to do enduring things
fields.meaning: Wealth is perishable; let those who obtain it immediately practise those (virtues) which are imperishable

fields.couplet: The showy day is but a saw  Your life, know that, to file and gnaw
fields.meaning: Time, which shows itself (to the ignorant) as if it were something (real) is in the estimation of the wise (only) a saw which cuts down life

fields.couplet: Ere tongue benumbs and hiccough comes  Rise up to do good deeds betimes
fields.meaning: Let virtuous deeds be done quickly, before the hiccup comes making the tongue silent

fields.couplet: One was yesterday; not today!
fields.meaning: This world possesses the greatness that one who yesterday was is not today

fields.couplet: Man knows not his next moment  On crores of things he is intent
fields.meaning: Innumerable are the thoughts which occupy the mind of (the unwise), who know not that they shall live another moment

fields.couplet: The soul from body any day  Like bird from egg-shell flies away
fields.meaning: The love of the soul to the body is like (the love of) a bird to its egg which it flies away from and leaves empty

fields.couplet: Death is like a slumber deep  And birth like waking from that sleep
fields.meaning: Death is like sleep; birth is like awaking from it

fields.couplet: The life berthed in this body shows  A fixed home it never knows
fields.meaning: It seems as if the soul, which takes a temporary shelter in a body, had not attained a home

fields.couplet: From what from what a man is free  From that, from that his torments flee
fields.meaning: Whatever thing, a man has renounced, by that thing; he cannot suffer pain

fields.couplet: Give up all to gain the True  And endless joys shall hence seek you
fields.meaning: After a man has renounced (all things), there will still be many things in this world (which he may enjoy); if he should desire them, let him, while it is time abandon (the world)

fields.couplet: Curb the senses five and renounce  The carving desires all at once
fields.meaning: Let the five senses be destroyed; and at the same time, let everything be abandoned that (the ascetic) has (formerly) desired

fields.couplet: To have nothing is law of vows  Having the least deludes and snares
fields.meaning: To be altogether destitute is the proper condition of those who perform austerities; if they possess anything, it will change (their resolution) and bring them back to their confused state

fields.couplet: Why add to bonds while this body  Is too much for saints to be birth-free
fields.meaning: What means the addition of other things those who are attempting to cut off (future) births, when even their body is too much (for them)

fields.couplet: Who curbs the pride of I and mine  Gets a world rare for gods to gain
fields.meaning: Shall enter realms above the powers divine

fields.couplet: Grief clings on and on to those  Who cling to bonds without release
fields.meaning: Sorrows will never let go their hold of those who give not up their hold of desire

fields.couplet: Who renounce all are free from care  Others suffer delusive snare
fields.meaning: Those who have entirely renounced (all things and all desire) have obtained (absorption into God); all others wander in confusion, entangled in the net of (many) births

fields.couplet: Bondage cut off, rebirth is off  The world then seems instable stuff
fields.meaning: At the moment in which desire has been abandoned, (other) births will be cut off; when that has not been done, instability will be seen

fields.couplet: Bind Thyself to the unbound one  That binding breaks all bonds anon
fields.meaning: Desire the desire of Him who is without desire; in order to renounce desire, desire that desire

fields.couplet: That error entails ignoble birth  Which deems vain things as things of worth
fields.meaning: Inglorious births are produced by the confusion (of mind) which considers those things to be real which are not real

fields.couplet: Men of spotless pure insight  Enjoy delight devoid of night
fields.meaning: A clear, undimmed vision of things will deliver its possessors from the darkness of future births, and confer the felicity (of heaven)

fields.couplet: To doubtless minds whose heart is clear  More than earth heaven is near
fields.meaning: Heaven is nearer than earth to those men of purified minds who are freed from from doubt

fields.couplet: Knowledge of five senses is vain  Without knowing the Truth within
fields.meaning: Even those who have all the knowledge which can be attained by the five senses, will derive no benefit from it, if they are without a knowledge of the true nature of things

fields.couplet: Knowledge is truth of things to find  In every case of every kind
fields.meaning: (True) knowledge is the perception concerning every thing of whatever kind, that that thing is the true thing

fields.couplet: Who learn and here the Truth discern  Enter the path of non-return
fields.meaning: They, who in this birth have learned to know the True Being, enter the road which returns not into this world

fields.couplet: One-minded sage sees inner-truth  He is free from thoughts of rebirth
fields.meaning: Let it not be thought that there is another birth for him whose mind having thoroughly considered (all it has been taught) has known the True Being

fields.couplet: It is knowledge to know Self-Truth  And remove the folly of birth
fields.meaning: True knowledge consists in the removal of ignorance; which is (the cause of) births, and the perception of the True Being who is (the bestower of) heaven

fields.couplet: Know the Refuge; off with bondage  Be free from ills of thraldom, O sage
fields.meaning: He who so lives as to know Him who is the support of all things and abandon all desire, will be freed from the evils which would otherwise cleave to him and destroy (his efforts after absorption)

fields.couplet: Woes expire when lust, wrath, folly  Expire even to name, fully
fields.meaning: If the very names of these three things, desire, anger, and confusion of mind, be destroyed, then will also perish evils (which flow from them)

fields.couplet: Desire to all, always is seed  From which ceaseless births proceed
fields.meaning: (The wise) say that the seed, which produces unceasing births, at all times, to all creatures, is desire

fields.couplet: If long thou must, long for non-birth  It comes by longing no more for earth
fields.meaning: If anything be desired, freedom from births should be desired; that (freedom from births) will be attained by desiring to be without desire

fields.couplet: No such wealth is here and there  As peerless wealth of non-desire
fields.meaning: There is in this world no excellence equal to freedom from desire; and even in that world, there is nothing like it

fields.couplet: To nothing crave is purity  That is the fruit of verity
fields.meaning: Purity (of mind) consists in freedom from desire; and that (freedom from desire) is the fruit of the love of truth

fields.couplet: The free are those who desire not  The rest not free in bonds are caught
fields.meaning: They are said to be free (from future birth) who are freed from desire; all others (who, whatever else they may be free from, are not freed from desire) are not thus free

fields.couplet: Dread desire; Virtue is there  To every soul desire is snare!
fields.meaning: It is the chief duty of (an ascetic) to watch against desire with (jealous) fear; for it has power to deceive (and destroy) him

fields.couplet: Destroy desire; deliverance  Comes as much as you aspire hence
fields.meaning: If a man thoroughly cut off all desire, the deeds, which confer immortality, will come to him, in the path in which he seeks them

fields.couplet: Desire extinct no sorrow-taints  Grief comes on grief where it pretends
fields.meaning: There is no sorrow to those who are without desire; but where that is, (sorrow) will incessantly come, more and more

fields.couplet: Desire, the woe of woes destroy  Joy of joys here you enjoy
