fields.meaning: Even while in this body, joy will never depart (from the mind, in which) desire, that sorrow of sorrows, has been destroyed

fields.couplet: Off with desire insatiate  You gain the native blissful state
fields.meaning: The removal of desire, whose nature it is never to be satisfied, will immediately confer a nature that can never be changed

fields.couplet: Efforts succeed by waxing star  Wealth-losing brings waning star
fields.meaning: Perseverance comes from a prosperous fate, and idleness from an adverse fate

fields.couplet: Loss-fate makes a dull fool of us  Gain-fate makes us prosperous, wise!
fields.meaning: An adverse fate produces folly, and a prosperous fate produces enlarged knowledge

fields.couplet: What matters subtle study deep?  Levels of innate wisdom-keep
fields.meaning: Although (a man) may study the most polished treatises, the knowledge which fate has decreed to him will still prevail

fields.couplet: Two natures in the world obtain  Some wealth and others wisdom gain
fields.meaning: There are (through fate) two different natures in the world, hence the difference (observable in men) in (their acquisition of) wealth, and in their attainment of knowledge

fields.couplet: In making wealth fate changes mood;  The good as bad and bad as good
fields.meaning: In the acquisition of property, every thing favourable becomes unfavourable, and (on the other hand) everything unfavourable becomes favourable, (through the power of fate)

fields.couplet: Things not thine never remain  Things destined are surely thine
fields.meaning: Whatever is not conferred by fate cannot be preserved although it be guarded with most painful care; and that, which fate has made his, cannot be lost, although one should even take it and throw it away

fields.couplet: Who crores amass enjoy but what  The Dispenser's decrees allot
fields.meaning: Even those who gather together millions will only enjoy them, as it has been determined by the disposer (of all things)

fields.couplet: The destitute desire will quit  If fate with ills visit them not
fields.meaning: The destitute will renounce desire (and become ascetics), if (fate) do not make them suffer the hindrances to which they are liable, and they pass away

fields.couplet: Who good in time of good perceive  In evil time why should they grieve?
fields.meaning: How is it that those, who are pleased with good fortune, trouble themselves when evil comes, (since both are equally the decree of fate) ?

fields.couplet: What power surpasses fate? Its will  Persists against the human skill
fields.meaning: What is stronger than fate ? If we think of an expedient (to avert it), it will itself be with us before (the thought)

fields.couplet: People, troops, wealth, forts, council, friends  Who owns these six is lion of kings
fields.meaning: He who possesses these six things, an army, a people, wealth, ministers, friends and a fortress, is a lion among kings

fields.couplet: Courage, giving, knowledge and zeal  Are four failless features royal
fields.meaning: Never to fail in these four things, fearlessness, liberality, wisdom, and energy, is the kingly character

fields.couplet: Alertness, learning bravery  Are adjuncts three of monarchy
fields.meaning: These three things, viz, vigilance, learning, and bravery, should never be wanting in the ruler of a country

fields.couplet: A brave noble king refrains from vice  Full of virtue and enterprise
fields.meaning: He is a king who, with manly modesty, swerves not from virtue, and refrains from vice

fields.couplet: The able king gets, stores and guards  And spends them for people's safeguards
fields.meaning: He is a king who is able to acquire (wealth), to lay it up, to guard, and to distribute it

fields.couplet: That land prospers where the king is  Easy to see, not harsh of words
fields.meaning: The whole world will exalt the country of the king who is easy of access, and who is free from harsh language

fields.couplet: The world commends and acts his phrase  Who sweetly speaks and gives with grace
fields.meaning: The world will praise and submit itself to the mind of the king who is able to give with affability, and to protect all who come to him

fields.couplet: He is the Lord of men who does  Sound justice and saves his race
fields.meaning: That king, will be esteemed a God among men, who performs his own duties, and protects (his subjects).

fields.couplet: Under his shelter thrives the world  Who bears remarks bitter and bold
fields.meaning: The whole world will dwell under the umbrella of the king, who can bear words that embitter the ear

fields.couplet: He is the Light of Kings who has  Bounty, justice, care and grace
fields.meaning: He is the light of kings who has there four things, beneficence, benevolence, rectitude, and care for his people

fields.couplet: Lore worth learning, learn flawlessly  Live by that learning thoroughly
fields.meaning: Let a man learn thoroughly whatever he may learn, and let his conduct be worthy of his learning

fields.couplet: Letter, number, art and science  Of living kind both are the eyes
fields.meaning: Letters and numbers are the two eyes of man

fields.couplet: The learned alone have eyes on face  The ignorant two sores of disgrace
fields.meaning: The learned are said to have eyes, but the unlearned have (merely) two sores in their face

fields.couplet: To meet with joy and part with thought  Of learned men this is the art
fields.meaning: It is the part of the learned to give joy to those whom they meet, and on leaving, to make them think (Oh! when shall we meet them again.)

fields.couplet: Like poor before rich they yearn:  For knowledge: the low never learn
fields.meaning: The unlearned are inferior to the learned, before whom they stand begging, as the destitute before the wealthy

fields.couplet: As deep you dig the sand spring flows  As deep you learn the knowledge grows
fields.meaning: Water will flow from a well in the sand in proportion to the depth to which it is dug, and knowledge will flow from a man in proportion to his learning

fields.couplet: All lands and towns are learner's own  Why not till death learning go on!
fields.meaning: How is it that any one can remain without learning, even to his death, when (to the learned man) every country is his own (country), and every town his own (town) ?

fields.couplet: The joy of learning in one birth  Exalts man upto his seventh
fields.meaning: The learning, which a man has acquired in one birth, will yield him pleasure during seven births

fields.couplet: The learned foster learning more  On seeing the world enjoy their lore
fields.meaning: The learned will long (for more learning), when they see that while it gives pleasure to themselves, the world also derives pleasure from it

fields.couplet: Learning is wealth none could destroy  Nothing else gives genuine joy
fields.meaning: Learning is the true imperishable riches; all other things are not riches

fields.couplet: Like play of chess on squareless board  Vain is imperfect loreless word
fields.meaning: To speak in an assembly (of the learned) without fullness of knowledge, is like playing at chess (on a board) without squares

fields.couplet: Unlearned man aspiring speech  Is breastless lady's love-approach
fields.meaning: The desire of the unlearned to speak (in an assembly), is like a woman without breasts desiring (the enjoyment of ) woman-hood

fields.couplet: Ev'n unread men are good and wise  If before the wise, they hold their peace
fields.meaning: The unlearned also are very excellent men, if they know how to keep silence before the learned

fields.couplet: The unread's wit though excellent  Is not valued by the savant
fields.meaning: Although the natural knowledge of an unlearned man may be very good, the wise will not accept for true knowledge

fields.couplet: A man untaught when speech he vaunts  Sadly fails before savants
fields.meaning: The self-conceit of an unlearned man will fade away, as soon as he speaks in an assembly (of

fields.couplet: People speak of untaught minds  \"They just exist like barren lands\"
fields.meaning: The unlearned are like worthless barren land: all that can be said of them is, that they exist

fields.couplet: Like painted clay-doll is his show  Grand subtle lore who fails to know
fields.meaning: The beauty and goodness of one who is destitute of knowledge by the study of great and exquisite works, is like (the beauty and goodness) of a painted earthen doll

fields.couplet: Wealth in the hand of fools is worse  Than a learned man's empty purse
fields.meaning: Wealth, gained by the unlearned, will give more sorrow than the poverty which may come upon the learned

fields.couplet: Lower are fools of higher birth  Than low-born men of learning's worth
fields.meaning: The unlearned, though born in a high caste, are not equal in dignity to the learned; though they may have been born in a low caste

fields.couplet: Like beasts before men, dunces are  Before scholars of shining lore
fields.meaning: As beasts by the side of men, so are other men by the side of those who are learned in celebrated works

fields.couplet: Wealth of wealths is listening's wealth  It is the best of wealths on earth
fields.meaning: Wealth (gained) by the ear is wealth of wealth; that wealth is the chief of all wealth

fields.couplet: Some food for the stomach is brought  When the ear gets no food for thought
fields.meaning: When there is no food for the ear, give a little also to the stomach

fields.couplet: Whose ears get lots of wisdom-food  Equal gods on oblations fed
fields.meaning: Those who in this world enjoy instruction which is the food of the ear, are equal to the Gods, who enjoy the food of the sacrifices

fields.couplet: Though not learned, hear and heed  That serves a staff and stay in need
fields.meaning: Although a man be without learning, let him listen (to the teaching of the learned); that will be to him a staff in adversity

fields.couplet: Virtuous men's wisdom is found  A strong staff on slippery ground
fields.meaning: The words of the good are like a staff in a slippery place

fields.couplet: Lend ear to good words however few  That much will highly exalt you
fields.meaning: Let a man listen, never so little, to good (instruction), even that will bring him great dignity

fields.couplet: Who listen well and learn sharply  Not ev'n by slip speak foolishly
fields.meaning: Not even when they have imperfectly understood (a matter), will those men speak foolishly, who have profoundly studied and diligently listened (to instruction)

fields.couplet: That ear though hearing is dulled  Which is not by wisdom drilled
fields.meaning: The ear which has not been bored by instruction, although it hears, is deaf

fields.couplet: A modest mouth is hard for those  Who care little to counsels wise
fields.meaning: It is a rare thing to find modesty, a reverend mouth- with those who have not received choice instruction

fields.couplet: Who taste by mouth and not by ear  What if they fare ill or well here?
fields.meaning: What does it matter whether those men live or die, who can judge of tastes by the mouth, and not by the ear ?

fields.couplet: Wisdom's weapon wards off all woes  It is a fort defying foes
fields.meaning: Wisdom is a weapon to ward off destruction; it is an inner fortress which enemies cannot destroy

fields.couplet: Wisdom checks the straying senses  Expels evils, impels goodness
fields.meaning: Not to permit the mind to go where it lists, to keep it from evil, and to employ it in good, this is wisdom

fields.couplet: To grasp the Truth from everywhere  From everyone is wisdom fair
fields.meaning: To discern the truth in every thing, by whomsoever spoken, is wisdom

fields.couplet: Speaking out thoughts in clear trends  Wisdom subtle sense comprehends
fields.meaning: To speak so as that the meaning may easily enter the mind of the hearer, and to discern the subtlest thought which may lie hidden in the words of others, this is wisdom

fields.couplet: The wise-world the wise befriend  They bloom nor gloom, equal in mind
fields.meaning: To secure the friendship of the great is true wisdom; it is (also) wisdom to keep (that friendship unchanged, and) not opening and closing (like the lotus flower)

fields.couplet: As moves the world so move the wise  In tune with changing times and ways
fields.meaning: To live as the world lives, is wisdom

fields.couplet: The wise foresee what is to come  The unwise lack in that wisdom
fields.meaning: The wise are those who know beforehand what will happen; those who do not know this are the unwise

fields.couplet: Fear the frightful and act wisely  Not to fear the frightful's folly
fields.meaning: Not to fear what ought to be feared, is folly; it is the work of the wise to fear what should be feared

fields.couplet: No frightful evil shocks the wise  Who guard themselves against surprise
fields.meaning: No terrifying calamity will happen to the wise, who (foresee) and guard against coming evils

fields.couplet: Who have wisdom they are all full  Whatev'r they own, misfits are nil
fields.meaning: Those who possess wisdom, possess every thing; those who have not wisdom, whatever they may possess, have nothing

fields.couplet: Plenty is their prosperity  Who're free from wrath pride lust petty
fields.meaning: Truly great is the excellence of those (kings) who are free from pride, anger, and lust

fields.couplet: Mean pride, low pleasure, avarice  These add blemishes to a prince
fields.meaning: Avarice, undignified pride, and low pleasures are faults in a king

fields.couplet: Though millet-small their faults might seem  Men fearing disgrace, Palm-tall deem
fields.meaning: Those who fear guilt, if they commit a fault small as a millet seed, will consider it to be as large as a palmyra tree

fields.couplet: Watch like treasure freedom from fault  Our fatal foe is that default
fields.meaning: Guard against faults as a matter (of great consequence; for) faults are a deadly enemy

fields.couplet: Who fails to guard himself from flaw  Loses his life like flame-lit straw
fields.meaning: The prosperity of him who does not timely guard against faults, will perish like straw before fire

fields.couplet: What fault can be the king's who cures  First his faults, then scans others
fields.meaning: What fault will remain in the king who has put away his own evils, and looks after the evils of others

fields.couplet: That miser's wealth shall waste and end  Who would not for a good cause spend
fields.meaning: The wealth of the avaricious man, who does not expend it for the purposes for which he ought to expend it will waste away and not continue

fields.couplet: The gripping greed of miser's heart  Is more than fault the worst apart
fields.meaning: Griping avarice is not to be reckoned as one among other faults; (it stands alone - greater than all)

fields.couplet: Never boast yourself in any mood  Nor do a deed that does no good
fields.meaning: Let no (one) praise himself, at any time; let him not desire to do useless things

fields.couplet: All designs of the foes shall fail  If one his wishes guards in veil
fields.meaning: If (a king) enjoys, privately the things which he desires, the designs of his enemies will be useless

fields.couplet: Weigh their worth and friendship gain  Of men of virtue and mature brain
fields.meaning: Let (a king) ponder well its value, and secure the friendship of men of virtue and of mature knowledge

fields.couplet: Cherish the help of men of skill  Who ward and safe-guard you from ill
fields.meaning: Let (a king) procure and kindly care for men who can overcome difficulties when they occur, and guard against them before they happen

fields.couplet: Honour and have the great your own  Is rarest of the rare things known
fields.meaning: To cherish great men and make them his own, is the most difficult of all difficult things

fields.couplet: To have betters as intimates  Power of all powers promotes
fields.meaning: So to act as to make those men, his own, who are greater than himself is of all powers the highest

fields.couplet: Ministers are the monarch's eyes  Round him should be the right and wise
fields.meaning: As a king must use his ministers as eyes (in managing his kingdom), let him well examine their character and qualifications before he engages them

fields.couplet: To move with worthy friends who knows  Has none to fear from frightful foes
fields.meaning: There will be nothing left for enemies to do, against him who has the power of acting (so as to secure) the fellowship of worthy men

fields.couplet: No foe can foil his powers  whose friends reprove him when he errs
fields.meaning: Who are great enough to destroy him who has servants that have power to rebuke him ?

fields.couplet: The careless king whom none reproves  Ruins himself sans harmful foes
fields.meaning: The king, who is without the guard of men who can rebuke him, will perish, even though there be no one to destroy him

fields.couplet: No capital, no gain in trade  No prop secure sans good comrade
fields.meaning: There can be no gain to those who have no capital; and in like manner there can be no permanence to

fields.couplet: To give up good friends is ten times worse  Than being hated by countless foes
fields.meaning: It is tenfold more injurious to abandon the friendship of the good, than to incur the hatred of the many

fields.couplet: The ignoble the noble fear  The mean hold them as kinsmen dear
fields.meaning: (True) greatness fears the society of the base; it is only the low - minded who will regard them as friends

fields.couplet: With soil changes water's taste  With mates changes the mental state
fields.meaning: As water changes (its nature), from the nature of the soil (in which it flows), so will the character of men resemble that of their associates

fields.couplet: Wisdom depends upon the mind  The worth of man upon his friend
fields.meaning: The power of knowing is from the mind; (but) his character is from that of his associates

fields.couplet: Wisdom seems to come from mind  But it truly flows from the kind
fields.meaning: Wisdom appears to rest in the mind, but it really exists to a man in his companions

fields.couplet: Purity of the thought and deed  Comes from good company indeed
fields.meaning: Chaste company is the staff on which come, these two things, viz, purity of mind and purity of conduct

fields.couplet: Pure-hearted get good progeny  Pure friendship acts with victory
fields.meaning: To the pure-minded there will be a good posterity By those whose associates are pure, no deeds will be done that are not good

fields.couplet: Goodness of mind increases gain  Good friendship fosters fame again
fields.meaning: Goodness of mind will give wealth, and good society will bring with it all praise, to men

fields.couplet: Men of wisdom, though good in mind  In friends of worth a new strength find
fields.meaning: Yet good companionship is confirmation strong

fields.couplet: Good mind decides the future bliss  Good company gains strength to this
fields.meaning: Future bliss is (the result) of goodness of mind; and even this acquires strength from the society of the good

fields.couplet: No help good company exeeds;  The bad to untold anguish leads
fields.meaning: There is no greater help than the company of the good; there is no greater source of sorrow than the company of the wicked

fields.couplet: Weigh well output the loss and gain  And proper action ascertain
fields.meaning: Let a man reflect on what will be lost, what will be acquired and (from these) what will be his ultimate gain, and (then, let him) act

fields.couplet: Nothing is hard for him who acts  With worthy counsels weighing facts
fields.meaning: There is nothing too difficult to (be attained by) those who, before they act, reflect well themselves, and thoroughly consider (the matter) with chosen friends

fields.couplet: The wise risk not their capital  In doubtful gains and lose their all
fields.meaning: Wise men will not, in the hopes of profit, undertake works that will consume their principal

fields.couplet: They who scornful reproach fear  Commence no work not made clear
fields.meaning: Those who fear reproach will not commence anything which has not been (thoroughly considered) and made clear to them

fields.couplet: Who marches without plans and ways  His field is sure to foster foes
fields.meaning: One way to promote the prosperity of an enemy, is (for a king) to set out (to war) without having thoroughly weighed his ability (to cope with its chances)

fields.couplet: Doing unfit action ruins Failing fit-act also ruins
fields.meaning: He will perish who does not what is not fit to do; and he also will perish who does not do what it is fit to

fields.couplet: Think and dare a proper deed  Dare and think is bad in need
fields.meaning: Consider, and then undertake a matter; after having undertaken it, to say "We will consider," is folly

fields.couplet: Toil without a plan ahead Is doomed to fall though supported
fields.meaning: The work, which is not done by suitable methods, will fail though many stand to uphold it

fields.couplet: Attune the deeds to habitude Or ev'n good leads to evil feud
fields.meaning: There are failures even in acting well, when it is done without knowing the various dispositions of men

fields.couplet: Do deeds above reproachfulness The world refutes uncomely mess
fields.meaning: Let a man reflect, and do things which bring no reproach; the world will not approve, with him, of things which do not become of his position to adopt

fields.couplet: Judge act and might and foeman's strength The allies' strength and go at length
fields.meaning: Let (one) weigh well the strength of the deed (he purposes to do), his own strength, the strength of his enemy, and the strength of the allies (of both), and then let him act

fields.couplet: Nothing hampers the firm who know What they can and how to go
fields.meaning: There is nothing which may not be accomplished by those who, before they attack (an enemy), make themselves acquainted with their own ability, and with whatever else is (needful) to be known, and

fields.couplet: Many know not their meagre might Their pride breaks up in boastful fight
fields.meaning: There are many who, ignorant of their (want of) power (to meet it), have haughtily set out to war, and broken down in the midst of it

fields.couplet: Who adapts not, outsteps measure And brags himself-his fall is sure
fields.meaning: He will quickly perish who, ignorant of his own resources flatters himself of his greatness, and does

fields.couplet: Even the gentle peacock's plume Cart's axle breaks by gross volume
fields.meaning: The axle tree of a bandy, loaded only with peacocks' feathers will break, if it be greatly overloaded

fields.couplet: Beyond the branches' tip who skips Ends the life as his body rips
fields.meaning: There will be an end to the life of him who, having climbed out to the end of a branch, ventures to go further

fields.couplet: Know the limit; grant with measure This way give and guard your treasure
fields.meaning: Let a man know the measure of his ability (to give), and let him give accordingly; such giving is the way to preserve his property

fields.couplet: The outflow must not be excess No matter how small income is
fields.meaning: Even though the income (of a king) be small, it will not cause his (ruin), if his outgoings be not larger than his income

fields.couplet: Who does not know to live in bounds His life seems rich but thins and ends
fields.meaning: The prosperity of him who lives without knowing the measure (of his property), will perish, even while it seems to continue

fields.couplet: Wealth amassed quickly vanishes Sans level if one lavishes
fields.meaning: The measure of his wealth will quickly perish, whose liberality weighs not the measure of his property

fields.couplet: By day the crow defeats the owl Kings need right time their foes to quell
fields.meaning: A crow will overcome an owl in the day time; so the king who would conquer his enemy must have (a suitable) time

fields.couplet: Well-ordered seasoned act is cord That fortune binds in bon accord
fields.meaning: Acting at the right season, is a cord that will immoveably bind success (to a king)

fields.couplet: What is hard for him who acts With proper means and time and tacts?
fields.meaning: Is there anything difficult for him to do, who acts, with (the right) instruments at the right time ?

fields.couplet: Choose proper time and act and place Even the world you win with ease
fields.meaning: Though (a man) should meditate (the conquest of) the world, he may accomplish it if he acts in the right time, and at the right place

fields.couplet: Who want to win the world sublime Wait unruffled biding their time
fields.meaning: They who thoughtfully consider and wait for the (right) time (for action), may successfully meditate (the conquest of) the world

fields.couplet: By self-restraint stalwarts keep fit Like rams retreating but to butt
fields.meaning: The self-restraint of the energetic (while waiting for a suitable opportunity), is like the drawing back of a fighting-ram in order to butt

fields.couplet: The wise jut not their vital fire They watch their time with hidden ire
fields.meaning: The wise will not immediately and hastily shew out their anger; they will watch their time, and restrain it within

fields.couplet: Bear with hostiles when you meet them Fell down their head in fateful time
fields.meaning: If one meets his enemy, let him show him all respect, until the time for his destruction is come; when that is come, his head will be easily brought low

fields.couplet: When comes the season ripe and rare Dare and do hard things then and there
fields.meaning: If a rare opportunity occurs, while it lasts, let a man do that which is rarely to be accomplished (but for such an opportunity)

fields.couplet: In waiting time feign peace like stork In fighting time strike like its peck
fields.meaning: At the time when one should use self-control, let him restrain himself like a heron; and, let him like it, strike, when there is a favourable opportunity

fields.couplet: No action take, no foe despise Until you have surveyed the place
fields.meaning: Let not (a king) despise (an enemy), nor undertake any thing (against him), until he has obtained (a suitable) place for besieging him

fields.couplet: Many are gains of fortresses Ev'n to kings of power and prowess
fields.meaning: Even to those who are men of power and expedients, an attack in connection with a fortification will yield many advantages

fields.couplet: Weaklings too withstand foe's offence In proper fields of strong defence
fields.meaning: Even the powerless will become powerful and conquer, if they select a proper field (of action), and guard themselves, while they make war on their enemies

fields.couplet: If fighters fight in vantage field The plans of foes shall be baffled
fields.meaning: If they who draw near (to fight) choose a suitable place to approach (their enemy), the latter, will have to relinquish the thought which they once entertained, of conquering them

fields.couplet: In water crocodile prevails In land before others it fails
fields.meaning: In deep water, a crocodile will conquer (all other animals); but if it leave the water, other animals will conquer it

fields.couplet: Sea-going ship goes not on shore Nor on sea the strong-wheeled car
fields.meaning: Wide chariots, with mighty wheels, will not run on the ocean; neither will ships that the traverse ocean, move on the earth

fields.couplet: No aid but daring dash they need When field is chosen right for deed
fields.meaning: You will need no other aid than fearlessness, if you thoroughly reflect (on what you are to do), and select (a suitable) place for your operations

fields.couplet: Though force is small, if place is right One quells a foe of well-armed might
fields.meaning: The power of one who has a large army will perish, if he goes into ground where only a small army can act

fields.couplet: To face a foe at home is vain Though fort and status are not fine
fields.meaning: It is a hazardous thing to attack men in their own country, although they may neither have power nor a good fortress

fields.couplet: A fox can kill a war tusker Fearless with feet in deep quagmire
fields.meaning: A fox can kill a fearless, warrior-faced elephant, if it go into mud in which its legs sink down

fields.couplet: Pleasure, gold, fear of life Virtue- Test by these four and trust the true
fields.meaning: Let (a minister) be chosen, after he has been tried by means of these four things, viz,-his virtue, (love of) money, (love of) sexual pleasure, and tear of (losing) life

fields.couplet: Spotless name of noble birth Shamed of stain-that choice is worth
fields.meaning: (The king's) choice should (fall) on him, who is of good family, who is free from faults, and who has the modesty which fears the wounds (of sin)

fields.couplet: Though deep scholars of stainless sense Rare is freedom from ignorance
fields.meaning: When even men, who have studied the most difficult works, and who are free from faults, are (carefully) examined, it is a rare thing to find them without ignorance

fields.couplet: Good and evil in man weigh well Judge him by virtues which prevail
fields.meaning: Let (a king) consider (a man's) good qualities, as well as his faults, and then judge (of his character) by that which prevails

fields.couplet: By the touchstone of deeds is seen If any one is great or mean
fields.meaning: A man's deeds are the touchstone of his greatness and littleness

fields.couplet: Choose not those men without kinsmen Without affine or shame of sin
fields.meaning: Let (a king) avoid choosing men who have no relations; such men have no attachment, and thereforehave no fear of crime

fields.couplet: On favour leaning fools you choose; Folly in all its forms ensues
fields.meaning: Yields all his being up to folly's blind control

fields.couplet: To trust an untried stranger brings Endless troubles on all our kins
fields.meaning: Sorrow that will not leave even his posterity will come upon him chooses a stranger whose character he has not known

fields.couplet: Trust not without testing and then Find proper work for trusted men
fields.meaning: Let (a king) choose no one without previous consideration; after he has made his choice, let him unhesitatingly select for each such duties as are appropriate

fields.couplet: Trust without test; The trusted doubt; Both entail troubles in and out
fields.meaning: To make choice of one who has not been examined, and to entertain doubts respecting one who has been chosen, will produce irremediable sorrow

fields.couplet: Employ the wise who will discern The good and bad and do good turn
fields.meaning: He should be employed (by a king), whose nature leads him to choose the good, after having weighed both the evil and the good in any undertaking

fields.couplet: Let him act who resource swells; Fosters wealth and prevents ills
fields.meaning: Let him do (the king's) work who can enlarge the sources (of revenue), increase wealth and considerately prevent the accidents (which would destroy it)

fields.couplet: Trust him in whom these four you see: Love, wit, non-craving, clarity
fields.meaning: Let the choice (of a king) fall upon him who largely possesses these four things, love, knowledge, a clear mind and freedom from covetousness

fields.couplet: Though tried and found fit, yet we see Many differ before duty
fields.meaning: Even when (a king) has tried them in every possible way, there are many men who change, from the nature of the works (in which they may be employed)

fields.couplet: Wise able men with power invest Not by fondness but by hard test
fields.meaning: (A king's) work can only be accomplished by a man of wisdom and patient endurance; it is not of a nature to be given to one from mere personal attachment

fields.couplet: Discern the agent and the deed And just in proper time proceed
fields.meaning: Let (a king) act, after having considered the agent (whom he is to employ), the deed (he desires to do), and the time which is suitable to it

fields.couplet: This work, by this, this man can do Like this entrust the duty due
fields.meaning: After having considered, "this man can accomplish this, by these means", let (the king) leave with him the discharge of that duty

fields.couplet: His fitness for the duty scan Leave him to do the best he can
fields.meaning: Having considered what work a man is fit for, let (the king) employ him in that work

fields.couplet: Who do duty for duty's sake Doubt them; and fortune departs quick
fields.meaning: Prosperity will leave (the king) who doubts the friendship of the man who steadily labours in the discharge of his duties

fields.couplet: Worker straight the world is straight The king must look to this aright
fields.meaning: Let a king daily examine the conduct of his servants; if they do not act crookedly, the world will not act crookedly

fields.couplet: Let fortunes go; yet kinsmen know The old accustomed love to show
fields.meaning: Even when (a man's) property is all gone, relatives will act towards him with their accustomed (kindness)

fields.couplet: The gift of loving Kins bestows  Fadeless fortune's fresh flowers
fields.meaning: If (a man's) relatives remain attached to him with unchanging love, it will be a source of everincreasing wealth

fields.couplet: A kinless wealth is like a tank Which overflows without a bank
fields.meaning: The wealth of one who does not mingle freely with his relatives, will be like the filling of water in a

fields.couplet: The fruit of growing wealth is gained When kith and kin are happy found
fields.meaning: To live surrounded by relatives, is the advantage to be derived from the acquisition of wealth

fields.couplet: Loving words and liberal hand Encircle kith and kin around
fields.meaning: He will be surrounded by numerous relatives who manifests generosity and affability

fields.couplet: Large giver and wrathless man Commands on earth countless kinsmen
fields.meaning: No one, in all the world, will have so many relatives (about him), as he who makes large gift, and does not give way to anger

fields.couplet: The crows hide not; thy call and eat Welfare abides a man of heart
fields.meaning: The crows do not conceal (their prey), but will call out for others (to share with them) while they eat it; wealth will be with those who show a similar disposition (towards their relatives)

fields.couplet: From public gaze when kings perceive Each one's merits so many thrive
fields.meaning: Many relatives will live near a king, when they observe that he does not look on all alike, but that he looks on each man according to his merit

fields.couplet: Forsaken friends will come and stay When cause for discord goes away
fields.meaning: Those who have been friends and have afterwards forsaken him, will return and join themselves (to him), when the cause of disagreement is not to be found in him

fields.couplet: Who leaves and returns with motive The king should test him and receive
fields.meaning: When one may have left him, and for some cause has returned to him, let the king fulfil the object (for which he has come back) and thoughtfully receive him again

fields.couplet: Worse than wrath in excess is Forgetfulness in joy-excess
fields.meaning: More evil than excessive anger, is forgetfulness which springs from the intoxication of great joy

fields.couplet: Negligence kills renown just as Ceaseless want wisdom destroys
fields.meaning: Forgetfulness will destroy fame, even as constant poverty destroys knowledge

fields.couplet: Forgetful nature fails of fame All schools of thinkers say the same
fields.meaning: Thoughtlessness will never acquire fame; and this tenet is upheld by all treatises in the world

fields.couplet: The fearful find no fortress here The forgetful find good never
fields.meaning: Just as the coward has no defence (by whatever fortifications ha may be surrounded), so the thoughtless has no good (whatever advantages he may possess)

fields.couplet: Failing foresight the guardless man Shall rue his folly later on
fields.meaning: The thoughtless man, who provides not against the calamities that may happen, will afterwards repent for his fault

fields.couplet: Forget none; watch with wakeful care Miss none; the gain is sans compare
fields.meaning: There is nothing comparable with the possession of unfailing thoughtfulness at all times; and towards all persons

fields.couplet: With cautious care pursue a thing Impossible there is nothing
fields.meaning: There is nothing too difficult to be accomplished, if a man set about it carefully, with unflinching endeavour

fields.couplet: Do what the wise commend as worth If not, for seven births no mirth
fields.meaning: Let (a man) observe and do these things which have been praised (by the wise); if he neglects and fails to perform them, for him there will be no (happiness) throughout the seven births

fields.couplet: When joy deludes, their fate recall Whom negligence has made to fall
fields.meaning: Let (a king) think of those who have been ruined by neglect, when his mind is elated with joy

fields.couplet: Easy it is a thing to get When the mind on it is set
fields.meaning: It is easy for (one) to obtain whatever he may think of, if he can again think of it

fields.couplet: Test and attest impartially Consult and act the laws justly
fields.meaning: To examine into (the crimes which may be committed), to show no favour (to any one), to desire to act with impartiality towards all, and to inflict (such punishments) as may be wisely resolved on,

fields.couplet: The earth looks up to sky and thrives And mankind to king's rod of justice
fields.meaning: When there is rain, the living creation thrives; and so when the king rules justly, his subjects thrive

fields.couplet: The Sage's scripture and virtue spring From the sceptre of a stately king
fields.meaning: The sceptre of the king is the firm support of the Vedas of the Brahmin, and of all virtues therein described

fields.couplet: The world clings to the ruler's feet Whose sceptre clasps the people's heart
fields.meaning: The world will constantly embrace the feet of the great king who rules over his subjects with love

fields.couplet: Full rains and yields enrich the land Which is ruled by a righteous hand
fields.meaning: Rain and plentiful crops will ever dwell together in the country of the king who sways his sceptre with justice

fields.couplet: Not the spear but the sceptre straight That brings success to monarch's might
fields.meaning: It is not the javelin that gives victory, but the king's sceptre, if it do no injustice

fields.couplet: The king protects the entire earth And justice protects his royal worth
fields.meaning: The king defends the whole world; and justice, when administered without defect, defends the king

fields.couplet: Hard of access, the unjust king He shall himself his ruin bring
fields.meaning: The king who gives not facile audience (to those who approach him), and who does not examine and pass judgment (on their complaints), will perish in disgrace

fields.couplet: Save his subjects and chide the wrong Is flawless duty of a king
fields.meaning: In guarding his subjects (against injury from others), and in preserving them himself; to punish crime

fields.couplet: Killing killers, the king, behold Weeds removes from cropful field
fields.meaning: For a king to punish criminals with death, is like pulling up the weeds in the green corn

fields.couplet: The unjust tyrant oppressor  Is worse than cruel murderer
fields.meaning: The king who gives himself up to oppression and acts unjustly (towards his subjects) is more cruel than the man who leads the life of a murderer

fields.couplet: Sceptered tyrant exacting gold Is \"give\" of lanced robber bold
fields.meaning: The request (for money) of him who holds the sceptre is like the word of a highway robber who stands with a weapon in hand and says "give up your wealth"

fields.couplet: Spy wrongs daily and do justice Or day by day the realm decays
fields.meaning: The country of the king who does not daily examine into the wrongs done and distribute justice, will daily fall to ruin

fields.couplet: The king shall wealth and subjects lose If his sceptre he dares abuse
fields.meaning: The king, who, without reflecting (on its evil consequences), perverts justice, will lose at once both his wealth and his subjects

fields.couplet: Groaning tears caused by tyrant's sway  File the royal wealth away
fields.meaning: Will not the tears, shed by a people who cannot endure the oppression which they suffer (from their king), become a saw to waste away his wealth ?

fields.couplet: Glory endures by sceptre right Without it wanes the royal light
fields.meaning: Righteous government gives permanence to (the fame of) kings; without that their fame will have no endurance

fields.couplet: Dry like the earth without rainfall Is graceless king to creatures all
fields.meaning: As is the world without rain, so live a people whose king is without kindness

fields.couplet: To have is worse than having not If ruler is unjust despot
fields.meaning: Property gives more sorrow than poverty, to those who live under the sceptre of a king without justice

fields.couplet: The sky withdraws season's shower If the king misuses his power
fields.meaning: If the king acts contrary to justice, rain will become unseasonable, and the heavens will withhold their showers

fields.couplet: The *six-functioned forget their lore Cows give less if kings guard no more * the six functions are: learning, teaching,  giving,  getting, sacrificing, kindling sacrifice These are duties of Vedic savants
fields.meaning: If the guardian (of the country) neglects to guard it, the produce of the cows will fail, and the men of six duties viz, the Brahmins will forget the vedas

fields.couplet: A king enquires and gives sentence  Just to prevent future offence
fields.meaning: He is a king who having equitably examined (any injustice which has been brought to his notice), suitably punishes it, so that it may not be again committed

fields.couplet: Wield fast the rod but gently lay This strict mildness prolongs the sway
fields.meaning: Let the king, who desires that his prosperity may long remain, commence his preliminary enquires with strictness, and then punish with mildness

fields.couplet: His cruel rod of dreadful deed Brings king's ruin quick indeed
fields.meaning: The cruel-sceptred king, who acts so as to put his subjects in fear, will certainly and quickly come to ruin

fields.couplet: As men the king a tyrant call  His days dwindled, hasten his fall
fields.meaning: The king who is spoken of as cruel will quickly perish; his life becoming shortened

fields.couplet: Whose sight is scarce, whose face is foul His wealth seems watched by a ghoul
fields.meaning: The great wealth of him who is difficult of access and possesses a sternness of countenance, is like that which has been obtained by a devil

fields.couplet: Whose word is harsh, whose sight is rude His wealth and power quickly fade
fields.meaning: The abundant wealth of the king whose words are harsh and whose looks are void of kindness, will instantly perish instead of abiding long, with him

fields.couplet: Reproofs rough and punishments rude Like files conquering power corrode
fields.meaning: Severe words and excessive punishments will be a file to waste away a king's power for destroying (his enemies)

fields.couplet: The king who would not take counsels Rages with wrath-his fortune fails
fields.meaning: The prosperity of that king will waste away, who without reflecting (on his affairs himself), commits them to his ministers, and (when a failure occurs) gives way to anger, and rages against them

fields.couplet: The king who builds not fort betimes Fears his foes in wars and dies
fields.meaning: The king who has not provided himself with a place of defence, will in times of war be seized with fear and quickly perish

fields.couplet: The crushing burden borne by earth Is tyrants bound to fools uncouth
fields.meaning: The earth bears up no greater burden than ignorant men whom a cruel sceptre attaches to itself (as the ministers of its evil deeds)

fields.couplet: Living in the world implies The bounteous dame of benign eyes
fields.meaning: The world exists through that greatest ornament (of princes), a gracious demeanour

fields.couplet: World lives by looks of lovely worth Who lack them are burdens of earth
fields.meaning: The prosperity of the world springs from the kindliness, the existence of those who have no (kindliness) is a burden to the earth

fields.couplet: Of tuneless song what is the use? Without gracious looks what are eyes?
fields.meaning: Of what avail is a song if it be inconsistent with harmony ? what is the use of eyes which possess no kindliness

fields.couplet: Except that they are on the face  What for are eyes sans measured grace
fields.meaning: Beyond appearing to be in the face, what good do they do, those eyes in which is no well-regulated kindness ?

fields.couplet: Kind looks are jewels for eyes to wear Without them they are felt as sore
fields.meaning: Kind looks are the ornaments of the eyes; without these they will be considered (by the wise) to be merely two sores

fields.couplet: Like trees on inert earth they grow Who don't eye to eye kindness show
fields.meaning: They resemble the trees of the earth, who although they have eyes, never look kindly (on others)

fields.couplet: Ungracious men lack real eyes Men of real eyes show benign grace
fields.meaning: Men without kind looks are men without eyes; those who (really) have eyes are also not devoid of kind looks

fields.couplet: Who gracious are but dutiful Have right for this earth beautiful
fields.meaning: The world is theirs (kings) who are able to show kindness, without injury to their affairs, (administration of justice)

fields.couplet: To be benign and bear with foes Who vex us is true virtue's phase
fields.meaning: Patiently to bear with, and show kindness to those who grieve us, is the most excellent of all dispositions

fields.couplet: Men of graceful courtesy Take hemlock and look cheerfully
fields.meaning: Those who desire (to cultivate that degree of) urbanity which all shall love, even after swallowing the poison served to them by their friends, will be friendly with them

fields.couplet: A king should treat these two as eyes  The code of laws and careful spies
fields.meaning: Let a king consider as his eyes these two things, a spy and a book (of laws) universally esteemed

fields.couplet: All that happens, always, to all  The king should know in full detail
fields.meaning: 'Tis duty of the king to learn with speed

fields.couplet: Conquests are not for the monarch Who cares not for the Spy's remark
fields.meaning: There is no way for a king to obtain conquests, who knows not the advantage of discoveries made by a spy

fields.couplet: His officers, kinsmen and foes  Who watch keenly are worthy spies
fields.meaning: He is a spy who watches all men, to wit, those who are in the king's employment, his relatives, and his enemies

fields.couplet: Fearless gaze, suspectless guise  Guarding secrets mark the spies
fields.meaning: A spy is one who is able to assume an appearance which may create no suspicion (in the minds of others), who fears no man's face, and who never reveals (his purpose)

fields.couplet: Guised as monks they gather secrets They betray them not under threats
fields.meaning: He is a spy who, assuming the appearance of an ascetic, goes into (whatever place he wishes), examines into (all, that is needful), and never discovers himself, whatever may be done to him

fields.couplet: A spy draws out other's secrets Beyond a doubt he clears his facts
fields.meaning: A spy is one who is able to discover what is hidden and who retains no doubt concerning what he has known

fields.couplet: The reports given by one spy By another spy verify
fields.meaning: Let not a king receive the information which a spy has discovered and made known to him, until he has examined it by another spy

fields.couplet: Engage the spies alone, apart When three agree confirm report
fields.meaning: Let a king employ spies so that one may have no knowledge of the other; and when the information of three agrees together, let him receive it

fields.couplet: Give not the spy open reward It would divulge the secret heard!
fields.meaning: Let not a king publicly confer on a spy any marks of his favour; if he does, he will divulge his own secret

fields.couplet: To own is to own energy All others own but lethargy
fields.meaning: Energy makes out the man of property; as for those who are destitute of it, do they (really) possess what they possess ?

fields.couplet: Psychic heart is wealth indeed Worldly wealth departs in speed
fields.meaning: The possession of (energy of) mind is true property; the possession of wealth passes away and abides not

fields.couplet: The strong in will do not complain  The loss of worldly wealth and gain
fields.meaning: They who are possessed of enduring energy will not trouble themselves, saying, "we have lost our property."

fields.couplet: Fortune enquires, enters with boom Where tireless strivers have their home
fields.meaning: Wealth will find its own way to the man of unfailing energy

fields.couplet: Water depth is lotus height  Mental strength is men's merit
fields.meaning: The stalks of water-flowers are proportionate to the depth of water; so is men's greatness proportionate to their minds

fields.couplet: Let thoughts be always great and grand  Though they fail their virtues stand
fields.meaning: In all that a king thinks of, let him think of his greatness; and if it should be thrust from him (by fate), it will have the nature of not being thrust from him

fields.couplet: Elephants are firm when arrows hit Great minds keep fit ev'n in defeat
fields.meaning: The strong minded will not faint, even when all is lost; the elephant stands firm, even when wounded by a shower of arrows

fields.couplet: Heartless persons cannot boast \"We are liberal to our best\"
fields.meaning: Those who have no (greatness of) mind, will not acquire the joy of saying in the world, "we have excercised liaberality"

fields.couplet: Huge elephant sharp in tusk quails  When tiger, less in form, assails
fields.meaning: Although the elephant has a large body, and a sharp tusk, yet it fears the attack of the tiger

fields.couplet: Mental courage is true manhood Lacking that man is like a wood
fields.meaning: Energy is mental wealth; those men who are destitute of it are only trees in the form of men

fields.couplet: Quenchless lamp of ancestry goes When foul idleness encloses
fields.meaning: By the darkness, of idleness, the indestructible lamp of family (rank) will be extinguished

fields.couplet: To make your home an ideal home Loath sloth as sloth; refuse it room
fields.meaning: Let those, who desire that their family may be illustrious, put away all idleness from their conduct

fields.couplet: The fool who fosters sluggishness Before he dies ruins his house
fields.meaning: The (lustre of the) family of the ignorant man, who acts under the influence of destructive laziness will perish, even before he is dead

fields.couplet: Who strive not high, sunk deep in sloth Ruin their house by evil growth
fields.meaning: Family (greatness) will be destroyed, and faults will increase, in those men who give way to laziness, and put forth no dignified exertions

fields.couplet: To lag, forget, idle and doze These four are pleasure boats of loss
fields.meaning: Procrastination, forgetfulness, idleness, and sleep, these four things, form the vessel which is desired by those destined to destruction

fields.couplet: With all the wealth of lords of earth The slothful gain nothing of worth
fields.meaning: It is a rare thing for the idle, even when possessed of the riches of kings who ruled over the whole earth, to derive any great benefit from it

fields.couplet: The slothful lacking noble deeds Subject themselves to scornful words
fields.meaning: Those who through idleness, and do not engage themselves in dignified exertion, will subject

fields.couplet: If sloth invades a noble house It will become a slave of foes
fields.meaning: If idleness take up its abode in a king of high birth, it will make him a slave of his enemies

fields.couplet: The blots on race and rule shall cease When one from sloth gets his release
fields.meaning: When a man puts away idleness, the reproach which has come upon himself and his family will disappear

fields.couplet: The slothless king shall gain en masse *All regions trod by Lord apace * Hindu mythology holds that Lord Vishnu measured with his feet the three worlds
fields.meaning: The king who never gives way to idleness will obtain entire possession of (the whole earth) passed over by him who measured (the worlds) with His foot

fields.couplet: Feel not frustrate saying This hard Who tries attains striving's reward
fields.meaning: Yield not to the feebleness which says, "this is too difficult to be done"; labour will give the greatness (of mind) which is necessary (to do it)

fields.couplet: In doing work don't break and shirk The world will quit who quits his work
fields.meaning: Take care not to give up exertion in the midst of a work; the world will abandon those who abandon their unfinished work

fields.couplet: On excellence of industry Depends magnanimous bounty
fields.meaning: The lustre of munificence will dwell only with the dignity of laboriousness or efforts

fields.couplet: Bounty of man who never strives Like sword in eunuch's hand it fails
fields.meaning: The liberality of him, who does not labour, will fail, like the manliness of a hermaphrodite, who has a sword in its hand

fields.couplet: Work who likes and not pleasure  Wipes grief of friends, pillar secure
fields.meaning: He who desires not pleasure, but desires labour, will be a pillar to sustain his relations, wiping away their sorrows

fields.couplet: Industry adds prosperity Indolence brings but poverty
fields.meaning: Labour will produce wealth; idleness will bring poverty

fields.couplet: Illuck abides with sloth they say *Laxmi's gifts with labourers stay *Laxmi the Goddes of wealth and prosperity
fields.meaning: They say that the black Mudevi (the goddess of adversity) dwells with laziness, and the Latchmi (the goddess of prosperity) dwells with the labour of the industrious

fields.couplet: Misfortune is disgrace to none The shame is nothing learnt or done
fields.meaning: Adverse fate is no disgrace to any one; to be without exertion and without knowing what should be known, is disgrace

fields.couplet: Though fate is against fulfilment Hard labour has ready payment
fields.meaning: Although it be said that, through fate, it cannot be attained, yet labour, with bodily exertion, will yield its reward

fields.couplet: Tireless Toiler's striving hand Shall leave even the fate behind
fields.meaning: They who labour on, without fear and without fainting will see even fate (put) behind their back

fields.couplet: Laugh away troubles; there is No other way to conquer woes
fields.meaning: If troubles come, laugh; there is nothing like that, to press upon and drive away sorrow

fields.couplet: Deluging sorrows come to nought When wise men face them with firm thought
fields.meaning: A flood of troubles will be overcome by the (courageous) thought which the minds of the wise will entertain, even in sorrow

fields.couplet: Grief they face and put to grief Who grieve not grief by mind's relief
fields.meaning: They give sorrow to sorrow, who in sorrow do not suffer sorrow

fields.couplet: Who pulls like bulls patiently on Causes grief to grieve anon
fields.meaning: Troubles will vanish (i.e., will be troubled) before the man who (struggles against difficulties) as a

fields.couplet: Before the brave grief grieves and goes Who dare a host of pressing woes
fields.meaning: The troubles of that man will be troubled (and disappear) who, however thickly they may come upon him, does not abandon (his purpose)

fields.couplet: The wise that never gloat in gain Do not fret in fateful ruin
fields.meaning: Will those men ever cry out in sorrow, "we are destitute" who, (in their prosperity), give not way to (undue desire) to keep their wealth

fields.couplet: The wise worry no more of woes Knowing body's butt of sorrows
fields.meaning: The great will not regard trouble as trouble, knowing that the body is the butt of trouble

fields.couplet: Who seek not joy, deem grief norm By sorrows do not come to harm
fields.meaning: That man never experiences sorrow, who does not seek for pleasure, and who considers distress to be natural (to man)

fields.couplet: In joy to joy who is not bound In grief he grieves not dual round!
fields.meaning: He does not suffer sorrow, in sorrow who does not look for pleasure in pleasure

fields.couplet: His glory is esteemed by foes Who sees weal in wanton woes!
fields.meaning: The elevation, which even his enemies will esteem, will be gained by him, who regards pain as pleasure

fields.couplet: He is minister who chooses Right means, time, mode and rare ventures
fields.meaning: The minister is one who can make an excellent choice of means, time, manner of execution, and the difficult undertaking (itself)

fields.couplet: With these he guards people, -by his Knowledge, firmness and manliness
fields.meaning: The minister is one who in addition to the aforesaid five things excels in the possession of firmness,

fields.couplet: A minister cherishes friends Divides foes and the parted blends
fields.meaning: The minister is one who can effect discord (among foes), maintain the good-will of his friends and restore to friendship those who have seceded (from him)

fields.couplet: A minister must sift reflect Select and say surely one fact
fields.meaning: The minister is one who is able to comprehend (the whole nature of an undertaking), execute it in the best manner possible, and offer assuring advice (in time of necessity)

fields.couplet: Have him for help who virtue knows Right wisdom speaks, ever apt in acts
fields.meaning: He is the best helper (of the king) who understanding the duties, of the latter, is by his special learning, able to tender the fullest advice, and at all times conversant with the best method (of

fields.couplet: Which subtler brain can stand before The keen in brain with learned love?
fields.meaning: What (contrivances) are there so acute as to resist those who possess natural acuteness in addition to learning ?

fields.couplet: Albeit you know to act from books Act after knowing world's outlooks
fields.meaning: Though you are acquainted with the (theoretical) methods (of performing an act), understand the ways of the world and act accordingly

fields.couplet: The man in place must tell the facts Though the ignorant king refutes
fields.meaning: Although the king be utterly ignorant, it is the duty of the minister to give (him) sound advice

fields.couplet: Seventy crores of foes are better Than a minister with mind bitter
fields.meaning: Far better are seventy crores of enemies (for a king) than a minister at his side who intends (his) ruin

fields.couplet: The unresolved, though well designed To fulfil an act they have no mind
fields.meaning: Those ministers who are destitute of (executive) ability will fail to carry out their projects, although they may have contrived aright

fields.couplet: The goodness called goodness of speech Is goodness which nothing can reach
fields.meaning: The possession of that goodness which is called the goodness of speech is (even to others) better than any other goodness

fields.couplet: Since gain or ruin speeches bring Guard against the slips of tongue
fields.meaning: Since (both) wealth and evil result from (their) speech, ministers should most carefully guard themselves against faultiness therein

fields.couplet: A speech is speech that holds ears And attracts ev'n those that are averse
fields.meaning: The (minister's) speech is that which seeks (to express) elements as bind his friends (to himself) and is so delivered as to make even his enemies desire (his friendship)

fields.couplet: Weigh thy words and speak; because  No wealth or virtue words surpass
fields.meaning: Understand the qualities (of your hearers) and (then) make your speech; for superior to it, there is neither virtue nor wealth

fields.couplet: Speak out thy world so that no word Can win it and say untoward
fields.meaning: Deliver your speech, after assuring yourself that no counter speech can defeat your own

fields.couplet: Spotless men speak what is sweet And grasp in others what is meet
fields.meaning: It is the opinion of those who are free from defects in diplomacy that the minister should speak so as to make his hearers desire (to hear more) and grasp the meaning of what he hears himself

fields.couplet: No foe defies the speaker clear Flawless, puissant, and free from fear
fields.meaning: It is impossible for any one to conquer him by intrique who possesses power of speech, and is neither faulty nor timid

fields.couplet: The world will quickly carry out The words of counsellors astute
fields.meaning: If there be those who can speak on various subjects in their proper order and in a pleasing manner, the world would readily accept them

fields.couplet: They overspeak who do not seek A few and flawless words to speak
fields.meaning: They will desire to utter many words, who do not know how to speak a few faultless ones

fields.couplet: Who can't express what they have learnt Are bunch of flowers not fragrant
fields.meaning: Those who are unable to set forth their acquirements (before others) are like flowers blossoming in a cluster and yet without fragrance

fields.couplet: Friendship brings gain; but action pure Does every good thing we desire
fields.meaning: The efficacy of support will yield (only) wealth; (but) the efficacy of action will yield all that is desired

fields.couplet: Eschew always acts that do not  Bring good nor glory on their part
fields.meaning: Ministers should at all times avoid acts which, in addition to fame, yield no benefit (for the future)

fields.couplet: Those in the world desire for fame Should shun the deed that dims their name
fields.meaning: Those who say, "we will become (better)" should avoid the performance of acts that would destroy (their fame)

fields.couplet: Though perils press the faultless wise Shun deeds of mean, shameful device
fields.meaning: Those who have infallible judgement though threatened with peril will not do acts which have brought disgrace (on former ministers)

fields.couplet: Do not wrong act and grieve, \"Alas\"  If done, do not repeat it twice
fields.meaning: Let a minister never do acts of which he would have to grieve saying, "what is this I have done"; (but) should he do (them), it were good that he grieved not

fields.couplet: Though she who begot thee hungers Shun acts denounced by ancient seers
fields.meaning: Though a minister may see his mother starve; let him do not act which the wise would (treat with contempt)

fields.couplet: Pinching poverty of the wise Is more than wealth hoarded by Vice
fields.meaning: Far more excellent is the extreme poverty of the wise than wealth obtained by heaping up of sinful

fields.couplet: Those who dare a forbidden deed Suffer troubles though they succeed
fields.meaning: The actions of those, who have not desisted from doing deeds forbidden (by the great), will, even if they succeed, cause them sorrow

fields.couplet: Gains from weeping, weeping go Though lost, from good deeds blessings flow
fields.meaning: All that has been obtained with tears (to the victim) will depart with tears (to himself); but what has been by fair means; though with loss at first, will afterwards yield fruit

fields.couplet: The wealth gathered in guilty ways Is water poured in wet clay vase
fields.meaning: (For a minister) to protect (his king) with wealth obtained by foul means is like preserving a vessel of wet clay by filling it with water

fields.couplet: A powerful mind does powerful act And all the rest are imperfect
fields.meaning: Firmness in action is (simply) one's firmness of mind; all other (abilities) are not of this nature

fields.couplet: Shun failing fuss; fail not purpose These two are maxims of the wise
fields.meaning: Not to perform a ruinous act, and not to be discouraged by the ruinous termination of an act, are the two maxims which, the wise say, from the principles of those who have investigated the subject

fields.couplet: The strong achieve and then display Woe unto work displayed midway
fields.meaning: So to perform an act as to publish it (only) at its termination is (true) manliness; for to announce it beforehand, will cause irremediable sorrow

fields.couplet: Easy it is to tell a fact But hard it is to know and act
fields.meaning: To say (how an act is to be performed) is (indeed) easy for any one; but far difficult it is to do according to what has been said

fields.couplet: Dynamic deeds of a doughty soul Shall win the praise of king and all
fields.meaning: The firmness in action of those who have become great by the excellence (of their counsel) will, by attaining its fulfilment in the person of the king, be esteemed (by all).

fields.couplet: The will-to-do achieves the deed When mind that wills is strong indeed
fields.meaning: If those who have planned (an undertaking) possess firmness (in executing it) they will obtain what they have desired even as they have desired it

fields.couplet: Scorn not the form: for men there are Like linchpin of big rolling car
fields.meaning: Let none be despised for (their) size; (for) the world has those who resemble the linch-pin of the big rolling car

fields.couplet: Waver not; do wakefully  The deed resolved purposefully
fields.meaning: An act that has been firmly resolved on must be as firmly carried out without delay

fields.couplet: Do with firm will though pains beset  The deed that brings delight at last
fields.meaning: Though it should cause increasing sorrow (at the outset), do with firmness the act that yield bliss (in the end)

fields.couplet: The world merits no other strength But strength of will-to-do at length
fields.meaning: The great will not esteem those who esteem not firmness of action, whatever other abilities the latter may possess

fields.couplet: When counsel takes a resolve strong Weak delay of action is wrong
fields.meaning: Consultation ends in forming a resolution (to act); (but) delay in the execution of that resolve is an evil

fields.couplet: Delay such acts as need delay Delay not acts that need display
fields.meaning: Sleep over such (actions) as may be slept over; (but) never over such as may not be slept over

fields.couplet: It's best to act when feasible If not see what is possible
fields.meaning: Whenever it is possible (to overcome your enemy) the act (of fighting) is certainly good; if not, endeavour to employ some more successful method

fields.couplet: Work or foe left unfinished Flare up like fire unextinguished
fields.meaning: When duly considered, the incomplete execution of an undertaking and hostility will grow and destroy one like the (unextinguished) remnant of a fire

fields.couplet: Money and means, time, place and deed Decide these five and then proceed
fields.meaning: Do an act after a due consideration of the (following) five, viz money, means, time, execution and place

fields.couplet: Weigh well the end, hindrance, profit  And then pursue a fitting act
fields.meaning: An act is to be performed after considering the exertion required, the obstacles to be encountered, and the great profit to be gained (on its completion)

fields.couplet: Know first the secret from experts That is the way of fruitful acts
fields.meaning: The method of performance for one who has begun an act is to ascertain the mind of him who knows the secret thereof

fields.couplet: Lure a tusker by a tusker Achieve a deed by deed better
fields.meaning: To make one undertaking the means of accomplishing another (similar to it) is like making one rutting elephant the means of capturing another

fields.couplet: Than doing good to friends it is More urgent to befriend the foes
fields.meaning: One should rather hasten to secure the alliance of the foes (of one's foes) than perform good offices to one's friends

fields.couplet: Small statesmen fearing people's fear Submit to foes superior
fields.meaning: Ministers of small states, afraid of their people being frightened, will yield to and acknowledge their superior foes, if the latter offer them a chance of reconciliation

fields.couplet: Love, noble birth, good courtesy Pleasing kings mark true embassy
fields.meaning: The qualification of an ambassador are affection (for his relations) a fitting birth, and the possession of attributes pleasing to royalty

fields.couplet: Envoys must bear love for their prince Knowledge and learned eloquence
fields.meaning: Love (to his sovereign), knowledge (of his affairs), and a discriminating power of speech (before other sovereigns) are the three sine qua non qualifications of an ambassador

fields.couplet: Savant among savants, he pleads  Before lanced king, triumphant words
fields.meaning: To be powerful in politics among those who are learned (in ethics) is the character of him who speaks

fields.couplet: Who has these three: good form, sense, lore Can act as bold ambassador
fields.meaning: He may go on a mission (to foreign rulers) who has combined in him all these three viz, (natural) sense, an attractive bearing and well-tried learning

fields.couplet: Not harsh, the envoy's winsome ways Does good by pleasant words concise
fields.meaning: He is an ambassador who (in the presence of foreign rulers) speaks briefly, avoids harshness, talks so as to make them smile, and thus brings good (to his own sovereign)

fields.couplet: Learned; fearless, the envoy tends Convincing words which time demands
fields.meaning: He is an ambassador who having studied (politics) talks impressively, is not afraid of angry looks, and knows (to employ) the art suited to the time

fields.couplet: Knowing duty time and place The envoy employs mature phrase
fields.meaning: He is chief (among ambassadors) who understands the proper decorum (before foreign princes), seeks the (proper) occasion, knows the (most suitable) place, and delivers his message after (due)

fields.couplet: The true envoy of three virtues Is pure helpful and bold in views
fields.meaning: The qualifications of him who faithfully delivers his (sovereign's) message are purity, the support (of foreign ministers), and boldness, with truthfulness in addition to the (aforesaid) three

fields.couplet: The envoy who ports the king's message Has flawless words and heart's courage
fields.meaning: He alone is fit to communicate (his sovereign's) reply, who possesses the firmness not to utter even inadvertently what may reflect discredit (on the latter)

fields.couplet: Braving death the bold envoy Assures his king's safety and joy
fields.meaning: He is the ambassador who fearlessly seeks his sovereign's good though it should cost him his life (to deliver his message)

fields.couplet: Move with hostile kings as with fire  Not coming close nor going far
fields.meaning: Thus let them act who dwell beneath of warlike kings the palace-roof

fields.couplet: Crave not for things which kings desire  This brings thee their fruitful favour
fields.meaning: For ministers not to cover the things desired by their kings will through the kings themselves yield them everlasting wealth

fields.couplet: Guard thyself from petty excess Suspected least, there's no redress
fields.meaning: Ministers who would save themselves should avoid (the commission of) serious errors for if the king's suspicion is once roused, no one can remove it

fields.couplet: Whisper not; nor smile exchange Amidst august men's assemblage
fields.meaning: While in the presence of the sovereign, ministers should neither whisper to nor smile at others

fields.couplet: Hear not, ask not the king's secret Hear only when he lets it out
fields.meaning: (When the king is engaged) in secret counsel (with others), ministers should neither over-hear anything whatever nor pry into it with inquisitive questions, but (wait to) listen when it is divulged (by

fields.couplet: Discern his mood and time and tell No dislikes but what king likes well
fields.meaning: Knowing the (king's disposition and seeking the right time, (the minister) should in a pleasing manner suggest things such as are desirable and not disagreeable

fields.couplet: Tell pleasing things; and never tell Even if pressed what is futile
fields.meaning: Ministers should (always) give agreeable advice but on no occasion recommend useless actions, though requested (to do so)

fields.couplet: As young and kinsman do not slight; Look with awe king's light and might
fields.meaning: Ministers should behave in accordance with the (Divine) light in the person of kings and not despise them saying, "He is our junior (in age) and connected with our family!"

fields.couplet: The clear-visioned do nothing base Deeming they have the monarch's grace
fields.meaning: Those whose judgement is firm will not do what is disagreeable (to the sovereign) saying (within

fields.couplet: Worthless acts based on friendship old  Shall spell ruin and woe untold
fields.meaning: The (foolish) claim with which a minister does unbecoming acts because of his (long) familiarity (with the king) will ensure his ruin

fields.couplet: Who reads the mind by look, untold Adorns the changeless sea-girt world
fields.meaning: The minister who by looking (at the king) understands his mind without being told (of it), will be a perpetual ornament to the world which is surrounded by a never-drying sea

fields.couplet: Take him as God who reads the thought Of another man with without a doubt
fields.meaning: He is to be esteemed a god who is able to ascertain without a doubt what is within (one's mind)

fields.couplet: By sign who scans the sign admit At any cost in cabinet
fields.meaning: The king should ever give whatever (is asked) of his belongings and secure him who, by the indications (of his own mind) is able to read those of another

fields.couplet: Untold, he who divines the thought Though same in form is quite apart
fields.meaning: Those who understand one's thoughts without being informed (thereof) and those who do not, may (indeed) resemble one another bodily; still are they different (mentally)

fields.couplet: Among senses what for is eye If thought by thought one can't descry?
fields.meaning: Of what use are the eyes amongst one's members, if they cannot by their own indications dive those of another ?

fields.couplet: What throbs in mind the face reflects Just as mirror nearby objects
fields.meaning: As the mirror reflects what is near so does the face show what is uppermost in the mind

fields.couplet: Than face what is subtler to tell First if the mind feels well or ill
fields.meaning: Is there anything so full of knowledge as the face ? (No) it precedes the mind, whether (the latter is) pleased or vexed

fields.couplet: Just standing in front would suffice For those who read the mind on face
fields.meaning: If the king gets those who by looking into his mind can understand (and remove) what has occurred (to him) it is enough that he stand looking at their face

fields.couplet: Friend or foe the eyes will show To those who changing outlooks know
fields.meaning: If a king gets ministers who can read the movements of the eye, the eyes (of foreign kings) will (themselves) reveal (to him) their hatred or friendship

fields.couplet: The scale of keen discerning minds  Is eye and eye that secrets finds
fields.meaning: The measuring-rod of those (ministers) who say "we are acute" will on inquiry be found to be their (own) eyes and nothing else

fields.couplet: The pure in thought and eloquence  Adapt their words to audience
fields.meaning: Let the pure who know the arrangement of words speak with deliberation after ascertaining (the nature of) the court (then assembled)

fields.couplet: Who know the art of speech shall suit Their chosen words to time in fact
fields.meaning: Let the good who know the uses of words speak with a clear knowledge after ascertaining the time (suited to the court)

fields.couplet: They speak in vain at length who talk Words unversed which ears don't take
fields.meaning: Those who undertake to speak without knowing the (nature of the) court are ignorant of the quality of words as well as devoid of the power (of learning)

fields.couplet: Before the bright be brilliant light Before the muff be mortar white
fields.meaning: Ministers should be lights in the assembly of the enlightned, but assume the pure whiteness of mortar (ignorance) in that of fools

fields.couplet: Modest restraint all good excels Which argues not before elders
fields.meaning: The modesty by which one does not rush forward and speak in (an assembly of) superiors is the best among all (one's) good qualities

fields.couplet: Tongue-slip before the talented wise is like slipping from righteous ways
fields.meaning: (For a minister) to blunder in the presence of those who have acquired a vast store of learning and know (the value thereof) is like a good man stumbling (and falling away) from the path (of virtue)

fields.couplet: The learning of the learned shines Valued by flawless scholar-minds
fields.meaning: The learning of those who have read and understood (much) will shine in the assembly of those who faultlessly examine (the nature of) words

fields.couplet: To address understanding ones Is to water beds of growing grains
fields.meaning: Lecturing to those who have the ability to understand (for themselves) is like watering a bed of plants that are growing (of themselves)

fields.couplet: O ye who speak before the keen Forgetful, address not the mean
fields.meaning: Those who are able to speak good things impressively in an assembly of the good should not even forgetfully speak them in that of the low

fields.couplet: To hostiles who wise words utters Pours ambrosia into gutters
fields.meaning: To utter (a good word) in the assembly of those who are of inferior rank is like dropping nectar on the ground

fields.couplet: The pure fail not in power of words Knowing grand council's moods and modes
fields.meaning: The pure who know the classification of words having first ascertained the nature (of the court) will not (through fear) falter in their speech before the powerful body

fields.couplet: Among scholars he is scholar Who holds scholars with learned lore
fields.meaning: Those who can agreeably set forth their acquirements before the learned will be regarded as the most learned among the learned

fields.couplet: Many brave foes and die in fields The fearless few face wise councils
fields.meaning: Many indeed may (fearlessly) die in the presence of (their) foes; (but) few are those who are fearless in the assembly (of the learned)

fields.couplet: Impress the learned with your lore From greater savants learn still more
fields.meaning: (Ministers) should agreeably set forth their acquirements before the learned and acquire more (knowledge) from their superiors (in learning)

fields.couplet: Grammar and logic learn so that Foes you can boldly retort
fields.meaning: In order to reply fearlessly before a foreign court, (ministers) should learn logic according to the rules (of grammar)
