fields.couplet: To cowards what can sword avail And books to those who councils fail?
fields.meaning: What have they to do with a sword who are not valiant, or they with learning who are afraid of an intelligent assembly ?

fields.couplet: Like eunuch's sword in field, is vain His lore who fears men of brain
fields.meaning: The learning of him who is diffident before an assembly is like the shining sword of an hermaphrodite in the presence of his foes

fields.couplet: Though learned much his lore is dead Who says no good before the good
fields.meaning: Those who cannot agreeably speak good things before a good assembly are indeed unprofitable persons inspite of all their various acquirements

fields.couplet: Who fear to face good assembly Are learned idiots, certainly
fields.meaning: They who, though they have learned and understood, are yet afraid of the assembly of the good, are said to be inferior (even) to the illiterate

fields.couplet: They are breathing dead who dare not Empress before the wise their art
fields.meaning: Those who through fear of the assembly are unable to set forth their learning in an interesting manner, though alive, are yet like the dead

fields.couplet: It's country which has souls of worth Unfailing yields and ample wealth
fields.meaning: A kingdom is that in which (those who carry on) a complete cultivation, virtuous persons, and

fields.couplet: The Land has large luring treasure Where pests are nil and yields are sure
fields.meaning: A kingdom is that which is desire for its immense wealth, and which grows greatly in prosperity, being free from destructive causes

fields.couplet: It's land that bears pressing burdens And pays its tax which king demands
fields.meaning: A kingdom is that which can bear any burden that may be pressed on it (from adjoining kingdoms) and (yet) pay the full tribute to its sovereign

fields.couplet: It is country which is free from Fierce famine, plague and foemen's harm
fields.meaning: A kingdom is that which continues to be free from excessive starvation, irremediable epidemics, and destructive foes

fields.couplet: Sects and ruinous foes are nil No traitors in a land tranquil
fields.meaning: A kingdom is that which is without various (irregular) associations, destructive internal enemies, and murderous savages who (sometimes) harass the sovereign

fields.couplet: The land of lands no ruin knows Even in grief its wealth yet grows
fields.meaning: The learned say that the best kingdom is that which knows no evil (from its foes), and, if injured (at all), suffers no diminution in its fruitfulness

fields.couplet: Waters up and down, hills and streams With strong forts as limbs country beams
fields.meaning: The constituents of a kingdom are the two waters (from above and below), well situated hills and an undestructible fort

fields.couplet: Rich yield, delight, defence and wealth Are jewels of lands with blooming health
fields.meaning: Freedom from epidemics, wealth, produce, happiness and protection (to subjects); these five, the learned, say, are the ornaments of a kingdom

fields.couplet: A land is land which yields unsought Needing hard work the land is nought
fields.meaning: The learned say that those are kingdom whose wealth is not laboured for, and those not, whose wealth is only obtained through labour

fields.couplet: Though a land has thus every thing It is worthless without a king
fields.meaning: Although in possession of all the above mentioned excellences, these are indeed of no use to a country, in the absence of harmony between the sovereign and the sujects

fields.couplet: The fort is vital for offence Who fear the foes has its defence
fields.meaning: A fort is an object of importance to those who march (against their foes) as well as to those who through fear (of pursuers) would seek it for shelter

fields.couplet: A crystal fount, a space a mount Thick woods form a fort paramount
fields.meaning: A fort is that which has everlasting water, plains, mountains and cool shady forests

fields.couplet: An ideal fort's so says science: High, broad, strong and hard for access
fields.meaning: The learned say that a fortress is an enclosure having these four (qualities) viz, height, breadth, strength and inaccessibility

fields.couplet: Ample in space, easy to hold The fort foils enemies bold
fields.meaning: A fort is that which has an extensive space within, but only small places to be guarded, and such as can destroy the courage of besieging foes

fields.couplet: Impregnable with stores of food Cosy to live-That fort is good
fields.meaning: A fort is that which cannot be captured, which abounds in suitable provisions, and affords a position of easy defence to its inmates

fields.couplet: A fort is full of stores and arms And brave heroes to meet alarms
fields.meaning: A fort is that which has all (needful) things, and excellent heroes that can help it against destruction (by foes)

fields.couplet: Besieging foes a fort withstands Darts and mines of treacherous hands
fields.meaning: A fort is that which cannot be captured by blockading, assaulting, or undermining it

fields.couplet: A fort holds itself and defies The attacks of encircling foes
fields.meaning: That is a fort whose inmates are able to overcome without losing their ground, even abler men who have besieged it

fields.couplet: A fort it is that fells the foes And gains by deeds a name glorious
fields.meaning: A fort is that which derives excellence from the stratagems made (by its inmates) to defeat their enemies in the battlefield

fields.couplet: But a fort however grand Is nil if heroes do not stand
fields.meaning: Although a fort may possess all (the above-said) excellence, it is, as it were without these, if its inmates possess not the excellence of action

fields.couplet: Naught exists that can, save wealth Make the worthless as men of worth
fields.meaning: Besides wealth there is nothing that can change people of no importance into those of (some) importance

fields.couplet: The have-nothing poor all despise The men of wealth all raise and praise
fields.meaning: All despise the poor; (but) all praise the rich

fields.couplet: Waneless wealth is light that goes To every land and gloom removes
fields.meaning: The imperishable light of wealth goes into regions desired (by its owner) and destroys the darkness (of enmity therein)

fields.couplet: The blameless wealth from fairest means Brings good virtue and also bliss
fields.meaning: The wealth acquired with a knowledge of the proper means and without foul practices will yield virtue and happiness

fields.couplet: Riches devoid of love and grace Off with it; it is disgrace!
fields.meaning: (Kings) should rather avoid than seek the accumulation of wealth which does not flow in with mercy and love

fields.couplet: Escheats, derelicts; spoils of war Taxes duties are king's treasure
fields.meaning: The spoils of slaughtered foes; these are the royal revenues

fields.couplet: Grace the child of love is nourished By the wet-nurse of wealth cherished
fields.meaning: The child mercy which is borne by love grows under the care of the rich nurse of wealth

fields.couplet: Treasures in hand fulfil all things Like hill-tuskers the wars of kings
fields.meaning: An undertaking of one who has wealth in one's hands is like viewing an elephant-fight from a hill-top

fields.couplet: Make wealth; there is no sharper steel The insolence of foes to quell
fields.meaning: Accumulate wealth; it will destroy the arrogance of (your) foes; there is no weapon sharper than it

fields.couplet: They have joy and virtue at hand Who acquire treasures abundant
fields.meaning: To those who have honestly acquired an abundance of riches, the other two, (virtue and pleasure) are things easy (of acquisition)

fields.couplet: The daring well-armed winning force Is king's treasure and main resource
fields.meaning: The army which is complete in (its) parts and conquers without fear of wounds is the chief wealth of the king

fields.couplet: Through shots and wounds brave heroes hold Quailing not in fall, the field
fields.meaning: Ancient army can alone have the valour which makes it stand by its king at the time of defeat, fearless of wounds and unmindful of its reduced strength

fields.couplet: Sea-like ratfoes roar What if? They perish at a cobra's whiff
fields.meaning: What if (a host of) hostile rats roar like the sea ? They will perish at the mere breath of the cobra

fields.couplet: The army guards its genial flame Not crushed, routed nor marred in name
fields.meaning: That indeed is an army which has stood firm of old without suffering destruction or deserting (to the enemy)

fields.couplet: The real army with rallied force Resists even Death-God fierce
fields.meaning: That indeed is an army which is capable of offering a united resistance, even if Yama advances against it with fury

fields.couplet: Manly army has merits four:- Stately-march, faith, honour, valour
fields.meaning: Valour, honour, following in the excellent-footsteps (of its predecessors) and trust-worthiness; these four alone constitute the safeguard of an army

fields.couplet: Army sets on to face to foes Knowing how the trend of war goes
fields.meaning: That is an army which knowing the art of warding off an impending struggle, can bear against the dust-van (of a hostile force)

fields.couplet: Army gains force by grand array Lacking in stay or dash in fray
fields.meaning: Though destitute of courage to fight and strength (to endure), an army may yet gain renown by the splendour of its appearance

fields.couplet: Army shall win if it is free From weakness, aversion, poverty
fields.meaning: An army can triumph (over its foes) if it is free from diminution; irremediable aversion and poverty

fields.couplet: With troops in large numbers on rolls Army can't march missing gen'rals
fields.meaning: Though an army may contain a large number of permanent soldiers, it cannot last if it has no generals

fields.couplet: Stand not before my chief, O foes! Many who stood, in stones repose
fields.meaning: O my foes, stand not before my leader; (for) many are those who did so but afterwards stood (in the shape of) statues

fields.couplet: To lift a lance that missed a tusker Is prouder than shaft that hit a hare
fields.meaning: It is more pleasant to hold the dart that has missed an elephant than that which has hit hare in the forest

fields.couplet: Valour is fight with fierce courage Mercy to the fallen is its edge
fields.meaning: The learned say that fierceness (incontest with a foe) is indeed great valour; but to become a benefactor in case of accident (to a foe) is the extreme (limit) of that valour

fields.couplet: At the tusker he flings his lance One in body smiles another chance
fields.meaning: The hero who after casting the lance in his hand on an elephant, comes (in search of another) will pluck the one (that sticks) in his body and laugh (exultingly)

fields.couplet: When lances dart if heroes wink \"It is a rout\" the world will think
fields.meaning: Is it not a defeat to the valiant to wink and destroy their ferocious look when a lance in cast at them (by their foe) ?

fields.couplet: The brave shall deem the days as vain Which did not battle-wounds sustain
fields.meaning: The hero will reckon among wasted days all those on which he had not received severe wounds

fields.couplet: Their anklets aloud jingle their name Who sacrifice their life for fame
fields.meaning: The fastening of ankle-ring by those who disire a world-wide renown and not (the safety of) their lives is like adorning (themselves)

fields.couplet: The king may chide, they pursue strife; They fear loss of glory; not life
fields.meaning: The heroes who are not afraid of losing their life in a contest will not cool their ardour, even if the king prohibits (their fighting)

fields.couplet: Who will blame the heroes that lose Their lives in war to keep their vows?
fields.meaning: Who would reproach with failure those who seal their oath with their death ?

fields.couplet: Such a death shall be prayed for Which draws the the tears of the ruler
fields.meaning: If (heroes) can so die as to fill with tears the eyes of their rulers, such a death deserves to be obtained even by begging

fields.couplet: Like friendship what's so hard to gain? That guards one against acts villain?
fields.meaning: What so sure defence 'gainst all that foe can do?

fields.couplet: Good friendship shines like waxing moon, The bad withers like waning moon
fields.meaning: The friendship of the wise waxes like the new moon; (but) that of fools wanes like the full moon

fields.couplet: Like taste in books good friendship grows The more one moves the more he knows
fields.meaning: Like learning, the friendship of the noble, the more it is cultivated, the more delightful does it become

fields.couplet: Not to laugh is friendship made But to hit when faults exceed
fields.meaning: Friendship is to be practised not for the purpose of laughing but for that of being beforehand in giving one another sharp rebukes in case of transgression

fields.couplet: No close living nor clasping grip Friendship's feeling heart's fellowship
fields.meaning: Living together and holding frequent intercourse are not necessary (for friendship); (mutual) understanding can alone create a claim for it

fields.couplet: Friendship is not more smile on face It is the smiling heart's embrace
fields.meaning: The love that dwells (merely in the smiles of the face is not friendship; (but) that which dwells deep in the smiles of the heart is true friendship

fields.couplet: From ruin friendship saves and shares The load of pain and right path shows
fields.meaning: (True) friendship turns aside from evil (ways) makes (him) walk in the (good) way, and, in case of loss if shares his sorrow (with him)

fields.couplet: Friendship hastens help in mishaps Like hands picking up dress that slips
fields.meaning: (True) friendship hastens to the rescue of the afflicted (as readily) as the hand of one whose garment is loosened (before an assembly)

fields.couplet: Friendship is enthroned on the strength That always helps with utmost warmth
fields.meaning: Friendship may be said to be on its throne when it possesses the power of supporting one at all times and under all circumstances, (in the practice or virtue and wealth)

fields.couplet: \"Such we are and such they are!\" Ev'n this boast will friendship mar
fields.meaning: Though friends may praise one another saying, "He is so intimate with us, and we so much (with him)"; (still) such friendship will appear mean

fields.couplet: Than testless friendship nought is worse For contacts formed will scarcely cease
fields.meaning: As those who are of a friendly nature will not forsake (a friend) after once loving (him), there is no evil so great as contracting a friendship without due inquiry

fields.couplet: Friendship made without frequent test Shall end in grief and death at last
fields.meaning: The friendship contracted by him who has not made repeated inquiry will in the end grieve (him) to death

fields.couplet: Temper, descent, defects and kins Trace well and take companions
fields.meaning: Make friendship (with one) after ascertaining (his) character, birth, defects and the whole of one's relations

fields.couplet: Take as good friend at any price The nobly born who shun disgrace
fields.meaning: The friendship of one who belongs to a (good) family and is afraid of (being charged with) guilt, is worth even purchasing

fields.couplet: Who make you weep and chide wrong trends And lead you right are worthy friends
fields.meaning: You should examine and secure the friendship of those who can speak so as to make you weep over a crime (before its commission) or rebuke you severely (after you have done it) and are able to teach

fields.couplet: Is there a test like misfortune A rod to measure out kinsmen?
fields.meaning: Even in ruin there is some good; (for) it is a rod by which one may measure fully (the affection of one's) relations

fields.couplet: Keep off contacts with fools; that is The greatest gain so say the wise
fields.meaning: It is indead a gain for one to renounce the friendship of fools

fields.couplet: Off with thoughts that depress the heart Off with friends that in woe depart
fields.meaning: Do not think of things that discourage your mind, nor contract friendship with those who would forsake you in adversity

fields.couplet: Friends who betray at ruin's brink Burn our mind ev'n at death to think
fields.meaning: The very thought of the friendship of those who have deserted one at the approach of adversity will burn one's mind at the time of death

fields.couplet: The blameless ones as friends embarace; Give something and give up the base
fields.meaning: Continue to enjoy the friendship of the pure; (but) renounce even with a gift, the friendship of those who do not agree (with the world)

fields.couplet: That friendship is good amity Which restrains not one's liberty
fields.meaning: Imtimate friendship is that which cannot in the least be injured by (things done through the) right (of longstanding intimacy)

fields.couplet: Friendship's heart is freedom close; Wise men's duty is such to please
fields.meaning: The constituents of friendship are (things done through) the right of intimacy; to be pleased with such a right is the duty of the wise

fields.couplet: Of long friendship what is the use Righteous freedom if men refuse?
fields.meaning: Of what avail is long-standing friendship, if friends do not admit as their own actions done through the right of intimacy ?

fields.couplet: Things done unasked by loving friends Please the wise as familiar trends!
fields.meaning: If friends, through the right of friendship, do (anything) without being asked, the wise will be pleased with them on account of its desirability

fields.couplet: Offence of friends feel it easy As folloy or close intimacy
fields.meaning: If friends should perform what is painful, understand that it is owing not only to ignorance, but also to the strong claims of intimacy

fields.couplet: They forsake not but continue In friendship's bounds though loss ensue
fields.meaning: Those who stand within the limits (of true friendship) will not even in adversity give up the intimacy of long-standing friends

fields.couplet: Comrades established in firm love Though ruin comes waive not their vow
fields.meaning: Those who have (long) stood in the path of affection will not give it up even if their friends cause (them) their ruin

fields.couplet: Fast friends who list not tales of ill Though wronged they say \"that day is well\"
fields.meaning: To those who understand that by which they should not listen to (tales about) the faults of their friends, that is a (profitable) day on which the latter may commit a fault

fields.couplet: To love such friends the world desires Whose friendship has unbroken ties
fields.meaning: They will be loved by the world, who have not forsaken the friendship of those with whom they have kept up an unbroken long-standing intimacy

fields.couplet: Even foes love for better ends Those who leave not long-standing friends
fields.meaning: Even enemies will love those who have never changed in their affection to their long-standingfriends

fields.couplet: Swallowing love of soulless men Had better wane than wax anon
fields.meaning: The decrease of friendship with those who look as if they would eat you up (through excess of love) while they are really destitute of goodness is far better than its increase

fields.couplet: Who fawn in wealth and fail in dearth Gain or lose; such friends have no worth
fields.meaning: Of what avail is it to get or lose the friendship of those who love when there is gain and leave when there is none ?

fields.couplet: Cunning friends who calculate  Are like thieves and whores wicked
fields.meaning: Friendship who calculate the profits (of their friendship), prostitutes who are bent on obtaining their gains, and thieves are (all) of the same character

fields.couplet: Better be alone than trust in those That throw in field like faithless horse
fields.meaning: Solitude is more to be desired than the society of those who resemble the untrained horses which throw down (their riders) in the fields of battle

fields.couplet: Friends low and mean that give no help- Leave them is better than to keep
fields.meaning: It is far better to avoid that to contract the evil friendship of the base who cannot protect (their friends) even when appointed to do so

fields.couplet: Million times the wise man's hate Is better than a fool intimate
fields.meaning: The hatred of the wise is ten-million times more profitable than the excessive intimacy of the fool

fields.couplet: Ten-fold crore you gain from foes Than from friends who are vain laughers
fields.meaning: What comes from enemies is a hundred million times more profitable than what comes from the friendship of those who cause only laughter

fields.couplet: Without a word those friends eschew Who spoil deeds which they can do
fields.meaning: Gradually abandon without revealing (beforehand) the friendship of those who pretend inability to carry out what they (really) could do

fields.couplet: Even in dreams the tie is bad With those whose deed is far from word
fields.meaning: The friendship of those whose actions do not agree with their words will distress (one) even in (one's) dreams

fields.couplet: Keep aloof from those that smile At home and in public revile
fields.meaning: Avoid even the least approach to a contraction of friendship with those who would love you in private but ridicule you in public

fields.couplet: The friendship by an enemy shown Is anvil in time, to strike you down
fields.meaning: The friendship of those who behave like friends without inward affection is a weapon that may be thrown when a favourable opportunity presents itself

fields.couplet: Who pretend kinship but are not Their friendship's fickle like woman's heart
fields.meaning: The friendship of those who seem to be friends while they are not, will change like the love of women

fields.couplet: They may be vast in good studies But heartfelt-love is hard for foes
fields.meaning: Though (one's) enemies may have mastered many good books, it will be impossible for them to become truly loving at heart

fields.couplet: Fear foes whose face has winning smiles Whose heart is full of cunning guiles
fields.meaning: One should fear the deceitful who smile sweetly with their face but never love with their heart

fields.couplet: Do not trust in what they tell Whose mind with your mind goes ill
fields.meaning: In nothing whatever is it proper to rely on the words of those who do not love with their heart

fields.couplet: The words of foes is quickly seen Though they speak like friends in fine
fields.meaning: Though (one's) foes may utter good things as though they were friends, once will at once understand (their evil, import)

fields.couplet: Trust not the humble words of foes Danger darts from bending bows
fields.meaning: Since the bending of the bow bespeaks evil, one should not accept (as good) the humiliating speeches of one's foes

fields.couplet: Adoring hands of foes hide arms Their sobbing tears have lurking harms
fields.meaning: A weapon may be hid in the very hands with which (one's) foes adore (him) (and) the tears they shed are of the same nature

fields.couplet: In open who praise, at heart despise Cajole and crush them in friendly guise
fields.meaning: It is the duty of kings to affect great love but make it die (inwardly); as regard those foes who shew them great friendship but despise them (in their heart)

fields.couplet: When foes, in time, play friendship's part Feign love on face but not in heart
fields.meaning: When one's foes begin to affect friendship, one should love them with one's looks, and, cherishing no love in the heart, give up (even the former)

fields.couplet: This is folly's prominent vein To favour loss and forego gain
fields.meaning: Folly is one (of the chief defects); it is that which (makes one) incur loss and forego gain

fields.couplet: Folly of follies is to lead A lewd and lawless life so bad
fields.meaning: The greatest folly is that which leads one to take delight in doing what is forbidden

fields.couplet: Shameless, aimless, callous, listless Such are the marks of foolishness
fields.meaning: Shamelessness indifference (to what must be sought after), harshness, and aversion for everything (that ought to be desired) are the qualities of the fool

fields.couplet: No fool equals the fool who learns Knows, teaches, but self-control spurns
fields.meaning: There are no greater fools than he who, though he has read and understood (a great deal) and even taught it to others, does not walk according to his own teaching

fields.couplet: The fool suffers seven fold hells In single birth of hellish ills
fields.meaning: A fool can procure in a single birth a hell into which he may enter and suffer through all the seven births

fields.couplet: A know-nothing fool daring a deed Not only fails but feels fettered
fields.meaning: If the fool, who knows not how to act undertakes a work, he will (certainly) fail (But) is it all ? He will even adorn himself with fetters

fields.couplet: Strangers feast and kinsmen fast  When fools mishandle fortunes vast
fields.meaning: If a fool happens to get an immense fortune, his neighbours will enjoy it while his relations starve

fields.couplet: Fools possessing something on hand Like dazed and drunken stupids stand
fields.meaning: A fool happening to possess something is like the intoxication of one who is (already) giddy

fields.couplet: Friendship with fools is highly sweet For without a groan we part
fields.meaning: The friendship between fools is exceedingly delightful (to each other): for at parting there will be

fields.couplet: Entrance of fools where Savants meet Looks like couch trod by unclean feet
fields.meaning: The appearance of a fool in an assembly of the learned is like placing (one's) unwashed feet on a bed

fields.couplet: Want of wisdom is want of wants Want of aught else the world nev'r counts
fields.meaning: The want of wisdom is the greatest of all wants; but that of wealth the world will not regard as such

fields.couplet: When fool bestows with glee a gift It comes but by getter's merit
fields.meaning: (The cause of) a fool cheerfully giving (something) is nothing else but the receiver's merit (in a former birth)

fields.couplet: The self-torments of fools exceed Ev'n tortures of their foes indeed
fields.meaning: The suffering that fools inflict upon themselves is hardly possible even to foes

fields.couplet: Stupidity is vanity That cries \"We have sagacity\"
fields.meaning: What is called want of wisdom is the vanity which says, "We are wise"

fields.couplet: Feigning knowledge that one has not Leads to doubt ev'n that he has got
fields.meaning: Fools pretending to know what has not been read (by them) will rouse suspicion even as to what they have thoroughly mastered

fields.couplet: Fools their nakedness conceal And yet their glaring faults reveal
fields.meaning: Even to cover one's nakedness would be folly, if (one's) faults were not covered (by forsaking them)

fields.couplet: The fool that slights sacred counsels Upon himself great harm entails
fields.meaning: The fool who neglects precious counsel does, of his own accord, a great injury to himself

fields.couplet: He listens not nor himself knows Plague is his life until it goes
fields.meaning: The fool will not perform (his duties) even when advised nor ascertain them himself; such a soul is a

fields.couplet: Sans Self-sight in vain one opens Sight To the blind who bet their sight as right
fields.meaning: One who would teach a fool will (simply) betray his folly; and the fool would (still) think himself "wise in his own conceit"

fields.couplet: To people's \"Yes\" who proffer \"No\" Deemed as ghouls on earth they go
fields.meaning: He who denies the existence of what the world believes in will be regarded as a demon on earth

fields.couplet: Hatred is a plague that divides And rouses illwill on all sides
fields.meaning: The disease which fosters the evil of disunion among all creatures is termed hatred by the wise

fields.couplet: Rouse not hatred and confusion Though foes provoke disunion
fields.meaning: Though disagreeable things may be done from (a feeling of) disunion, it is far better that nothing painful be done from (that of) hatred

fields.couplet: Shun the plague of enmity And win everlasting glory
fields.meaning: To rid one-self of the distressing dtsease of hatred will bestow (on one) a never-decreasing imperishable fame

fields.couplet: Hate-the woe of woes destroy; Then joy of joys you can enjoy
fields.meaning: If hatred which is the greatest misery is destroyed, it will yield the greatest delight

fields.couplet: Who can overcome them in glory That are free from enmity?
fields.meaning: Who indeed would think of conquering those who naturally shrink back from hatred ?

fields.couplet: His fall and ruin are quite near Who holds enmity sweet and dear
fields.meaning: Failure and ruin are not far from him who says it is sweet to excel in hatred

fields.couplet: They cannot see the supreme Truth Who hate and injure without ruth
fields.meaning: Who only know to work men woe, fulfilled of enmity

fields.couplet: To turn from enmity is gain Fomenting it brings fast ruin
fields.meaning: Shrinking back from hatred will yield wealth; indulging in its increase will hasten ruin

fields.couplet: Fortune favours when hate recedes Hatred exceeding ruin breeds
fields.meaning: At the approach of wealth one will not think of hatred (but) to secure one's ruin, one will look to its increase

fields.couplet: All evils come from enmity All goodness flow from amity
fields.meaning: All calamities are caused by hatred; but by the delight (of friendship) is caused the great wealth of good virtues

fields.couplet: Turn from strife with foes too strong With the feeble for battle long
fields.meaning: Avoid offering resistance to the strong; (but) never fail to cherish enmity towards the weak

fields.couplet: Loveless, aidless, powerless king Can he withstand an enemy strong?
fields.meaning: How can he who is unloving, destitute of powerful aids, and himself without strength overcome the might of his foe ?

fields.couplet: Unskilled, timid, miser, misfit He is easy for foes to hit
fields.meaning: In the estimation of foes miserably weak is he, who is timid, ignorant, unsociable and niggardly

fields.couplet: The wrathful restive man is prey To any, anywhere any day
fields.meaning: He who neither refrains from anger nor keeps his secrets will at all times and in all places be easily conquered by all

fields.couplet: Crooked, cruel, tactless and base Any foe can fell him with ease
fields.meaning: (A) pleasing (object) to his foes is he who reads not moral works, does nothing that is enjoined by them cares not for reproach and is not possessed of good qualities

fields.couplet: Blind in rage and mad in lust To have his hatred is but just
fields.meaning: Highly to be desired is the hatred of him whose anger is blind, and whose lust increases beyond measure

fields.couplet: Pay and buy his enmity Who muddles chance with oddity
fields.meaning: It is indeed necessary to obtain even by purchase the hatred of him who having begun (a work) does what is not conductive (to its accomplishment)

fields.couplet: With no virtue but full of vice He loses friends and delights foes
fields.meaning: He will become friendless who is without (any good) qualities and whose faults are many; (such a character) is a help to (his) foes

fields.couplet: The joy of heroes knows no bounds When timid fools are opponents
fields.meaning: There will be no end of lofty delights to the victorious, if their foes are (both) ignorant and timid

fields.couplet: Glory's light he will not gain Who fails to fight a fool and win
fields.meaning: The light (of fame) will never be gained by him who gains not the trifling reputation of having fought an unlearned (foe)

fields.couplet: Let not one even as a sport The ill-natured enmity court
fields.meaning: The evil of hatred is not of a nature to be desired by one even in sport

fields.couplet: Incur the hate of bow-ploughers But not the hate of word-ploughers
fields.meaning: Though you may incur the hatred of warriors whose ploughs are bows, incur not that of ministers whose ploughs are words

fields.couplet: Forlorn, who rouses many foes The worst insanity betrays
fields.meaning: He who being alone, incurs the hatred of many is more infatuated than even mad men

fields.couplet: This world goes safely in his grace Whose heart makes friends even of foes
fields.meaning: Whose worthy rule can change his foes to friends

fields.couplet: Alone, if two foes you oppose Make one of them your ally close
fields.meaning: He who is alone and helpless while his foes are two should secure one of them as an agreeable help (to himself)

fields.couplet: Trust or distrust; during distress Keep aloof; don't mix with foes
fields.meaning: Though (one's foe is) aware or not of one's misfortune one should act so as neither to join nor separate (from him)

fields.couplet: To those who know not, tell not your pain Nor your weakness to foes explain
fields.meaning: Relate not your suffering even to friends who are ignorant of it, nor refer to your weakness in the presence of your foes

fields.couplet: Know how and act and defend well The pride of enemies shall fall
fields.meaning: The joy of one's foes will be destroyed if one guards oneself by knowing the way (of acting) and securing assistance

fields.couplet: Cut off thorn-trees when young they are; Grown hard, they cut your hands beware
fields.meaning: A thorny tree should be felled while young, (for) when it is grown it will destroy the hand of the feller

fields.couplet: To breathe on earth they are not fit Defying foes who don't defeat
fields.meaning: Those who do not destroy the pride of those who hate (them) will certainly not exist even to breathe

fields.couplet: Traitorous kinsmen will make you sad As water and shade do harm when bad
fields.meaning: Shade and water are not pleasant, (if) they cause disease; so are the qualities of (one's) relations not agreeable, (if) they cause pain

fields.couplet: You need not sword-like kinsmen fear Fear foes who feign as kinsmen dear
fields.meaning: Fear not foes (who say they would cut) like a sword; (but) fear the friendship of foes (who seemingly

fields.couplet: The secret foe in days evil Will cut you, beware, like potters' steel
fields.meaning: Fear internal enmity and guard yourself; (if not) it will destroy (you) in an evil hour, as surely as the tool which cuts the potter's clay

fields.couplet: The evil-minded foe within Foments trouble, spoils kinsmen!
fields.meaning: The secret enmity of a person whose mind in unreformed will lead to many evils causing disaffection among (one's) relations

fields.couplet: A traitor among kinsmen will Bring life-endangering evil
fields.meaning: If there appears internal hatred in a (king's) family; it will lead to many a fatal crime

fields.couplet: Discord in kings' circle entails Life-destroying deadly evils
fields.meaning: If hatred arises among (one's) own people, it will be hardly possible (for one) to escape death

fields.couplet: A house hiding hostiles in core Just seems on like the lid in jar
fields.meaning: Never indeed will a family subject to internal hatred unite (really) though it may present an apparent union like that of a casket and its lid

fields.couplet: By secret spite the house wears out Like gold crumbling by file's contact
fields.meaning: A family subject to internal hatred will wear out and lose its strength like iron that has been filed away

fields.couplet: Ruin lurks in enmity As slit in sesame though it be
fields.meaning: Although internal hatred be as small as the fragment of the sesamum (seed), still does destruction dwell in it

fields.couplet: Dwell with traitors that hate in heart Is dwelling with snake in selfsame hut
fields.meaning: Living with those who do not agree (with one) is like dwelling with a cobra (in the same) hut

fields.couplet: Not to spite the mighty ones Safest safeguard to living brings
fields.meaning: Not to disregard the power of those who can carry out (their wishes) is more important than all the watchfulness of those who guard (themselves against evil)

fields.couplet: To walk unmindful of the great Shall great troubles ceaseless create
fields.meaning: To behave without respect for the great (rulers) will make them do (us) irremediable evils

fields.couplet: Heed not and do, if ruin you want Offence against the mighty great
fields.meaning: If a person desires ruin, let him not listen to the righteous dictates of law, but commit crimes against those who are able to slay (other sovereigns)

fields.couplet: The weak who insult men of might Death with their own hands invite
fields.meaning: The weak doing evil to the strong is like beckoning Yama to come (and destroy them)

fields.couplet: Where can they go and thrive where Pursued by powerful monarch's ire?
fields.meaning: Those who have incurred the wrath of a cruel and mighty potentate will not prosper wherever they may go

fields.couplet: One can escape in fire caught The great who offends escapes not
fields.meaning: Though burnt by a fire (from a forest), one may perhaps live; (but) never will he live who has shown disrespect to the great (devotees)

fields.couplet: If holy mighty sages frown Stately gifts and stores who can own?
fields.meaning: If a king incurs the wrath of the righteous great, what will become of his government with its splendid auxiliaries and (all) its untold wealth ?

fields.couplet: When hill-like sages are held small The firm on earth lose home and all
fields.meaning: If (the) hill-like (devotees) resolve on destruction, those who seemed to be everlasting will be destroyed root and branch from the earth

fields.couplet: Before the holy sage's rage Ev'n Indra's empire meets damage
fields.meaning: Kings even fall from high estate and perish in the flame

fields.couplet: Even mighty aided men shall quail If the enraged holy seers will
fields.meaning: Though in possession of numerous auxiliaries, they will perish who are-exposed to the wrath of the noble whose penance is boundless

fields.couplet: Who dote on wives lose mighty gain That lust, dynamic men disdain
fields.meaning: Those who lust after their wives will not attain the excellence of virtue; and it is just this that is not desired by those who are bent on acquiring wealth

fields.couplet: Who dotes, unmanly, on his dame His wealth to him and all is shame
fields.meaning: The wealth of him who, regardless (of his manliness), devotes himself to his wife's feminine nature will cause great shame (to ali men) and to himself;

fields.couplet: Who's servile to his wife always Shy he feels before the wise
fields.meaning: The frailty that stoops to a wife will always make (her husband) feel ashamed among the good

fields.couplet: Fearing his wife salvationless The weaklings' action has no grace
fields.meaning: The undertaking of one, who fears his wife and is therefore destitute of (bliss), will never be applauded

fields.couplet: Who fears his wife fears always Good to do to the good and wise
fields.meaning: He that fears his wife will always be afraid of doing good deeds (even) to the good

fields.couplet: Who fear douce arms of their wives Look petty even with god-like lives
fields.meaning: They that fear the bamboo-like shoulders of their wives will be destitute of manliness though they may flourish like the Gods

fields.couplet: Esteemed more is women bashful Than man servile unto her will
fields.meaning: Even shame faced womanhood is more to be esteemed than the shameless manhood that performs

fields.couplet: By fair-browed wives who are governed Help no friends nor goodness tend
fields.meaning: Those who yield to the wishes of their wives will neither relieve the wants of (their) friends nor perform virtuous deeds

fields.couplet: No virtue riches nor joy is seen In those who submit to women
fields.meaning: From those who obey the commands of their wives are to be expected neither deeds of virtue, nor those of wealth nor (even) those of pleasure

fields.couplet: Thinkers strong and broad of heart By folly on fair sex do not dote
fields.meaning: The foolishness that results from devotion to a wife will never be found in those who possess a reflecting mind and a prosperity (flowing) therefrom

fields.couplet: For gold, not love their tongue cajoles Men are ruined by bangled belles
fields.meaning: The sweet words of elegant braceleted (prostitutes) who desire (a man) not from affection but from avarice, will cause sorrow

fields.couplet: Avoid ill-natured whores who feign Love only for their selfish gain
fields.meaning: One must ascertain the character of the ill-natured women who after ascertaining the wealth (of a man) speak (as if they were) good natured-ones, and avoid intercourse (with them)

fields.couplet: The false embrace of whores is like That of a damned corpse in the dark
fields.meaning: The false embraces of wealth-loving women are like (hired men) embracing a strange corpse in a dark room

fields.couplet: The wise who seek the wealth of grace Look not for harlots' low embrace
fields.meaning: The wise who seek the wealth of grace will not desire the base favours of those who regard wealth (and not pleasure) as (their) riches

fields.couplet: The lofty wise will never covet The open charms of a vile harlot
fields.meaning: Those whose knowledge is made excellent by their (natural) sense will not covet the trffling delights

fields.couplet: Those who guard their worthy fame Shun the wanton's vaunting charm
fields.meaning: Those who would spread (the fame of) their own goodness will not desire the shoulders of those,who rejoice in their accomplishments and bestow their despicable favours (on all who pay)

fields.couplet: Hollow hearts alone desire The arms of whores with hearts elsewere
fields.meaning: Those who are destitute of a perfectly (reformed) mind will covet the shoulders of those who embrace (them) while their hearts covet other things

fields.couplet: Senseless fools are lured away By arms of sirens who lead astray
fields.meaning: The wise say that to such as are destitute of discerning sense the embraces of faithless women are (as ruinous as those of) the celestail female

fields.couplet: The soft jewelled arms of whores are hell Into which the degraded fall
fields.meaning: The delicate shoulders of prostitutes with excellent jewels are a hell into which are plunged the ignorant base

fields.couplet: Double-minded whores, wine and dice Are lures of those whom fortune flies
fields.meaning: Treacherous women, liquor, and gambling are the associates of such as have forsaken by Fortune

fields.couplet: Foes fear not who for toddy craze The addicts daily their glory lose
fields.meaning: Those who always thirst after drink will neither inspire fear (in others) nor retain the light (of their fame)

fields.couplet: Drink not liquor; but let them drink Whom with esteem the wise won't think
fields.meaning: Let no liquor be drunk; if it is desired, let it be drunk by those who care not for esteem of the great

fields.couplet: The drunkard's joy pains ev'n mother's face How vile must it look for the wise?
fields.meaning: Intoxication is painful even in the presence of (one's) mother; what will it not then be in that of the wise ?

fields.couplet: Good shame turns back from him ashamed Who is guilty of wine condemned
fields.meaning: The fair maid of modesty will turn her back on those who are guilty of the great and abominable crime of drunkenness

fields.couplet: To pay and drink and lose the sense Is nothing but rank ignorance
fields.meaning: To give money and purchase unconsciousness is the result of one's ignorance of (one's own actions)

fields.couplet: They take poison who take toddy And doze ev'n like a dead body
fields.meaning: They that sleep resemble the deed; (likewise) they that drink are no other than poison-eaters

fields.couplet: The secret drunkards' senses off Make the prying public laugh
fields.meaning: Those who always intoxicate themselves by a private (indulgence in) drink; will have their secrets detected and laughed at by their fellow-townsmen

fields.couplet: Don't say I'm not a drunkard hard The hidden fraud is known abroad
fields.meaning: Let (the drunkard) give up saying "I have never drunk"; (for) the moment (he drinks) he will simply betray his former attempt to conceal

fields.couplet: Can torch search one in water sunk?  Can reason reach the raving drunk?
fields.meaning: Reasoning with a drunkard is like going under water with a torch in search of a drowned man

fields.couplet: The sober seeing the drunkard's plight On selves can't they feel same effect?
fields.meaning: When (a drunkard) who is sober sees one who is not, it looks as if he remembered not the evil effects of his (own) drink

fields.couplet: Avoid gambling, albeit you win Gulping bait-hook what does fish gain?
fields.meaning: Though able to win, let not one desire gambling; (for) even what is won is like a fish swallowing the iron in fish-hook

fields.couplet: Can gamblers in life good obtain Who lose a hundred one to gain?
fields.meaning: That they may good obtain, and see a prosperous day? Is there indeed a means of livelihood that can bestow happiness on gamblers who gain one and lose a hundred?

fields.couplet: If kings indulge in casting dice All their fortune will flow to foes
fields.meaning: If the king is incessantly addicted to the rolling dice in the hope of gain, his wealth and the resources thereof will take their departure and fall into other's hands

fields.couplet: Nothing will make you poor like game Which adds to woes and ruins fame
fields.meaning: There is nothing else that brings (us) poverty like gambling which causes many a misery and destroys (one's) reputation

fields.couplet: The game, game-hall and gambler's art Who sought with glee have come to nought
fields.meaning: Penniless are those who by reason of their attachment would never forsake gambling, the gamblingplace and the handling (of dice)

fields.couplet: Men swallowed by the ogress, dice Suffer grief and want by that vice
fields.meaning: Those who are swallowed by the goddess called "gambling" will never have their hunger satisfied, but suffer the pangs of hell in the next world

fields.couplet: If men their time in game-den spend Ancestral wealth and virtues end
fields.meaning: To waste time at the place of gambling will destroy inherited wealth and goodness of character

fields.couplet: Game ruins wealth and spoils grace Leads to lies and wretched woes
fields.meaning: Gambling destroys property, teaches falsehood, puts an end to benevolence, and brings in misery (here and hereafter)

fields.couplet: Dress, wealth, food, fame, learning-these five In gambler's hand will never thrive
fields.meaning: The habit of gambling prevents the attainment of these five: clothing, wealth, food, fame and learning

fields.couplet: Love for game grows with every loss As love for life with sorrows grows
fields.meaning: As the gambler loves (his vice) the more he loses by it, so does the soul love (the body) the more it suffers through it

fields.couplet: Wind, bile and phlegm three cause disease So doctors deem it more or less
fields.meaning: If (food and work are either) excessive or deficient, the three things enumerated by (medical) writers, flatulence, biliousness, and phlegm, will cause (one) disease

fields.couplet: After digestion one who feeds His body no medicine needs
fields.meaning: No medicine is necessary for him who eats after assuring (himself) that what he has (already) eaten has been digested

fields.couplet: Eat food to digestive measure Life in body lasts with pleasure
fields.meaning: If (one's food has been) digested let one eat with moderation; (for) that is the way to prolong the life of an embodied soul

fields.couplet: Know digestion; with keen appetite Eat what is suitable and right
fields.meaning: (First) assure yourself that your food has been digested and never fail to eat, when very hungry, whatever is not disagreeable (to you)

fields.couplet: With fasting adjusted food right Cures ills of life and makes you bright
fields.meaning: There will be no disaster to one's life if one eats with moderation, food that is not disagreeable

fields.couplet: Who eats with clean stomach gets health With greedy glutton abides ill-health
fields.meaning: As pleasure dwells with him who eats moderately, so disease (dwells) with the glutton who eats voraciously

fields.couplet: who glut beyond the hunger's fire Suffer from untold diseases here
fields.meaning: He will be afflicted with numberless diseases, who eats immoderately, ignorant (of the rules of health)

fields.couplet: Test disease, its cause and cure And apply remedy that is sure
fields.meaning: Let the physician enquire into the (nature of the) disease, its cause and its method of cure and treat it faithfully according to (medical rule)

fields.couplet: Let the skilful doctor note The sickmen, sickness, season and treat
fields.meaning: The learned (physician) should ascertain the condition of his patient; the nature of his disease, and the season (of the year) and (then) proceed (with his treatment)

fields.couplet: Patient, doctor, medicine and nurse Are four-fold codes of treating course
fields.meaning: Medical science consists of four parts, viz, patient, physician, medicine and compounder; and each of these (again) contains four sub-divisions

fields.couplet: Right-sense and bashfulness adorn By nature only the noble-born
fields.meaning: Consistency (of thought, word and deed) and fear (of sin) are conjointly natural only to the high-born

fields.couplet: The noble-born lack not these three: Good conduct, truth and modesty
fields.meaning: The high-born will never deviate from these three; good manners, truthfulness and modesty

fields.couplet: Smile, gift, sweet words and courtesy These four mark true nobility
fields.meaning: A cheerful countenance, liberality, pleasant words, and an unreviling disposition, these four are said to be the proper qualities of the truly high-born

fields.couplet: Even for crores, the noble mood Cannot bend to degrading deed
fields.meaning: Though blessed with immense wealth, the noble will never do anything unbecoming

fields.couplet: The means of gift may dwindle; yet Ancient homes guard their noble trait
fields.meaning: Though their means fall off, those born in ancient families, will not lose their character (for liberality)

fields.couplet: Who guard their family prestige pure Stoop not to acts of cunning lure
fields.meaning: Those who seek to preserve the irreproachable honour of their families will not viciously do what is detrimental thereto

fields.couplet: The faults of nobly-born are seen Like on the sky the spots of moon
fields.meaning: As spots on her bright orb that walks sublime the evening sky

fields.couplet: If manners of the good are rude People deem their pedigree crude
fields.meaning: If one of a good family betrays want of affection, his descent from it will be called in question

fields.couplet: Soil's nature is seen in sprout The worth of birth from words flow out
fields.meaning: As the sprout indicates the nature of the soil, (so) the speech of the noble indicates (that of one's birth)

fields.couplet: All gain good name by modesty Nobility by humility
fields.meaning: He who desires a good name must desire modesty; and he who desires (the continuance of) a family greatness must be submissive to all

fields.couplet: Though needed for your life in main, From mean degrading acts refrain
fields.meaning: Actions that would degrade (one's) family should not be done; though they may be so important that not doing them would end in death

fields.couplet: Who seek honour and manly fame Don't do mean deeds even for name
fields.meaning: Those who desire (to maintain their) honour, will surely do nothing dishonourable, even for the sake of fame

fields.couplet: Be humble in prosperity In decline uphold dignity
fields.meaning: In great prosperity humility is becoming; dignity, in great adversity

fields.couplet: Like hair fallen from head are those Who fall down from their high status
fields.meaning: They who have fallen from their (high) position are like the hair which has fallen from the head

fields.couplet: Even hill-like men will sink to nought With abrus-grain-like small default
fields.meaning: Even those who are exalted like a hill will be thought low, if they commit deeds that are debasing

fields.couplet: Why fawn on men that scorn you here It yields no fame, heaven's bliss neither
fields.meaning: Why follow men who scorn, and at their bidding wait?

fields.couplet: Better it is to die forlorn Than live as slaves of those who scorn
fields.meaning: It is better for a man to be said of him that he died in his usual state than that he eked out his life by following those who disgraced him

fields.couplet: Is nursing body nectar sweet Even when one's honour is lost?
fields.meaning: For the high-born to keep their body in life when their honour is gone will certainly not prove a remedy against death

fields.couplet: Honour lost, the noble expire Like a yak that loses its hair
fields.meaning: Those who give up (their) life when (their) honour is at stake are like the yark which kills itself at the loss of (even one of) its hairs

fields.couplet: Their light the world adores and hails  Who will not live when honour fails
fields.meaning: The world will (always) praise and adore the fame of the honourable who would rather die than suffer indignity

fields.couplet: A heart of courage lives in light  Devoid of that one's life is night
fields.meaning: One's light is the abundance of one's courage; one's darkness is the desire to live destitute of such (a state of mind.)

fields.couplet: All beings are the same in birth But work decides their varied worth
fields.meaning: All human beings agree as regards their birth but differ as regards their characteristics, because of the different qualities of their actions

fields.couplet: Ignoble high not high they are The noble low not low they fare
fields.meaning: Though (raised) above, the base cannot become great; though (brought) low, the great cannot become base

fields.couplet: Greatness like woman's chastity Is guarded by self-varacity
fields.meaning: Exists while to itself is true

fields.couplet: Great souls when their will is active Do mighty deeds rare to achieve
fields.meaning: (Though reduced) the great will be able to perform, in the proper way, deeds difficult (for others to do)

fields.couplet: The petty-natured ones have not The mind to seek and befriend the great
fields.meaning: It is never in the nature of the base to seek the society of the great and partake of their nature

fields.couplet: The base with power and opulence Wax with deeds of insolence
fields.meaning: Even nobility of birth, wealth and learning, if in (the possession of) the base, will (only) produce everincreasing pride

fields.couplet: Greatness bends with modesty Meanness vaunts with vanity
fields.meaning: The great will always humble himself; but the mean will exalt himself in self-admiration

fields.couplet: Greatness is free from insolence Littleness swells with that offence
fields.meaning: Freedom from conceit is (the nature of true) greatness; (while) obstinacy therein is (that of) meanness

fields.couplet: Weakness of others greatness screens Smallness defects alone proclaims
fields.meaning: The great hide the faults of others; the base only divulge them

fields.couplet: All goodness is duty to them  Who are dutiful and sublime
fields.meaning: It is said that those who are conscious of their duty and behave with a perfect goodness will regard as natural all that is good

fields.couplet: Good in the great is character Than that there is nothing better
fields.meaning: The only delight of the perfect is that of their goodness; all other (sensual) delights are not to be included among any (true) delights

fields.couplet: Love, truth, regard, modesty, grace These five are virtue's resting place
fields.meaning: Affection, fear (of sin), benevolence, favour and truthfulness; these are the five pillars on which perfect goodness rests

fields.couplet: Not to kill is penance pure Not to slander virtue sure
fields.meaning: Penance consists in the goodness that kills not , and perfection in the goodness that tells not others' faults

fields.couplet: Humility is valour's strength A force that averts foes at length
fields.meaning: Stooping (to inferiors) is the strength of those who can accomplish (an undertaking); and that is the weapon with which the great avert their foes

fields.couplet: To bear repulse e'en from the mean Is the touch-stone of worthy men
fields.meaning: The touch-stone of perfection is to receive a defeat even at the hands of one's inferiors

fields.couplet: Of perfection what is the gain If it returns not joy for pain?
fields.meaning: Of what avail is perfect goodness if it cannot do pleasing things even to those who have pained (it) ?

fields.couplet: No shame there is in poverty To one strong in good quality
fields.meaning: Poverty is no disgrace to one who abounds in good qualities

fields.couplet: Aeons may change but not the seer Who is a sea of virtue pure
fields.meaning: Those who are said to be the shore of the sea of perfection will never change, though ages may change

fields.couplet: The world will not more bear its weight If from high virtue fall the great
fields.meaning: If there is a defect in the character of the perfect, (even) the great world cannot bear (its) burden

fields.couplet: To the polite free of access Easily comes courteousness
fields.meaning: If one is easy of access to all, it will be easy for one to obtain the virtue called goodness

fields.couplet: Humanity and noble birth Develop courtesy and moral worth
fields.meaning: Affectionateness and birth in a good family, these two constitute what is called a proper behaviour to all

fields.couplet: Likeness in limbs is not likeness It's likeness in kind courteousness
fields.meaning: Resemblance of bodies is no resemblance of souls; true resemblance is the resemblance of qualities that attract

fields.couplet: The world applauds those helpful men Whose actions are just and benign
fields.meaning: The world applauds the character of those whose usefulness results from their equity and charity

fields.couplet: The courteous don't even foes detest For contempt offends even in jest
fields.meaning: Reproach is painful to one even in sport; those (therefore) who know the nature of others exhibit (pleasing) qualities even when they are hated

fields.couplet: The world rests with the mannered best Or it crumbles and falls to dust
fields.meaning: The (way of the) world subsists by contact with the good; if not, it would bury itself in the earth and perish

fields.couplet: The mannerless though sharp like file Are like wooden blocks indocile
fields.meaning: He who is destitute of (true) human qualities (only) resembles a tree, though he may possess the sharpness of a file

fields.couplet: Discourtesy is mean indeed E'en to a base unfriendly breed
fields.meaning: It is wrong (for the wise) not to exhibit (good) qualities even towards those who bearing no friendship (for them) do only what is hateful

fields.couplet: To those bereft of smiling light Even in day the earth is night
fields.meaning: To those who cannot rejoice, the wide world is buried darkness even in (broad) day light

fields.couplet: The wealth heaped by the churlish base Is pure milk soured by impure vase
fields.meaning: The great wealth obtained by one who has no goodness will perish like pure milk spoilt by the

fields.couplet: Dead is he with wealth in pile Unenjoyed, it is futile
fields.meaning: He who does not enjoy the immense riches he has heaped up in his house, is (to be reckoned as) dead, (for) there is nothing achieved (by him)

fields.couplet: The niggard miser thinks wealth is all He hoards, gives not is born devil
fields.meaning: He who knows that wealth yields every pleasure and yet is so blind as to lead miserly life will be born a demon

fields.couplet: A burden he is to earth indeed Who hoards without a worthy deed
fields.meaning: A burden to the earth are men bent on the acquisition of riches and not (true) fame

fields.couplet: What legacy can he leave behind Who is for approach too unkind
fields.meaning: What will the miser who is not liked (by any one) regard as his own (in the world to come) ?

fields.couplet: What is the good of crores they hoard To give and enjoy whose heart is hard
fields.meaning: Those who neither give (to others) nor enjoy (their property) are (truly) destitute, though possessing immense riches

fields.couplet: Great wealth unused for oneself nor To worthy men is but a slur
fields.meaning: He who enjoys not (his riches) nor relieves the wants of the worthy is a disease to his wealth

fields.couplet: Who loaths to help have-nots, his gold Is like a spinster-belle grown old
fields.meaning: The wealth of him who never bestows anything on the destitute is like a woman of beauty growing old without a husband

fields.couplet: The idle wealth of unsought men Is poison-fruit-tree amidst a town
fields.meaning: The wealth of him who is disliked (by all) is like the fruit-bearing of the etty tree in the midst of a town

fields.couplet: Others usurp the shining gold In loveless, stingy, vicious hold
fields.meaning: To heap up glittering wealth, their hoards shall others take

fields.couplet: The brief want of the rich benign Is like rainclouds growing thin
fields.meaning: The short-lived poverty of those who are noble and rich is like the clouds becoming poor (for a while)

fields.couplet: To shrink from evil deed is shame The rest is blush of fair-faced dame
fields.meaning: True modesty is the fear of (evil) deeds; all other modesty is (simply) the bashfulness of virtuous maids

fields.couplet: Food, dress and such are one for all Modesty marks the higher soul
fields.meaning: Food, clothing and the like are common to all men but modesty is peculiar to the good

fields.couplet: All lives have their lodge in flesh Perfection has its home in blush
fields.meaning: As the body is the abode of the spirit, so the excellence of modesty is the abode of perfection

fields.couplet: Shame is the jewel of dignity Shameless swagger is vanity
fields.meaning: Is not the modesty ornament of the noble ? Without it, their haughtiness would be a pain (to others)

fields.couplet: In them resides the sense of shame Who blush for their and other's blame
fields.meaning: The world regards as the abode of modesty him who fear his own and other's guilt

fields.couplet: The great refuse the wonder-world Without modesty's hedge and shield
fields.meaning: The great make modesty their barrier (of defence) and not the wide world

fields.couplet: For shame their life the shame-sensed give Loss of shame they won't outlive
fields.meaning: The modest would rather lose their life for the sake of modesty than lose modesty for the sake of life

fields.couplet: Virtue is much ashamed of him Who shameless does what others shame
fields.meaning: Virtue is likely to forsake him who shamelessly does what others are ashamed of

fields.couplet: Lapse in manners injures the race Want of shame harms every good grace
fields.meaning: Want of manners injures one's family; but want of modesty injures one's character

fields.couplet: Movements of the shameless in heart Are string-led puppet show in fact
fields.meaning: The actions of those who are without modesty at heart are like those of puppet moved by a string

fields.couplet: No greatness is grander like Saying \"I shall work without slack\"
fields.meaning: There is no higher greatness than that of one saying I will not cease in my effort (to raise my family)

fields.couplet: These two exalt a noble home Ardent effort and ripe wisdom
fields.meaning: One's family is raised by untiring perseverance in both effort and wise contrivances

fields.couplet: When one resolves to raise his race Loin girt up God leads his ways
fields.meaning: The Deity will clothe itself and appear before him who resolves on raising his family

fields.couplet: Who raise their races with ceaseless pain No need for plan; their ends will gain
fields.meaning: Those who are prompt in their efforts (to better their family) need no deliberation, such efforts will of themselves succeed

fields.couplet: Who keeps his house without a blame People around, his kinship claim
fields.meaning: People will eagerly seek the friendship of the prosperous soul who has raised his family without foul means

fields.couplet: Who raise their race which gave them birth Are deemed as men of manly worth
fields.meaning: A man's true manliness consists in making himself the head and benefactor of his family

fields.couplet: Like dauntless heroes in battle field The home-burden rests on the bold
fields.meaning: Amid his kindred so the burthen rests upon the strong

fields.couplet: No season have they who raise their race Sloth and pride will honour efface
fields.meaning: As a family suffers by (one's) indolence and false dignity there is to be so season (good or bad) to those who strive to raise their family

fields.couplet: Is not his frame a vase for woes Who from mishaps shields his house?
fields.meaning: Is it only to suffering that his body is exposed who undertakes to preserve his family from evil ?

fields.couplet: A house will fall by a mishap With no good man to prop it up
fields.meaning: If there are none to prop up and maintain a family (in distress), it will fall at the stroke of the axe of misfortune

fields.couplet: Farming though hard is foremost trade Men ply at will but ploughmen lead
fields.meaning: Agriculture, though laborious, is the most excellent (form of labour); for people, though they go about (in search of various employments), have at last to resort to the farmer

fields.couplet: Tillers are linch-pin of mankind Bearing the rest who cannot tend
fields.meaning: Agriculturists are (as it were) the linch-pin of the world for they support all other workers who cannot till the soil

fields.couplet: They live who live to plough and eat The rest behind them bow and eat
fields.meaning: They alone live who live by agriculture; all others lead a cringing, dependent life

fields.couplet: Who have the shade of cornful crest Under their umbra umbrellas rest
fields.meaning: Patriotic farmers desire to bring all other states under the control of their own king

fields.couplet: Who till and eat, beg not; nought hide But give to those who are in need
fields.meaning: Those whose nature is to live by manual labour will never beg but give something to those who beg

fields.couplet: Should ploughmen sit folding their hands Desire-free monks too suffer wants
fields.meaning: If the farmer's hands are slackened, even the ascetic state will fail

fields.couplet: Moulds dried to quarter-dust ensure Rich crops without handful manure
fields.meaning: If the land is dried so as to reduce one ounce of earth to a quarter, it will grow plentifully even without a handful of manure

fields.couplet: Better manure than plough; then weed; Than irrigating, better guard
fields.meaning: Manuring is better than ploughing; after weeding, watching is better than watering (it)

fields.couplet: If landsmen sit sans moving about The field like wife will sulk and pout
fields.meaning: If the owner does not (personally) attend to his cultivation, his land will behave like an angry wife and yield him no pleasure

fields.couplet: Fair good earth will laugh to see Idlers pleading poverty
fields.meaning: The maiden, Earth, will laugh at the sight of those who plead poverty and lead an idle life

fields.couplet: What gives more pain than scarcity? No pain pinches like poverty
fields.meaning: There is nothing that afflicts (one) like poverty

fields.couplet: The sinner Want is enemy dire Of joys of earth and heaven there
fields.meaning: When cruel poverty comes on, it deprives one of both the present and future (bliss)

fields.couplet: The craving itch of poverty Kills graceful words and ancestry
fields.meaning: Hankering poverty destroys at once the greatness of (one's) ancient descent and (the dignity of one's) speech

fields.couplet: Want makes even good familymen Utter words that are low and mean
fields.meaning: Even in those of high birth, poverty will produce the fault of uttering mean words

fields.couplet: The pest of wanton poverty Brings a train of misery
fields.meaning: The misery of poverty brings in its train many (more) miseries

fields.couplet: The poor men's words are thrown away Though from heart good things they say
fields.meaning: The words of the poor are profitless, though they may be sound in thought and clear in expression

fields.couplet: Even the mother looks as stranger The poor devoid of character
fields.meaning: He that is reduced to absolute poverty will be regarded as a stranger even by his own mother

fields.couplet: The killing Want of yesterday Will it pester me even to-day?
fields.meaning: Is the poverty that almost killed me yesterday, to meet me today too ?

fields.couplet: One may sleep in the midst of fire In want a wink of sleep is rare
fields.meaning: One may sleep in the midst of fire; but by no means in the midst of poverty

fields.couplet: Renounce their lives the poor must Or salt and gruel go to waste
fields.meaning: The destitute poor, who do not renounce their bodies, only consume their neighbour's salt and water

fields.couplet: Demand from those who can supply Default is theirs when they deny
fields.meaning: If you meet with those that may be begged of, you may beg; (but) if they withhold (their gift) it is their blame and not yours

fields.couplet: Even demand becomes a joy When the things comes without annoy
fields.meaning: Even begging may be pleasant, if what is begged for is obtained without grief (to him that begs)

fields.couplet: Request has charm form open hearts Who know the duty on their part
fields.meaning: There is even a beauty in standing before and begging of those who are liberal in their gifts and understand their duty (to beggars)

fields.couplet: Like giving even asking seems From those who hide not even in dreams
fields.meaning: To beg of such as never think of withholding (their charity) even in their dreams, is in fact the same as giving (it oneself);

fields.couplet: The needy demand for help because The world has men who don't refuse
fields.meaning: As there are in the world those that give without refusing, there are (also) those that prefer to beg by simply standing before them

fields.couplet: The pain of poverty shall die Before the free who don't deny
fields.meaning: All the evil of begging will be removed at the sight of those who are far from the evil of refusing

fields.couplet: When givers without scorn impart A thrill of delight fills the heart
fields.meaning: Beggars rejoice exceedingly when they behold those who bestow (their alms) with kindness and courtesy

fields.couplet: This grand cool world shall move to and fro Sans Askers like a puppet show
fields.meaning: If there were no beggars, (the actions done in) the cool wide world would only resemble the movement of a puppet

fields.couplet: Where stands the glory of givers Without obligation seekers?
fields.meaning: What (praise) would there be to givers (of alms) if there were no beggars to ask for and reveive (them)

fields.couplet: The needy should not scowl at \"No\" His need another's need must show * Saint valluvar talks of two kinds of Asking:() Asking help for public causes or enterprises () Begging when one is able to work and this is condemned
fields.meaning: He who begs ought not to be angry (at a refusal); for even the misery of (his own) poverty should be a sufficient reason (for so doing)

fields.couplet: Not to beg is billions worth E'en from eye-like friends who give with mirth
fields.meaning: Not to beg (at all) even from those excellent persons who cheerfully give without refusing, will do immense good

fields.couplet: Let World-Maker loiter and rot If \"beg and live\" be human fate
fields.meaning: If the Creator of the world has decreed even begging as a means of livelihood, may he too go abegging and perish

fields.couplet: Nothing is hard like hard saying \"We end poverty by begging\"
fields.meaning: There is no greater folly than the boldness with which one seeks to remedy the evils of poverty by begging (rather than by working)

fields.couplet: All space is small before the great Who beg not e'en in want acute
fields.meaning: Even the whole world cannot sufficiently praise the dignity that would not beg even in the midst of destitution

fields.couplet: Though gruel thin, nothing is sweet Like the food earned by labour's sweat
fields.meaning: Even thin gruel is ambrosia to him who has obtained it by labour

fields.couplet: It may be water for the cow Begging tongue is mean anyhow
fields.meaning: There is nothing more disgraceful to one's tongue than to use it in begging water even for a cow

fields.couplet: If beg they must I beg beggers Not to beg from shrinking misers
fields.meaning: I beseech all beggars and say, "If you need to beg, never beg of those who give unwillingly."

fields.couplet: The hapless bark of beggary splits On the rock of refusing hits
fields.meaning: The unsafe raft of begging will split when it strikes on the rock of refusal

fields.couplet: The heart at thought of beggars melts; It dies at repulsing insults
fields.meaning: To think of (the evil of) begging is enough to melt one's heart; but to think of refusal is enough to break it

fields.couplet: The word \"No\" kills the begger's life Where can the niggard's life be safe?
fields.meaning: Saying "No" to a beggar takes away his life. (but as that very word will kill the refuser) where then would the latter's life hide itself ?

fields.couplet: The mean seem men only in form We have never seen such a sham
fields.meaning: The base resemble men perfectly (as regards form); and we have not seen such (exact) resemblance (among any other species)

fields.couplet: The base seem richer than the good For no care enters their heart or head
fields.meaning: The low enjoy more felicity than those who know what is good; for the former are not troubled with anxiety (as to the good)

fields.couplet: The base are like gods; for they too As prompted by their desire do
fields.meaning: The base resemble the Gods; for the base act as they like

fields.couplet: When the base meets a rake so vile Him he will exceed, exult and smile
fields.meaning: The base feels proud when he sees persons whose acts meaner than his own

fields.couplet: Fear forms the conduct of the low Craving avails a bit below
fields.meaning: (The principle of) behaviour in the mean is chiefly fear; if not, hope of gain, to some extent

fields.couplet: The base are like the beaten drum Since other's secrets they proclaim
fields.meaning: The base are like a drum that is beaten, for they unburden to others the secrets they have heard

fields.couplet: The base their damp hand will not shake But for fists clenched their jaws to break
fields.meaning: The mean will not (even) shake off (what sticks to) their hands (soon after a meal) to any but those who would break their jaws with their clenched fists

fields.couplet: The good by soft words profits yield The cane-like base when crushed and killed
fields.meaning: The great bestow (their alms) as soon as they are informed; (but) the mean, like the sugar-cane, only when they are tortured to death

fields.couplet: Faults in others the mean will guess On seeing how they eat and dress
fields.meaning: The base will bring an evil (accusation) against others, as soon as he sees them (enjoying) good food

fields.couplet: The base hasten to sell themselves From doom to flit and nothing else
fields.meaning: The base will hasten to sell themselves as soon as a calamity has befallen them. For what else are they fitted ?

fields.couplet: Is it an angel? A fair peacock Or jewelled belle? To my mind a shock!
fields.meaning: Is this jewelled female a celestial, a choice peahen, or a human being ? My mind is perplexed

fields.couplet: The counter glances of this belle Are armied dart of the Love-Angel
fields.meaning: This female beauty returning my looks is like a celestial maiden coming with an army to contend against me

fields.couplet: Not known before -I spy Demise In woman's guise with battling eyes
fields.meaning: I never knew before what is called Yama; I see it now; it is the eyes that carry on a great fight with (the help of) female qualities

fields.couplet: This artless dame has darting eyes That drink the life of men who gaze
fields.meaning: These eyes that seem to kill those who look at them are as it were in hostilities with this feminine simplicity

fields.couplet: Is it death, eye or doe? All three In winsome woman's look I see
fields.meaning: Is it Yama, (a pair of) eyes or a hind ?- Are not all these three in the looks of this maid ?

fields.couplet: If cruel brows unbent, would screen Her eyes won't cause me trembling pain
fields.meaning: Her eyes will cause (me) no trembling sorrow, if they are properly hidden by her cruel arched eyebrows

fields.couplet: Vest on the buxom breast of her Looks like rutting tusker's eye-cover
fields.meaning: The cloth that covers the firm bosom of this maiden is (like) that which covers the eyes of a rutting elephant

fields.couplet: Ah these fair brows shatter my might Feared by foemen yet to meet
fields.meaning: On her bright brow alone is destroyed even that power of mine that used to terrify the most fearless

fields.couplet: Which jewel can add to her beauty With fawn-like looks and modesty?
fields.meaning: Of what use are other jewels to her who is adorned with modesty, and the meek looks of a hind ?

fields.couplet: To the drunk alone is wine delight Nothing delights like love at sight
fields.meaning: Unlike boiled honey which yields delight only when it is drunk, love gives pleasure even when looked at

fields.couplet: Her painted eyes, two glances dart One hurts; the other heals my heart
fields.meaning: There are two looks in the dyed eyes of this (fair one); one causes pain, and the other is the cure thereof

fields.couplet: Her furtive lightning glance is more Than enjoyment of sexual lore
fields.meaning: A single stolen glance of her eyes is more than half the pleasure (of sexual embrace)

fields.couplet: She looked; looking bowed her head And love-plant was with water fed
fields.meaning: She has looked (at men) and stooped (her head); and that (sign) waters as it were (the corn of) our love

fields.couplet: I look; she droops to earth awhile I turn; she looks with gentle smile
fields.meaning: When I look, she looks down; when I do not, she looks and smiles gently

fields.couplet: No direct gaze; a side-long glance She darts at me and smiles askance
fields.meaning: She not only avoids a direct look at me, but looks as it were with a half-closed eye and smiles

fields.couplet: Their words at first seem an offence But quick we feel them friendly ones
fields.meaning: Though they may speak harshly as if they were strangers, the words of the friendly are soon understood

fields.couplet: Harsh little words; offended looks, Are feigned consenting love-lorn tricks
