fields.meaning: Little words that are harsh and looks that are hateful are (but) the expressions of lovers who wish to act like strangers

fields.couplet: What a grace the slim maid has! As I look she slightly smiles
fields.meaning: When I look, the pitying maid looks in return and smiles gently; and that is a comforting sign for me

fields.couplet: Between lovers we do discern A stranger's look of unconcern
fields.meaning: Both the lovers are capable of looking at each other in an ordinary way, as if they were perfect strangers

fields.couplet: The words of mouth are of no use When eye to eye agrees the gaze
fields.meaning: The words of the mouths are of no use whatever, when there is perfect agreement between the eyes (of lovers)

fields.couplet: In this bangled beauty dwell The joys of sight sound touch taste smell
fields.meaning: The (simultaneous) enjoyment of the five senses of sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch can only be found with bright braceleted (women)

fields.couplet: The cure for ailment is somewhere For fair maid's ill she is the cure
fields.meaning: The remedy for a disease is always something different (from it); but for the disease caused by this jewelled maid, she is herself the cure

fields.couplet: Is lotus-eyed lord's heaven so sweet As sleep in lover's arms so soft?
fields.meaning: Can the lotus-eyed Vishnu's heaven be indeed as sweet to those who delight to sleep in the delicate arms of their beloved ?

fields.couplet: Away it burns and cools anear Wherefrom did she get this fire?
fields.meaning: From whence has she got this fire that burns when I withdraw and cools when I approach ?

fields.couplet: The arms of my flower-tressed maid Whatever I wish that that accord
fields.meaning: Each varied form of joy the soul can wish is found

fields.couplet: My simple maid has nectar arms Each embrace brings life-thrilling charms
fields.meaning: The shoulders of this fair one are made of ambrosia, for they revive me with pleasure every time I embrace them

fields.couplet: Ah the embrace of this fair dame Is like sharing one's food at home
fields.meaning: The embraces of a gold-complexioned beautiful female are as pleasant as to dwell in one's own house and live by one's own (earnings) after distributing (a portion of it in charity)

fields.couplet: Joy is the fast embrace that doth Not admit e'en air between both
fields.meaning: To ardent lovers sweet is the embrace that cannot be penetrated even by a breath of breeze

fields.couplet: Sulking, feeling and clasping fast These three are sweets of lover's tryst
fields.meaning: Love quarrel, reconciliation and intercourse - these are the advantages reaped by those who marry for lust

fields.couplet: As knowledge reveals past ignorance So is the belle as love gets close
fields.meaning: As (one's) ignorance is discovered the more one learns, so does repeated intercourse with a welladorned female (only create a desire for more)

fields.couplet: Soft blessed anicha flower, hail On whom I dote is softer still
fields.meaning: May you flourish, O Anicham! you have a delicate nature But my beloved is more delicate than you

fields.couplet: You can't liken flowers by many eyed, To her bright eyes, O mind dismayed
fields.meaning: O my soul, fancying that flowers which are seen by many can resemble her eyes, you become confused at the sight of them

fields.couplet: The bamboo-shouldered has pearl-like smiles Fragrant breath and lance-like eyes
fields.meaning: The complexion of this bamboo-shouldered one is that of a shoot; her teeth, are pearls; her breath,

fields.couplet: Lily droops down to ground and says I can't equal the jewelled-one's eyes
fields.meaning: If the blue lotus could see, it would stoop and look at the ground saying, "I can never resemble the eyes of this excellent jewelled one."

fields.couplet: Anicha flower with stem she wears To her breaking waist sad-drum-blares!
fields.meaning: No merry drums will be beaten for the (tender) waist of her who has adorned herself with the anicham without having removed its stem

fields.couplet: Stars are confused to know which is The moon and which is woman's face
fields.meaning: The stars have become confused in their places not being able to distinguish between the moon and the maid's countenance

fields.couplet: Are there spots on the lady's face Just as in moon that changes phase?
fields.meaning: Could there be spots in the face of this maid like those in the bright full moon ?

fields.couplet: Like my lady's face if you shine All my love to you; hail O moon!
fields.meaning: If you can indeed shine like the face of women, flourish, O moon, for then would you be worth loving ?

fields.couplet: Like the face of my flower-eyed one If you look, then shine alone O moon!
fields.meaning: O moon, if you wish to resemble the face of her whose eyes are like (these) flowers, do not appear so as to be seen by all

fields.couplet: The soft flower and the swan's down are Like nettles to the feet of the fair
fields.meaning: The anicham and the feathers of the swan are to the feet of females, like the fruit of the (thorny) Nerunji

fields.couplet: Like milk and honey the dew is sweet From her white teeth whose word is soft
fields.meaning: The water which oozes from the white teeth of this soft speeched damsel is like a mixture of milk and honey

fields.couplet: Love between me and this lady Is like bond between soul and body
fields.meaning: The love between me and this damsel is like the union of body and soul

fields.couplet: Depart image in my pupil Giving room to my fair-browed belle!
fields.meaning: O you image in the pupil (of my eye)! depart; there is no room for (my) fair-browed beloved

fields.couplet: Life with my jewel is existence Death it is her severance
fields.meaning: My fair-jewelled one resembles the living soul (when she is in union with me), the dying soul when she leaves me

fields.couplet: Can I forget? I recall always The charms of her bright battling eyes
fields.meaning: If I had forgotten her who has bright battling eyes, I would have remembered (thee); but I never forget her (Thus says he to her maid)

fields.couplet: So subtle is my lover's form Ever in my eyes winking, no harm
fields.meaning: My lover would not depart from mine eyes; even if I wink, he would not suffer (from pain); he is so ethereal

fields.couplet: My lover in my eyes abides I paint them not lest he hides
fields.meaning: As my lover abides in my eyes, I will not even paint them, for he would (then) have to conceal himself

fields.couplet: My lover abides in my heart I fear hot food lest he feels hot
fields.meaning: As my lover is in my heart, I am afraid of eating (anything) hot, for I know it would pain him

fields.couplet: My eyes wink not lest he should hide And him as cruel the townsmen chide
fields.meaning: I will not wink, knowing that if I did, my lover would hide himself; and for this reason, this town says, he is unloving

fields.couplet: He abides happy in my heart But people mistake he is apart
fields.meaning: My lover dwells in my heart with perpetual delight; but the town says he is unloving and (therefore) dwells afar

fields.couplet: Pangs of passion find no recourse Except riding *`palmyra horse' * Palmyra horse or 'Madal' is a torture expressive of the burning passion of the lover to the beloved The lover's body is laid on a rough pricking palmyra bed and he is carried along the street with songs of love pangs The parents of the lovers first reproach them and then consent to their marriage
fields.meaning: To those who after enjoyment of sexual pleasure suffer (for want of more), there is no help so efficient as the palmyra horse

fields.couplet: Pining body and mind lose shame And take to riding of the palm
fields.meaning: Having got rid of shame, the suffering body and soul save themselves on the palmyra horse

fields.couplet: Once I was modest and manly My love has now Madal only
fields.meaning: Modesty and manliness were once my own; now, my own is the palmyra horse that is ridden by the lustful

fields.couplet: Rushing flood of love sweeps away The raft of shame and firmness, aye!
fields.meaning: The raft of modesty and manliness, is, alas, carried-off by the strong current of lust

fields.couplet: Palm-ride and pangs of eventide Are gifts of wreath-like bracelet maid
fields.meaning: She with the small garland-like bracelets has given me the palmyra horse and the sorrow that is endured at night

fields.couplet: Madal I ride at midnight for My eyes sleep not seeing this fair
fields.meaning: Mine eyes will not close in sleep on your mistress's account; even at midnight will I think of mounting the palmyra horse

fields.couplet: Her sea-like lust seeks not Madal! Serene is woman's self control
fields.meaning: There is nothing so noble as the womanly nature that would not ride the palmyra horse, though plunged a sea of lust

fields.couplet: Lust betrays itself in haste Though women are highly soft and chaste
fields.meaning: Even the Lust (of women) transgresses its secrecy and appears in public, forgetting that they are too chaste and liberal (to be overcome by it)

fields.couplet: My perplexed love roves public street Believing that none knows its secret
fields.meaning: And thus, in public ways, perturbed will rove

fields.couplet: Fools laugh at me before my eyes For they feel not my pangs and sighs
fields.meaning: Even strangers laugh (at us) so as to be seen by us, for they have not suffered

fields.couplet: Rumour sustains my existence Good luck! many know not its sense
fields.meaning: My precious life is saved by the raise of rumour, and this, to my good luck no others are aware of

fields.couplet: Rumour gives me the flower-like belle People know not what rare angel
fields.meaning: Not knowing the value of her whose eyes are like flowers this town has got up a rumour about me

fields.couplet: I profit by this public rumour Having not, I feel, I have her
fields.meaning: Will I not get a rumour that is known to the (whole) town ? For what I have not got is as if I had got it (already)

fields.couplet: Rumour inflames the love I seek Or else it becomes bleak and weak
fields.meaning: Rumour increases the violence of my passion; without it it would grow weak and waste away

fields.couplet: Drink delights as liquor flows Love delights as rumour grows
fields.meaning: As drinking liquor is delightful (to one) whenever one is in mirth, so is lust delightful to me whenever it is the subject of rumour

fields.couplet: One lasting day we met alone Lasting rumours eclipse our moon
fields.meaning: It was but a single day that I looked on (my lover); but the rumour thereof has spread like the seizure of the moon by the serpent

fields.couplet: Scandal manures; mother's refrain Waters the growth of this love-pain
fields.meaning: This malady (of lust) is manured by the talk of women and watered by the (harsh) words of my mother

fields.couplet: To quench the lust by rumour free Is to quench fire by pouring ghee
fields.meaning: To say that one could extinguish passion by rumour is like extinguishing fire with ghee

fields.couplet: Who said \"fear not\" flared up rumour Why then should I blush this clamour?
fields.meaning: When the departure of him who said "fear not" has put me to shame before others, why need I be ashamed of scandal

fields.couplet: Town raising this cry, I desire Consent is easy from my sire
fields.meaning: The rumour I desire is raised by the town (itself); and my lover would if desired consent (to my following him)

fields.couplet: Tell me if you but do not leave, Your quick return to those who live
fields.meaning: If it is not departure, tell me; but if it is your speedy return, tell it to those who would be alive then

fields.couplet: His sight itself was pleasing, near Embrace pains now by partings fear
fields.meaning: His very look was once pleasing; but (now) even intercourse is painful through fear of separation

fields.couplet: On whom shall I lay my trust hence While parting lurks in knowing ones?
fields.meaning: As even the lover who understands (everything) may at times depart, confidence is hardly possible

fields.couplet: He parts whose love told me -fear not Is my trust in him at default?
fields.meaning: If he who bestowed his love and said "fear not" should depart, will it be the fault of those who believed in (his) assuring words ?

fields.couplet: Stop his parting -my life to save Meeting is rare if he would leave
fields.meaning: If you would save (my life), delay the departure of my destined (husband); for if he departs, intercourse will become impossible

fields.couplet: His hardness says, \"I leave you now\" Is there hope of his renewed love?
fields.meaning: Is hard, when he could stand, and of departure speak to me

fields.couplet: Will not my gliding bangles' cry The parting of my lord betray?
fields.meaning: Do not the rings that begin to slide down my fingers forebode the separation of my lord ?

fields.couplet: Bitter is life in friendless place; Worse is parting love's embrace!
fields.meaning: Painful is it to live in a friendless town; but far more painful is it to part from one's lover

fields.couplet: Can fire that burns by touch burn like Parting of the hearts love-sick?
fields.meaning: Fire burns when touched; but, like the sickness of love, can it also burn when removed ?

fields.couplet: Many survive pangs of parting Not I this sore so distressing
fields.meaning: As if there were many indeed that can consent to the impossible, kill their pain, endure separation and yet continue to live afterwards

fields.couplet: It swells out like baled out spring How to bear this pain so writhing?
fields.meaning: I would hide this pain from others; but it (only) swells like a spring to those who drain it

fields.couplet: I can't conceal this nor complain For shame to him who caused this pain
fields.meaning: I cannot conceal this pain, nor can I relate it without shame to him who has caused it

fields.couplet: In life -poles of this wearied frame Are poised the weights of lust and shame
fields.meaning: (Both) lust and shame, with my soul for their shoulder pole balance themselves on a body that cannot bear them

fields.couplet: My lust is a sea; I do not see A raft to go across safely
fields.meaning: There is indeed a flood of lust; but there is no raft of safety to cross it with

fields.couplet: What wilt they prove when they are foes Who in friendship bring me woes!
fields.meaning: What will they prove when angry tempests lower?

fields.couplet: The pleasure in love is oceanful But its pangs are more painful
fields.meaning: The pleasure of lust is (as great as) the sea; but the pain of lust is far greater

fields.couplet: Wild waves of love I swim shoreless Pining alone in midnight hush
fields.meaning: I have swam across the terrible flood of lust, but have not seen its shore; even at midnight I am alone; still I live

fields.couplet: Night's mercy lulls all souls to sleep Keeping but me for companionship
fields.meaning: The night which graciously lulls to sleep all living creatures, has me alone for her companion

fields.couplet: Crueller than that cruel he Are midnight hours gliding slowly
fields.meaning: The long nights of these days are far more cruel than the heartless one who is torturing me

fields.couplet: Like heart, if my sight reaches him It won't in floods of tears swim!
fields.meaning: Could mine eyes travel like my thoughts to the abode (of my absent lord), they would not swim in this flood of tears

fields.couplet: The eye pointed him to me; why then They weep with malady and pine?
fields.meaning: As this incurable malady has been caused by my eyes which showed (him) to me, why should they now weep for (him)

fields.couplet: Why should these dyed eyes grieve now sans Regrets for their thoughtless glance?
fields.meaning: The dyed eyes that (then) looked without foresight, why should they now endure sorrow, without feeling sharply (their own fault)

fields.couplet: Eyes darted eager glance that day It's funny that they weep today
fields.meaning: They themselves looked eagerly (on him) and now they weep. Is not this to be laughed at ?

fields.couplet: These eyes left me to endless grief Crying adry without relief
fields.meaning: These painted eyes have caused me a lasting mortal disease; and now they can weep no more, the tears having dried up

fields.couplet: My eyes causing lust more than sea Suffer that torture sleeplessly
fields.meaning: Mine eyes have caused me a lust that is greater than the sea and (they themselves) endure the torture of sleeplessness

fields.couplet: Lo! eyes that wrought this love-sickness Are victims of the same themselves
fields.meaning: The eyes that have given me this disease have themselves been seized with this (suffering) Oh! I am much delighted

fields.couplet: Let tears dry up pining pining In eyes that eyed him longing longing
fields.meaning: The eyes that became tender and gazed intently on him, may they suffer so much as to dry up the fountain of their tears

fields.couplet: Ther's he whose lips loved, not his heart Yet my eyes pine seeing him not
fields.meaning: He is indeed here who loved me with his lips but not with his heart but mine eyes suffer from not seeing him

fields.couplet: He comes; no sleep; he goes; no sleep This is the fate of eyes that weep
fields.meaning: When he is away they do not sleep; when he is present they do not sleep; in either case, mine eyes endure unbearable agony

fields.couplet: Like drum beats eyes declare my heart; From people who could hide his secret?
fields.meaning: It is not difficult for the people of this place to understand the secret of those whose eyes, like mine, are as it were beaten drums

fields.couplet: My lover's parting, I allowed Whom to complain my hue pallid?
fields.meaning: I who (then) consented to the absence of my loving lord, to whom can I (now) relate the fact of my having turned sallow

fields.couplet: Claiming it is begot through him Pallor creeps and rides over my frame
fields.meaning: Sallowness, as if proud of having been caused by him, would now ride on my person

fields.couplet: He seized my beauty and modesty Leaving pangs and Pallor to me
fields.meaning: He has taken (away) my beauty and modesty, and given me instead disease and sallowness

fields.couplet: He is my thought, his praise my theme Yet this pallor steals over my frame
fields.meaning: I think (of him); and what I speak about is but his excellence; still is there sallowness; and this is deceitful

fields.couplet: My lover departed me there And pallor usurped my body here
fields.meaning: Just as my lover departed then, did not sallowness spread here on my person ?

fields.couplet: Just as darkness waits for light-off Pallor looks for lover's arms-off
fields.meaning: Just as darkness waits for the failing light; so does sallowness wait for the laxity of my husband's intercourse

fields.couplet: From his embrace I turned a nonce This pallor swallowed me at once
fields.meaning: I who was in close embrace just turned aside and the moment I did so, sallowness came on me like something to be seized on

fields.couplet: On my pallor they cast a slur But none says \"lo he parted her\"
fields.meaning: Besides those who say "she has turned sallow" there are none who say "he has forsaken her"

fields.couplet: Let all my body become pale If he who took my leave fares well
fields.meaning: If he is clear of guilt who has conciliated me (to his departure) let my body suffer its due and turn sallow

fields.couplet: Let people call me all pallid But my lover let them not deride
fields.meaning: It would be good to be said of me that I have turned sallow, if friends do not reproach with unkindness him who pleased me (then)

fields.couplet: Stoneless fruit of love they have Who are beloved by those they love
fields.meaning: The women who are beloved by those whom they love, have they have not got the stone-less fruit of sexual delight ?

fields.couplet: The lover-and-beloved's self-givings Are like rains to living beings
fields.meaning: The bestowal of love by the beloved on those who love them is like the rain raining (at the proper season) on those who live by it

fields.couplet: The pride of living is for those Whose love is returned by love so close
fields.meaning: The pride that says "we shall live" suits only those who are loved by their beloved (husbands)

fields.couplet: Whose love is void of love in turn Are luckless with all esteems they earn
fields.meaning: Even those who are esteemed (by other women) are devoid of excellence, if they are not loved by their beloved

fields.couplet: What can our lover do us now If he does not requite our love?
fields.meaning: He who is beloved by me, what will he do to me, if I am not beloved by him ?

fields.couplet: One sided pains; love in both souls Poises well like shoulder poles
fields.meaning: Lust, like the weight of the KAVADI, pains if it lies in one end only but pleases if it is in both

fields.couplet: This cupid aims at me alone; Knows he not my pallor and pain?
fields.meaning: Would not cupid who abides and contends in one party (only) witness the pain and sorrow (in that party)?

fields.couplet: None is so firm as she who loves Without kind words from whom she dotes
fields.meaning: There is no one in the world so hard-hearted as those who can live without receiving (even) a kind word from their beloved

fields.couplet: The lover accords not my desires And yet his words sweeten my ears
fields.meaning: Though my beloved bestows no love on one, still are his words sweet to my ears

fields.couplet: You tell your grief to listless he Bless my heart! rather fill up sea!
fields.meaning: Live, O my soul, would you who relate your great sorrow to strangers, try rather to fill up your own sea (of sorrow)

fields.couplet: Love is sweeter than wine; for vast Is its delight at very thought
fields.meaning: Sexuality is sweeter than liquor, because when remembered, it creates a most rapturous delight

fields.couplet: Pains are off at the lover's thought In all aspects this love is sweet
fields.meaning: Even to think of one's beloved gives one no pain Sexuality, in any degree, is always delightful

fields.couplet: To sneeze I tried hence but could not Me he tried to think but did not
fields.meaning: I feel as if I am going to sneeze but do not, and (therefore) my beloved is about to think (of me) but does not

fields.couplet: Have I a place within his heart? Ah from mine he will never depart
fields.meaning: He continues to abide in my soul, do I likewise abide in his ?

fields.couplet: Shame! My heart often he enters Banning me entry into his
fields.meaning: He who has imprisoned me in his soul, is he ashamed to enter incessantly into mine

fields.couplet: Beyond the thought of life with him What else of life can I presume?
fields.meaning: I live by remembering my (former) intercourse with him; if it were not so, how could I live ?

fields.couplet: What will happen if I forget When his memory burns my heart?
fields.meaning: I have never forgotten (the pleasure); even to think of it burns my soul; could I live, if I should ever forget it ?

fields.couplet: I bring him to ceaseless memory He chides not; and thus honours me
fields.meaning: He will not be angry however much I may think of him; is it not so much the delight my beloved

fields.couplet: Dear life ebbs away by thought Of him who said we are one heart
fields.meaning: My precious life is wasting away by thinking too much on the cruelty of him who said we were not different

fields.couplet: Hail moon! Set not so that I find Him who left me but not my mind
fields.meaning: May you live, O Moon! Do not set, that I mine see him who has departed without quitting my soul

fields.couplet: How shall I feast this dream-vision That brings the beloved's love-mission?
fields.meaning: Where with shall I feast the dream which has brought me my dear one's messenger ?

fields.couplet: I beg these fish-like dark eyes sleep To tell my lover how life I keep
fields.meaning: If my fish-like painted eyes should, at my begging, close in sleep, I could fully relate my sufferings to my lord

fields.couplet: In wakeful hours who sees me not I meet in dreams and linger yet
fields.meaning: My life lasts because in my dream I behold him who does not favour me in my waking hours

fields.couplet: In dreams I enjoy his love-bliss Who in wakeful hours I miss
fields.meaning: There is pleasure in my dream, because in it I seek and obtain him who does not visit me in my wakefulness

fields.couplet: Dream-sight of him delights at once Awake-What of seeing him -hence
fields.meaning: I saw him in my waking hours, and then it was pleasant; I see him just now in my dream, and it is (equally) pleasant

fields.couplet: If wakeful hours come to nought My lov'r in dreams would nev'r depart
fields.meaning: Were there no such thing as wakefulness, my beloved (who visited me) in my dream would not depart from me

fields.couplet: Awake he throws my overtures Adream, ah cruel! he tortures!
fields.meaning: The cruel one who would not favour me in my wakefulness, what right has he to torture me in my dreams?

fields.couplet: Asleep he embraces me fast; Awake he enters quick my heart
fields.meaning: When I am asleep he rests on my shoulders, (but) when I awake he hastens into my soul

fields.couplet: In dreams who don't discern lovers Rue their missing in wakeful hours
fields.meaning: They who have no dear ones to behold in their dreams blame him who visits me not in my waking hours

fields.couplet: The townsmen say he left me thus  In dreams failing to see him close
fields.meaning: The women of this place say he has forsaken me in my wakefulness I think they have not seen him visit me in my dreams

fields.couplet: Bless you! you are not eventide But killing dart to wedded bride!
fields.meaning: Live, O you evening are you (the former) evening? No, you are the season that slays (married) women

fields.couplet: Hail sad eventide dim and grim Has your mate like mine, cruel whim!
fields.meaning: A long life to you, O dark evening! You are sightless Is your help-mate (also) as hard-hearted as mine

fields.couplet: Wet eve came pale and trembling then Now it makes bold with growing pain
fields.meaning: The evening that (once) came in with trembling and dimness (now) brings me an aversion for life and increasing sorrow

fields.couplet: Lover away, comes eventide Like slayer to field of homicide
fields.meaning: In the absence of my lover, evening comes in like slayers on the field of slaughter

fields.couplet: What good have I done to morning And what evil to this evening?
fields.meaning: O eve, why art thou foe! thou dost renew my grief

fields.couplet: Evening pangs I have not known When my lord nev'r left me alone
fields.meaning: Previous to my husband's departure, I know not the painful nature of evening

fields.couplet: Budding at dawn burgeoning all day This disease blooms in evening gay
fields.meaning: This malady buds forth in the morning, expands all day long and blossoms in the evening

fields.couplet: A deadly arm, this shepherd's flute Hails flaming eve and slays my heart
fields.meaning: The shepherd's flute now sounds as a fiery forerunner of night, and is become a weapon that slays (me)

fields.couplet: Deluding eve if it prolongs The whole town will suffer love-pangs
fields.meaning: When night comes on confusing (everyone's) mind, the (whole) town will lose its sense and be plunged in sorrow

fields.couplet: Thinking of him whose quest is wealth My life outlives the twilight stealth
fields.meaning: My (hitherto) unextinguished life is now lost in this bewildering night at the thought of him who has the nature of wealth

fields.couplet: To lift from want he left me afar His thought makes my eyes blush the flower
fields.meaning: While we endure the unbearable sorrow, your eyes weep for him who is gone afar, and shun (the sight of) fragrant flowers

fields.couplet: My pale tearful eyes betray The hardness of my husband, away
fields.meaning: The discoloured eyes that shed tears profusely seem to betray the unkindness of our beloved

fields.couplet: These arms that swelled on nuptial day Now shrunk proclaim \"He is away\"
fields.meaning: The shoulders that swelled on the day of our union (now) seem to announce our separation clearly (to the public)

fields.couplet: Bracelets slip off the arms that have Lost old beauty for He took leave
fields.meaning: In the absence of your consort, your shoulders having lost their former beauty and fulness, your bracelets of pure gold have become loose

fields.couplet: Bereft of bracelets and old beauty Arms tell the cruel's cruelty
fields.meaning: The (loosened) bracelets, and the shoulders from which the old beauty has faded, relate the cruelty of the pitiless one

fields.couplet: Arms thin, armlets loose make you call My sire cruel; that pains my soul
fields.meaning: I am greatly pained to hear you call him a cruel man, just because your shoulders are reduced and your bracelets loosened

fields.couplet: Go and tell the cruel, O mind  Bruit ov'r my arms and glory find
fields.meaning: Can you O my soul! gain glory by relating to the (so-called) cruel one the clamour of my fading shoulders?

fields.couplet: The front of this fair one O paled As my clasping arms loosed their hold
fields.meaning: When I once loosened the arms that were in embrace, the forehead of the gold-braceleted women turned sallow

fields.couplet: Cool breeze crept between our embrace Her large rain-cloud-eyes paled at once
fields.meaning: When but a breath of breeze penetrated our embrace, her large cool eyes became sallow

fields.couplet: Pale eyes pained seeing the pallor Of the bright forehead of this fair
fields.meaning: Was it at the sight of what the bright forehead had done that the sallowness of her eyes became sad?

fields.couplet: Think of, O heart, some remedy To cure this chronic malady
fields.meaning: O my soul, will you not think and tell me some medicine be it what it may, that can cure this incurable malady?

fields.couplet: Bless O mind! you pine in vain For me he has no love serene
fields.meaning: Is folly, fare thee well my heart!

fields.couplet: O mind, why pine and sit moody? Who made you so pale lacks pity
fields.meaning: O my soul! why remain (here) and suffer thinking (of him)? There are no lewd thoughts (of you) in him who has caused you this disease of sorrow

fields.couplet: Take these eyes and meet him, O heart Or their hunger will eat me out
fields.meaning: O my soul! take my eyes also with you, (if not), these would eat me up (in their desire) to see him

fields.couplet: He spurns our love and yet, O mind, Can we desert him as unkind?
fields.meaning: O my soul! can he who loves not though he is beloved, be forsaken saying he hates me (now)?

fields.couplet: Wrath is false, O heart, face-to face Sans huff, you rush to his sweet embrace
fields.meaning: O my soul! when you see the dear one who remove dislike by intercourse, you are displeased and continue to be so Nay, your displeasure is (simply) false

fields.couplet: Off with love O mind, or shame I cannot endure both of them
fields.meaning: O my good soul, give up either lust or honour, as for me I can endure neither

fields.couplet: Without pity he would depart! You sigh and seek his favour, poor heart!
fields.meaning: You are a fool, O my soul! to go after my departed one, while you mourn that he is not kind enough to favour you

fields.couplet: The lover lives in Self you know; Whom you think, mind to whom you go?
fields.meaning: O my soul! to whom would you repair, while the dear one is within yourself?

fields.couplet: Without a thought he deserted us To think of him will make us worse
fields.meaning: If I retain in my heart him who has left me without befriending me, I shall lose even the (inward) beauty that remains

fields.couplet: Passion's axe shall break the door Of reserve bolted with my honour
fields.meaning: The axe of lust can break the door of chastity which is bolted with the bolt of modesty

fields.couplet: The thing called lust is a heartless power It sways my mind at midnight hour
fields.meaning: Even at midnight is my mind worried by lust, and this one thing, alas! is without mercy

fields.couplet: How to hide this lust which shows Itself while I sneeze unawares!
fields.meaning: I would conceal my lust, but alas, it yields not to my will but breaks out like a sneeze

fields.couplet: I was proud of my sex-reserve Lo lust betrays what I preserve
fields.meaning: I say I would be firm, but alas, my malady breaks out from its concealment and appears in public

fields.couplet: Dignity seeks not a deserter But Love-sick is its innovator
fields.meaning: The dignity that would not go after an absent lover is not known to those who are sticken by love

fields.couplet: O Grief, my deserter you seek Of your caprice what shall I speak!
fields.meaning: The sorrow I have endured by desiring to go after my absent lover, in what way is it excellent?

fields.couplet: When lover's love does what it desires We forget all shame unawares
fields.meaning: I know nothing like shame when my beloved does from love (just) what is desired (by me)

fields.couplet: The cheater of many wily arts His tempting words break through women's hearts
fields.meaning: Are not the enticing words of my trick-abounding roguish lover the weapon that breaks away my feminine firmness?

fields.couplet: In huff I went and felt at ease Heat to heart in sweet embrace
fields.meaning: I said I would feign dislike and so went (away); (but) I embraced him the moment I say my mind began to unite with him!

fields.couplet: To feign dislike is it not rare  For mates who melt like fat in fire?
fields.meaning: Is it possible for those whose hearts melt like fat in the fire to say they can feign a strong dislike and remain so?

fields.couplet: My eyes are dim lustre-bereft Worn fingers count days since he left
fields.meaning: My finger has worn away by marking (on the wall) the days he has been absent while my eyes have lost their lustre and begin to fail

fields.couplet: Beauty pales and my bracelets slide; Why not forget him now, bright maid?
fields.meaning: O you bright-jewelled maid, if I forget (him) today, my shoulders will lose their beauty even in the other life and make my bracelets loose

fields.couplet: Will as guide he went to win Yet I live-to see him again
fields.meaning: I still live by longing for the arrival of him who has gone out of love for victory and with valour as his guide

fields.couplet: My heart in rapture heaves to see His retun with love to embrace me
fields.meaning: My heart is rid of its sorrow and swells with rapture to think of my absent lover returning with his love

fields.couplet: Let me but gaze and gaze my spouse sallow on my soft shoulders files
fields.meaning: May I look on my lover till I am satisfied and thereafter will vanish the sallowness of my slender shoulders

fields.couplet: Let my spouse return just a day Joy-drink shall drive my pain away
fields.meaning: May my husband return some day; and then will I enjoy (him) so as to destroy all this agonizing sorrow

fields.couplet: If my eye-like lord returneth Shall I sulk or clasp or do both?
fields.meaning: On the return of him who is as dear as my eyes, am I displeased or am I to embrace (him); or am I to do both?

fields.couplet: May the king fight and win and give And with my wife I will feast this eve!
fields.meaning: Let the king fight and gain (victories); (but) let me be united to my wife and feast the evening

fields.couplet: One day seems as seven to those Who yearn return of distant spouse
fields.meaning: To those who suffer waiting for the day of return of their distant lovers one day is as long as seven days

fields.couplet: When her heart is broken, what is The good of meeting and love-embrace?
fields.meaning: After (my wife) has died of a broken heart, what good will there be if she is to receive me, has received me, or has even embraced me?

fields.couplet: You hide; but your painted eyes Restraint off, report your surmise
fields.meaning: Though you would conceal (your feelings), your painted eyes would not, for, transgressing (their bounds), they tell (me) something

fields.couplet: With seemly grace and stem-like arms The simple she has ample charms
fields.meaning: Unusually great is the female simplicity of your maid whose beauty fills my eyes and whose shoulders resemble the bamboo

fields.couplet: Something shines through her jewelled charm Like thread shining through wreathed gem
fields.meaning: There is something that is implied in the beauty of this woman, like the thread that is visible in a garland of gems

fields.couplet: Like scent in bud secrets conceal In the bosom of her half smile
fields.meaning: There is something in the unmatured smile of this maid like the fragrance that is contained in an unblossomed bud

fields.couplet: The close-bangled belle's hidden thought Has a cure for my troubled heart She to Her Maid
fields.meaning: The well-meant departure of her whose bangles are tight-fitting contains a remedy that can cure my great sorrow

fields.couplet: His over-kind close embrace sooths; But makes me feel, loveless, he parts
fields.meaning: The embrace that fills me with comfort and gladness is capable of enduring (my former) sorrow and meditating on his want of love

fields.couplet: Quick, my bracelets read before The mind of my lord of cool shore
fields.meaning: My bracelets have understood before me the (mental) separation of him who rules the cool seashore

fields.couplet: My lover parted but yesterday; With sallowness it is seventh day The Maid Tells Him
fields.meaning: It was but yesterday my lover departed (from me); and it is seven days since my complexion turned sallow

fields.couplet: She views her armlets, her tender arms And then her feet; these are her norms
fields.meaning: She looked at her bracelets, her tender shoulders, and her feet; this was what she did there (significantly)

fields.couplet: To express love-pangs by eyes and pray Is womanhood's womanly way
fields.meaning: To express their love-sickness by their eyes and resort to begging bespeaks more than ordinary female excellence

fields.couplet: Rapture at thought and joy when seen Belong to love and not to wine
fields.meaning: To please by thought and cheer by sight is peculiar, not to liquor but lust

fields.couplet: When passion grows palmyra-tall Sulking is wrong though millet-small
fields.meaning: If women have a lust that exceeds even the measure of the palmyra fruit, they will not desire (to feign) dislike even as much as the millet

fields.couplet: Though slighting me he acts his will My restless eyes would see him still
fields.meaning: Though my eyes disregard me and do what is pleasing to my husband, still will they not be satisfied unless they see him

fields.couplet: Huff I would, maid, but I forget; And leap to embrace him direct
fields.meaning: My heart, forgetting all, could not its love restrain

fields.couplet: When close I see not lord's blemish Like eyes that see not painter's brush
fields.meaning: Like the eyes which see not the pencil that paints it, I cannot see my husband's fault (just) when I meet him

fields.couplet: When he's with me I see not fault And nought but fault when he is not
fields.meaning: When I see my husband, I do not see any faults; but when I do not see him, I do not see anything but faults

fields.couplet: To leap in stream which carries off When lord is close to feign a huff
fields.meaning: Like those who leap into a stream which they know will carry them off, why should a wife feign dislike which she knows cannot hold out long?

fields.couplet: Like wine to addicts that does disgrace Your breast, O thief, is for my embrace!
fields.meaning: O you rogue! your breast is to me what liquor is to those who rejoice in it, though it only gives them an unpleasant disgrace

fields.couplet: Flower-soft is love; a few alone Know its delicacy so fine
fields.meaning: Sexual delight is more delicate than a flower, and few are those who understand its real nature

fields.couplet: She feigned dislike awhile but flew Faster for embrace than I do
fields.meaning: She once feigned dislike in her eyes, but the warmth of her embrace exceeded my own

fields.couplet: You see, his heart is his alone; Why not my heart be all my own?
fields.meaning: O my soul! although you have seen how his soul stands by him, how is it you do not stand by me?

fields.couplet: O heart, you see how he slights me Yet you clasp him as if friendly
fields.meaning: O my soul! although you have known him who does not love me, still do you go to him, saying "he will not be displeased."

fields.couplet: You follow him at will Is it \"The fallen have no friends\" my heart?
fields.meaning: O my soul! do you follow him at pleasure under the belief that the ruined have no friends?

fields.couplet: You won't sulk first and then submit Who will then consult you, my heart?
fields.meaning: O my soul! you would not first seem sulky and then enjoy (him); who then would in future consult you about such things?

fields.couplet: Frets to gain and fears loss in gain O my heart suffers ceaseless pain
fields.meaning: My soul fears when it is without him; it also fears when it is with him; it is subject to incessant sorrow

fields.couplet: My itching mind eats me anon As I muse on him all alone
fields.meaning: My mind has been (here) in order to eat me up (as it were) whenever I think of him in my solitude

fields.couplet: I forget shame but not his thought In mean foolish mind I'm caught
fields.meaning: I have even forgotten my modesty, having been caught in my foolish mind which is not dignified enough to forget him

fields.couplet: My heart living in love of him Hails his glory ignoring blame
fields.meaning: My soul which clings to life thinks only of his (own) gain in the belief that it would be disgraceful for it to despise him

fields.couplet: Who support a man in grief If lover's heart denies relief?
fields.meaning: Who would help me out of one's distress, when one's own soul refuses help to one?

fields.couplet: Why wonder if strangers disown When one's own heart is not his own?
fields.meaning: It is hardly possible for strangers to behave like relations, when one's own soul acts like a stranger

fields.couplet: Feign sulk; embrace him not so that We can see his distress a bit
fields.meaning: Let us witness awhile his keen suffering; just feign dislike and embrace him not

fields.couplet: Sulking is the salt of love; but Too much of it spoils the taste Wife Addresses Husband
fields.meaning: A little dislike is like salt in proportion; to prolong it a little is like salt a little too much

fields.couplet: To leave the sulker unembraced Is to grieve the one sorely grieved
fields.meaning: For men not to embrace those who have feigned dislike is like torturing those already in agony

fields.couplet: To comfort not lady in pout Is to cut the fading plant at root He within Himself
fields.meaning: Not to reconcile those who have feigned dislike is like cutting a faded creeper at its root

fields.couplet: Pouting of flower-eyed has To pure good mates a lovely grace
fields.meaning: An increased shyness in those whose eyes are like flowers is beautiful even to good and virtuous husbands

fields.couplet: Love devoid of frowns and pets Misses its ripe and unripe fruits
fields.meaning: Sexual pleasure, without prolonged and short-lived dislike, is like too ripe, and unripe fruit

fields.couplet: \"Will union take place soon or late?\" In lover's pout this leaves a doubt
fields.meaning: The doubt as to whether intercourse would take place soon or not, creates a sorrow (even) in feigned dislike

fields.couplet: What's the good of grieving lament When concious lover is not present?
fields.meaning: What avails sorrow when I am without a wife who can understand the cause of my sorrow?

fields.couplet: Water delights in a shady grove And sulking in souls of psychic love
fields.meaning: Like water in the shade, dislike is delicious only in those who love

fields.couplet: My heart athirst would still unite With her who me in sulking left!
fields.meaning: It is nothing but strong desire that makes her mind unite with me who can leave her to her own dislike

fields.couplet: I shrink to clasp you bosom lewd To the gaze of all ladies exposed
fields.meaning: You are given to prostitution; all those who are born as womankind enjoy you with their eyes in an ordinary way I will not embrace you

fields.couplet: He sneezed while we went on sulking Expecting me to say \"live long\"
fields.meaning: When I continued to be sulky he sneezed and thought I would (then) wish him a long life

fields.couplet: \"For which lady?\" she widely cries While I adorn myself with flowers
fields.meaning: Even if I were adorned with a garland of branch-flowers, she would say I did so to show it to another woman

fields.couplet: \"I love you more than all\" I said \"Than whom, than whom?\" she sulked and chid
fields.meaning: When I said I loved her more than any other woman, she said "more than others, yes, more than others," and remained sulky

fields.couplet: \"In this life we won't part\" I told Her eyes at once with tears were filled
fields.meaning: When I said I would never part from her in this life her eyes were filled with tears

fields.couplet: I said I thought of you She left Her embrace crying \"Oft you forget\"
fields.meaning: When I said I had remembered her, she said I had forgotten her and relaxing her embrace, began to feign dislike

fields.couplet: I sneezed; she blessed; then changed and wept  \"You sneezed now at which lady's thought?\"
fields.meaning: When I sneezed she blessed me, but at once changed (her mind) and wept, asking, "At the thought of whom did you sneeze?"

fields.couplet: I repressed sneeze; she wept crying \"Your thoughts from me you are hiding\"
fields.meaning: When I suppressed my sneezing, she wept saying, "I suppose you (did so) to hide from me your own people's remembrance of you"

fields.couplet: I try to coax her and she remarks \"Your coaxing others thus this marks\"
fields.meaning: 'I see', quoth she, 'to other folks How you are wondrous kind' Even when I try to remove her dislike, she is displeased and says, "This is the way you behave

fields.couplet: I think and gaze at her; she chides: \"On whom your thought just now abides?\"
fields.meaning: Even when I look on her contemplating (her beauty), she is displeased and says, "With whose thought have you (thus) looked on my person?"

fields.couplet: He is flawless; but I do pout So that his loving ways show out
fields.meaning: Although my husband is free from defects, the way in which he embraces me is such as to make me feign dislike

fields.couplet: Fading first, love blooms and outlives The petty pricks that pouting gives
fields.meaning: His love will increase though it may (at first seem to) fade through the short-lived distress caused by (my) dislike

fields.couplet: Is there a heaven like sulk beneath Of hearts that join like water and earth?
fields.meaning: Is there a celestial land that can please like the feigned dislike of those whose union resembles that of earth and water?

fields.couplet: In long pout after embrace sweet A weapon is up to break my heart
fields.meaning: In prolonged dislike after an embrace there is a weapon that can break my heart

fields.couplet: Though free form faults, one feels the charms Of feigned release from lover's arms
fields.meaning: Though free from defects, men feel pleased when they cannot embrace the delicate shoulders of those whom they love

fields.couplet: Sweeter than meal is digestion And sulk in love than union
fields.meaning: To digest what has been eaten is more delightful than to eat more; likewise love is more delightful in dislike than intercourse

fields.couplet: The yielder wins in lover's pout Reunited joy brings it out
fields.meaning: Those are conquerors whose dislike has been defeated and that is proved by the love (which

fields.couplet: Shall not our pouting again give The dew-browed joy of joint love?
fields.meaning: Will I enjoy once more through her dislike, the pleasure of that love that makes her forehead perspire?

fields.couplet: Sulk on O belle of shining jewels! Prolong O night! our delight swells!
fields.meaning: May the bright-jewelled one feign dislike, and may the night be prolonged for me to implore her!

fields.couplet: Bouderie is lovers' delight Its delight grows when they unite
fields.meaning: Dislike adds delight to love; and a hearty embrace (thereafter) will add delight to dislike
